IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) have been targeted therapeutically in cancer with agents designed to block all activity, and shut down aberrant signaling. The work proposed in this application will investigate whether it is possible to alter the dynamics of receptor signaling, and correct (rather than simply inhibit) aberrant signaling by oncogenic receptors – causing them to promote death or quiescence of cancer cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: This proposal will develop a Staphylococcus aureus (SA) vaccine delivery system comprising: (a) an injectable biodegradable (i.e., temporary) porous hydrogel “depot” that releases nanoparticles containing self-replicating mRNA (SR-mRNA) vaccine vectors expressing multi-valent SA adhesin genes. Novel cationic polymers condense and charge neutralize anionic SR-mRNA vaccines into nanoparticles (known as “polyplexes”) that are incorporated into the liquid hydrogel prior to injection and subsequent gelation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The goal of this study is to investigate how modulating the DNA methylome in pancreatic progenitors impact postnatal functional beta-cell mass. The significance is that humans need to maintain certain levels of this mass to avoid debilitating hypoglycemia or diabetes. We expect to uncover basic molecular and cellular mechanisms to help improve the regulation of this mass to avoid these diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although evidence-based treatment targets exist to change binge eating and weight-related behaviors, we do not know which targets to recommend to which people and how best to do so, which impedes our ability to precisely intervene. This trial aims to resolve gaps in our understanding of target selection within the behavior change process to optimize a digital guided self-help intervention into a just-in-time adaptive intervention that delivers personalized interventions in real time based on users’ changing needs. Results have implications beyond the current intervention given the role of these targets and processes for behavior change broadly, as well as for other multi-component interventions in how to package and deliver effective and engaging interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Minority children have outnumbered White children since 2020, but pediatric workforce diversity has failed to keep pace, especially in academia, with minorities comprising 50% of US children, but only 24% of US pediatricians, and underrepresented minorities make up only 11% of pediatricians and 10% of US medical- school faculty. Now in its 10th year, the Academic Pediatric Association (APA) Research in Academic Pediatrics Initiative on Diversity (RAPID) is the first research educational program targeting faculty diversity in general academic pediatrics, and an additional five years of funding is requested; the aim of RAPID is to design, implement, and evaluate a research educational program with the goal of successful recruitment, retention, and professional advancement of diverse junior faculty in general academic pediatrics who are pursuing careers in biomedical, behavioral, clinical, and social sciences consistent with NIDDK mission areas. If, as anticipated, the program continues to be highly successful, APA RAPID will result in: successful recruitment, retention, and professional advancement of diverse junior faculty researchers; increased likelihood that RAPID Scholars will present their project findings at a national professional meeting, publish their project findings, obtain additional research funding, maintain their APA membership, and highly rate their commitment to a research career in pediatric academic generalism; and a potential model societal program for enhancing the diversity of young investigators and their leadership skills.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Understanding the detailed organization and function of visual cortical areas and their underlying circuits is necessary to obtain a mechanistic understanding of visual processing and also contributes more generally to understanding circuit mechanisms across the cerebral cortex. Deficits in central visual processing are linked to strabismus, amblyopia and dyslexia. More generally, understanding circuit mechanisms that underlie cortical function also has important implications for diseases such as schizophrenia and autism, where impairments in the function of cortical circuits is implicated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Although tremendous progress has been made in treatment modalities of myeloproliferative neoplasms (MPNs), there is the necessity to improve and develop novel therapeutic approaches. Based on gene mutation profiling we propose to identify biomarkers for MPNs displaying specific defects in DNA damage repair pathways. These pathways will be then attacked by DNA repair inhibitors combined with already approved drugs to eliminate quiescent and proliferating MPN stem and progenitor cells without affecting normal cells and tissues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: This proposal seeks to validate an innovative therapeutic strategy potentially applicable to a broad spectrum of neurodegenerative disorders based on modulating the localization of NMDA Receptors (NMDARs) within the synapse. Because the activation of NMDARs located at the synaptic sites (sNMDARs) triggers pro-survival intracellular cascades whereas the overactivation of extrasynaptically located NMDARs (exNMDARs) is toxic for the neuron (excitotoxicity), we propose to interfere with the molecular mechanisms that control NMDAR localization to promote sNMDAR expression and decrease exNMDAR expression. If successful, this novel approach will contribute to reducing the burdens of illness and disability of many patients because excitotoxicity has been associated with Alzheimer’s and Huntington’s diseases, Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis and Multiple Sclerosis, among other neuropathies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Toxoplasma gondii is the causative agent of Toxoplasmosis, a life-threatening disease in immunocompromised individuals. In this proposal, we will focus on understanding how the parasites’ actin cytoskeleton drives intracellular cargo transport. Impaired protein trafficking through the secretory system results in parasite death so identification of novel proteins in this pathway paves the way for identification of new targets for anti-parasitic drug development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Palliative radiation therapy (RT) – RT intended to reduce symptoms rather than achieve cure – creates both benefits and harms, particularly for older adults in whom cancer occurs in a complex setting of multimorbidity and geriatric conditions. Little is known about the contribution of these geriatric conditions to RT-related outcomes in older adults with advanced cancer, including how they relate to (1) difficulties completing RT; (2) changes in function, hospitalization, and mortality after RT; and (3) self-reported toxicities and quality of life. This study examines risk factors associated with both incomplete treatment with palliative RT and treatment- related adverse outcomes in older adults, results of which will support a future R01 application that tests a targeted and geriatrics-driven intervention that improves post-RT outcomes important to older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neuromodulator signaling pathways in the brain are important therapeutic targets for the treatment of addiction. New pharmacology that targets these pathways is urgently needed, but it has proved difficult to discover in an unbiased manner novel small molecules with strong and specific effects on neuromodulator signaling. To address this need, we have established and validated a behavior-based screening platform that interrogates a rich and novel source of natural products - the 'dark' microbial metabolome - for fundamentally new classes of psychoactive compounds that target neuromodulator signaling systems integral to the pathology of addiction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: This work will define mechanisms that control gene expression to drive the development of human cortical interneurons. Mutations in the human genome sequence frequently disrupt these gene regulatory controls, perturbing interneuron development and contributing to disorders of the developing nervous system, such as pediatric epilepsies and autism spectrum and intellectual disability disorders. Many aspects of regulation of this developmental program appear to be unique to humans, and human genome sequence variants that cause disease are also often not present in other species. Therefore, modeling how this human neurodevelopmental program is regulated is necessary to build a foundation and resources for determining how such human- specific mutations disrupt this regulation to contribute to neurodevelopmental disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Radiation induced xerostomia (RIX) is among the most common side effect of radiation observed in head and neck cancer patients, has limited and relatively ineffective treatment options, and can cause severe adverse effects that damage patient’s quality of life. This proposal aims to evaluate the use and efficacy of mesenchymal stromal cells (MSCs) in the treatment of RIX in a mouse model and to support the career development of the PI. Our long-term goal is that this work leads to the development of novel and effective therapies for RIX to improve patient’s quality of life after radiation for head and neck cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In order for full restorative sleep to occur, the brain must exit the aroused and awake state and enter into a deep state of what is called “Slow Wave Sleep.” Neurons in the brainstem medullary region, coined the “parafacial zone” due to its location by the seventh facial nerve, strongly promote this stage of sleep and gaining an understanding of the cellular and circuit mechanisms underpinnings of how this occurs is vital in furthering our understanding of sleep-wake regulation. The proposed research is expected to uncover new targets leading to the development of new therapeutic and interventional strategies, and thereby reduce the burden of human disability, in not only sleep-wake related disorders such as insomnia, but also in neurodegenerative and neuropsychiatric disorders associated with sleep disruption.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative In addition to differentiated organ-specific cells, organs contain connective tissue cells, or stromal cells, and resident immune cells, and tissue insults lead to changes in the activity of both cell populations, including the production by stromal cells of cytokines that affect T cell biology and the establishment of specialized T cells capable of making cytokines that alter stromal cell biology. Ideally, these interactions lead to increased tissue resilience and help promote resistance to the source of the tissue insults, but dysregulated interactions can lead to loss of critical tissue functions. Our work will help delineate the mechanisms underlying these divergent outcomes and in so doing identify pathways amenable to therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative:  Alcohol and cannabis consumption occur significantly in the world’s population, and polysubstance misuse by adolescents may have significant long-term effects on cognitive and other biological systems. Alcohol intoxication has been linked to immune dis-regulation in the brain, liver and lung. Currently, contributing effects of alcohol and cannabis adolescent exposure upon lung inflammation and pneumonia remain unclear. Directed therapeutics can then be developed from these mechanistic studies, to improve the health, vitality and productivity of alcohol and/or cannabis-exposed people in our society. .

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adoptive T cell therapies have shown impressive performance in directing the immune system against some cancers, however the majority of patients still do not respond to this promising therapeutic strategy and new tools are needed to accelerate the discovery of more potent T cell therapies. We recently developed a novel CRISPR screening platform that enables comprehensive and efficient screening in primary human T cells for genes that regulate key therapeutic functions. We identified SOCS1 and RASA2 in a screen for genes that regulate T cell proliferation, and my proposed research aims to show that editing these genes can generate potent next-generation T cell therapies to ultimately improve responses in more cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The NLRP3 inflammasome forms a supramolecular complex that recruits and activates caspase-1, and plays key roles in innate immune surveillance of infections and other types of danger. These important functions of NLRP3 have garnered extensive interest by both academia and industry, which has transformed NLRP3 as a heavily pursued therapeutic target for diseases of aging and inflammation, including cardiovascular and neurodegenerative diseases. Investigating the functional mechanism of NLRP3 inflammasome activation would provide mechanistic insights that guide the development of NLRP3-targeted therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative There is currently no known prevention, cure, or effective treatment for Alzheimer’s disease and related dementia (ADRD) even as the number of people with ADRD is projected to increase dramatically as the population ages. Given these circumstances, policymakers, advocates, clinicians, patients, and caregivers have asked researchers to improve our understanding of the social and cultural dynamics of ADRD in order to develop effective, evidence-based, and sustainable approaches for caring for ADRD-impacted populations. This project develops research resources at the University of California San Francisco that address the need to advance research on the social and cultural dimensions of aging and ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed work on the mechanisms of retinal iron regulation is important for protecting human health because iron toxicity can occur when iron-containing metal gets into the eye in an accident, when there's bleeding in the eye, and in patients with aceruloplasminemia, age-related macular degeneration (AMD), glaucoma, diabetic retinopathy, and retinitis pigmentosa. Our knowledge of retinal iron regulation in the normal retina and understanding of the mechanism of iron accumulation in retinal disease are incomplete. The proposed studies will test mechanisms of transport and toxicity of ferrous iron, as well as a drug with strong potential to inhibit the toxicity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The parasite that causes Chagas disease infects almost six million people globally and causes more morbidity than any other parasitic pathogen in the Americas; congenital infections account for 22% of the 39,000 new infections annually, but unfortunately, many diagnoses are missed because of complicated diagnostic algorithms and a lack of tools to predict which infants are at highest risk. We propose a cohort study in Santa Cruz, Bolivia, where 20% of young women have Chagas disease, to identify risk factors for mother-to-child transmission, understand parasite gene expression signatures that increase risk of infection, and develop better diagnostic tests to detect infections soon after birth. Our innovative approach will integrate field epidemiology, cutting-edge sequencing techniques, and new diagnostics to improve our ability to identify pregnancies at high risk for vertical transmission and diagnose infected infants in the first weeks of life, thus increasing the number of affected children who are cured and decreasing the burden of Chagas disease worldwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE New therapeutic strategies are desperately needed for small cell lung cancer (SCLC), a highly aggressive disease for which outcomes have remained virtually unchanged for thirty years. Our preliminary data indicate that SCLC inter-tumoral heterogeneity among distinct molecular subsets imparts distinct vulnerabilities to chemotherapy, targeted therapies, and, potentially, immunotherapies; and that intra-tumoral heterogeneity (ITH) contributes to SCLC relapse and drug resistance. This proposal will investigate the therapeutic vulnerabilities of SCLC subtypes and mechanisms of resistance mediated through ITH that have the potential to be rapidly translated into effective, biomarker-driven approaches for patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Although progression of nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) to fibrotic non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) is emerging as the leading cause of liver disease, there are no FDA-approved drugs for NASH. To identify novel therapeutic targets of NAFLD/NASH, we will leverage the Pakistan Genomic Resource (PGR) that has established the world's largest biobank of human knockouts by leveraging high levels of consanguinity in Pakistan and conduct: (i) large-scale genetic analyses in at-least 700,000 participants of multi-ethnic origin to identify potential causal genes associated with NAFLD/NASH, (ii) conduct call back studies in human knockouts and their consanguineous family members to confirm the causal nature of such genes and assess any adverse effects resulting due to natural deficiency of such genes; (iii) investigate genetic variations that associate with progression of NAFLD to NASH; and (iv) conduct focused mechanistic studies in cells and mice for two high priority genes, WWP2 and CASP8, that have been linked with NAFLD/NASH risk through the studies we have already conducted. Evidence from our proposed studies should identify new mechanism-based, efficacious, and safe therapeutic targets for NASH that are validated through human genetics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Valium, Xanax, and related drugs, referred to as “benzodiazepines” are prescribed widely for the treatment of anxiety disorders, one of the most common psychiatric disorders in the U.S. Benzodiazepines are considered to be among the safest prescription drugs in modern medicine, but they unfortunately are also addictive drugs. The overall goal of this application is to uncover mechanisms that underlie long-term exposure to benzodiazepines, namely tolerance and physical dependence, in order to develop safer and more effective medications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: OVERALL This renewal of the Asthma and Allergic Disease Cooperative Research Center (AADCRC) program will continue to evaluate the still under-studied components of innate immunity and viral infection is asthma: Palmitoyl-oleoyl- phosphatidylglycerol (POPG), phosphatidylinositol (PI), Toll interacting protein (Tollip) and surfactant protein-A (SP-A) and their impact upon viral infections in asthma. The strong synergy and 20-year collaboration among the AADCRC’s three projects and project leaders will accelerate progress toward novel therapies by demonstrating that the innate immune components under study protect against viral infection in asthma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative A number of lines of evidence, including subjective self-report, suggest that difﬁculties with facial perception and memory are components of the deﬁcits experienced in diabetic retinopathy. However, very little work has been done on this question. The goals of the present effort are to (a) quantify the prevalence and severity of problems with facial perception and memory in non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy, (b) empirically analyze the representation and processing of two canonical forms of facial information (featural and conﬁgural), and (c) provide a ﬁrst formal theoretical account of that representation and processing, all in a sample of individuals with non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy, with and without macular edema.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE The slow pace of progress in understanding brain disorders is partly due to a lack of access to live neurons from patients for detailed investigation by imaging, recording, and stimulation. We propose to build the next-generation, in vitro organoid models of human brain function by including neural projections that release modulatory molecules. We plan to use this novel system to understand how communication between brain regions goes wrong in genetic neurodevelopmental disorders and to identify means to reverse these defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Metabolic syndrome (METS) and type 2 diabetes (T2D) are common, but complex, health conditions affecting 1/3 of the US population and increasing the risk of death and disability. The goal of this project is to define the relationship between brain inflammation and an early pathophysiologic feature of these diseases: impaired sympathetic nerve mediated lipolysis in adipose tissue. The results of this project will be applicable to targeting brain inflammation and adipose tissue dysfunction in the context of METS and T2D.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Loss of the Y chromosome in the blood of males increases with age, and it is associated with diminished survival and an increase risk of various diseases. However, it is not known if the loss of the Y chromosome has a causal role in age-associated diseases or whether it is an epiphenomenon of biological aging processes. We will employ novel mouse models to test whether the loss of the Y chromosome in blood cells impacts pathological cardiac remodeling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: TEXAS TECH UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCES CENTER AT EL PASO
PHR: Project narrative  MicroRNAs (miRNAs) enrichment was detected at synapse and synaptosomal components; however, the status of synaptosomal miRNAs and their precise roles in Alzheimer's disease progression are completely unexplored. Present study is designed to determine the status of synaptosomal and cytosolic miRNAs in Alzheimer's disease and to unveil their possible roles in amyloid-β and p-tau induced synaptic damage and cognitive dysfunction. The outcome of our study is expected to provide new insights about synaptosome- specific miRNAs and their therapeutic relevance in synaptic dysfunction in Alzheimer's disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: NARRATIVE The active role of osteocytes, cells embedded within bone, in maintaining skeletal health is disrupted with aging. Here we test the possibility that the disruption of osteocyte function with age contributes to age-related bone fragility and joint degeneration. Testing this hypothesis will advance our understanding of the cellular and molecular mechanisms controlling bone quality and joint disease, which will improve the success of clinical efforts to protect musculoskeletal health throughout the lifespan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The Medical Student Summer Research Program (MSSRP) aims to foster the development of biomedical, behavioral and clinical researchers among medical students who are in the early stages of their career decision-making. The MSSRP’s immersive approach exposes students to both the scientific principles underlying cardiovascular, pulmonary and hematological diseases and their translation to new clinical paradigms during intense, summer experiences encompassing laboratory and didactic training within an integrated and collaborative scientific environment. The overall goal is to help ensure that an adequate supply of diverse, well-trained physician scientists is available to address the needs of the public in these interest areas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our understanding of human health and disease and our capacity to develop disease treatment hinges critically on knowledge of the three-dimensional architectures and functional mechanisms of cellular macromolecules and macromolecular complexes. The terrestrial transcriptome, shaped in part by the action of ribozymes, comprises RNAs and RNA-protein complexes (RNPs) that play major roles in human health and disease. Nevertheless, knowledge of RNA and RNP function and our ability to target them with small molecules remains limited due to challenges in determining their structures and mechanisms at atomic resolution. The Piccirilli laboratory proposes two lines of investigation into noncoding RNA structure and function (1) the development of target- specific synthetic antibodies as crystallization/cryoEM chaperones for obtaining structures of RNAs, RNPs, and their complexes with small molecules, and (2) use of established ribozymes as model systems and new human ribozymes as exploratory targets to develop and apply chemical approaches to achieve deep understanding of how these catalysts shape the terrestrial transcriptome in health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Coagulation factor VIII (FVIII) and its carrier protein von Willebrand factor (VWF) play an essential role in blood coagulation, and their levels are associated with several arterial and venous thrombotic diseases. We will expand our knowledge of the genetics of FVIII and VWF levels in multi-ethnic populations, and explore complex regulatory mechanisms influencing FVIII and VWF levels such as epistasis and epigenetics. Results from this study will lead to a better understanding of the genomic and epigenetic regulation of FVIII and VWF levels and whether they play an independent or coordinated role in the pathology of thrombotic disease, thereby informing the targeted use of existing and novel therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Drug treatments to improve health should not cause sickness, pain, or distress. Our reality, however, is that science and medicine are far from achieving this goal. Understanding how disturbances in feeding behavior (e.g., anorexia/hunger loss, nausea/vomiting) and pathological weight loss or gain occur when treating those who suffer from chronic disease requires us to interrogate neurobiological systems out of balance in such conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE / PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Inflammation and immunity play dominant roles in physiological processes critical to controlling pathologies associated with infectious agents and cancer. Furthermore, immune deregulation can lead to autoimmune or immunodeficiency disorders. Major gaps exist in our understanding of the complex immunoregulatory network that controls these mechanisms. Therefore, increased understanding of the intricate signaling mechanisms central to coordinating these immunomodulatory responses is critical for designing effective immuno- and pharmacotherapies to combat disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative In the United States, 60% of adults have at least one chronic disease such as heart disease, cancer, and diabetes and 40% have two or more. Although research has identified genomic signatures of common diseases, these genomic risk assessments are not used in clinical care to identify, and if appropriate, pre-treat patients at high risk for developing disease. Establishing methods to implement genomic risk assessment and management in clinical care is the vital first step to leverage the power of genomics to prevent disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Narrative:  Circadian rhythms play a critical role: they optimize metabolism, physiology and behavior with the time-of-day. Our goal is to uncover the basic molecular and cellular mechanisms governing circadian rhythms and an important complex behavior they control, sleep. To this end, we use Drosophila because this model organism has proven to be particularly potent to reveal fundamental and conserved mechanisms underlying circadian clocks and sleep. Thus, we anticipate that our work will ultimately impact our understanding of diseases and ailments linked to circadian rhythm and sleep disruptions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Thyroid hormone (TH) is a critical mediator of fetal development and then essential for normal health during adulthood. Currently, therapy for those with hypothyroidism (either congenital or acquired later in life) is with L-thyroxine and many individuals on therapy do not feel adequately replaced, in this proposal we put forward experiments designed to develop thyroid hormone secreting follicular cells from human induced pluripotent stem cells. Completion of this work will give us significant insight into the developmental biology of the human thyroid and potentially offer a unique and powerful approach to treat hypothyroidism in humans, furthermore, the development of follicular cells from progenitor cells will give us an ideal model to better understand many diseases of the thyroid that affect human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our proposed research will identify fuels, such as ketone bodies, that support and direct different protective T cell lineages, as well as the system-level processes that control availability of these fuels. By defining how protective immune responses to infection are supported and directed by ketone body metabolism, the proposed research could be transformative, allowing us to better understand, treat, and prevent infectious diseases. Findings from these studies will provide a springboard for immunometabolic therapeutic research, opening new horizons for leveraging diet—such as exogenous metabolite supplementation or caloric restriction—to regulate host immune response to infection, ultimately boosting host defense and/or enhancing immunization effectiveness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The problems associated with an aging society transcend the boundaries of any specific discipline and play out across multiple biologic and societal domains ranging from individual cells to national and world economies. The six National Institute on Aging center programs address important topics in aging but typically from a specific disciplinary perspective. The objective of the Research Centers Coordinating Network is to initiate new cross‐disciplinary collaborative networks that bring together key thought leaders from each of the 6 NIA centers programs to align approaches across programs that will uncover synergies and insights leading to novel collaborations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative- Longworth, Michelle S. The de-repression of retrotransposable elements (RTEs) within the human genome leads to upregulation of Type I IFNs which can cause cell death, and this is currently being explored as a potential mechanism to kill cancer cells, in combination with immune checkpoint inhibitors. We discovered that condensin complexes are necessary for the ability of RTEs to induce IFN in epithelial cells (the most common cell type that develops into solid tumors), and in this proposal, we will determine how RTE expression influences condensins to promote Type I IFN induction and uncover novel roles for condensins in RTE-mediated innate immune signaling responses. Results will expand our knowledge of how RTEs activate innate immune responses, and identify new pathways that can be modulated to enhance cancer therapies that rely on RTE-mediated IFN induction to kill cancer cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative All organisms continuously perceive and evaluate nutrient availability, demand, and palatability. Recent research has shown that homeostatic drives are as influential in this process as are pleasurable experiences, and our work using the fruit fly, Drosophila melanogaster, has established that aging is modulated by these motivational states. Our proposed studies will dissect the molecular mechanisms through which neural states of feeding motivation influence aging and physiology in flies to illuminate how similar processes may control healthy aging in mammals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research will employ cutting-edge eye tracking methods to investigate fine-scale eye movement differences in psychosis, a topic that has barely been explored. Such an investigation constitutes an important first step towards characterizing the psychosis phenotype, which in turn could clarify the pathophysiology of psychosis and generate new methods for differential diagnosis. The proposed research will also provide a potentially new explanation of visual acuity and reading deficits in psychosis. This explanation, once established, can suggest new treatments and interventions for psychosis patients who exhibit poor acuity or reading ability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: O’Brien R50 Research Specialist (Clinician Scientist) Project Narrative Funding of Dr. O’Brien’s research efforts within the NCTN Children’s Oncology Group (COG) will contribute to advances in the treatment of children, adolescents, and young adults with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) through the evaluation of novel targeted therapies with the goal of improving efficacy and decreasing short and long-term toxicities. Over the next decade, the COG ALL committee aims to optimize the incorporation of immune-based therapies including blinatumomab, inotuzumab ozogamicin, and chimeric antigen receptor T-cell therapy as well as evaluate genomically targeted therapies in specific patient subgroups. Pharmacogenomic studies will be critical to identifying predictors of toxicity and response and tailoring therapy with both conventional and novel agents across diverse populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Macrophages, a type of immune cells, capture microbial pathogens in vesicles known as phagosomes, which are gradually filled with acid as they move towards the center of the immune cell where they fuse with another vesicle known as the lysosome for pathogen elimination. The goal of our proposal is to elucidate how the acid in the phagosome lumen governs the transport of the phagosome. Pathogens that cause severe diseases in humans employ various mechanisms to subvert phagosomal acidification, and therefore insights gained from this study will have significant implications for developing effective methods to combat these highly dangerous microbes.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Many children with cerebral palsy are often deprived of participation in life activities given limited postural control and walking capabilities, leading to delayed development and low quality of life. Ride-on power mobility devices allow for the self-generated, active control of mobility, with a novel stand-on ride-on device providing an additional support to maintaining upright posture to improve children’s balance and lower extremity strength. Our proposal will be the first study to evaluate biomechanical factors underlying expected changes in balance and mobility function after stand-on ride- on device use and generate fundamental knowledge to guide subsequent intervention work to enhance functional outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Over 280,000 people die from advanced heart failure each year in the United States. Clinical practice guidelines strongly recommend specialist palliative care for people with advanced heart failure to help address their many palliative care needs, however, few receive this vital service. Using mixed methods, this project will identify strategies that increase access to specialist palliative care and improve care near the end of life, findings that can inform the policies and care practices of palliative and cardiology programs nationwide, and improve the care of people with advanced heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Alternating phosphorylation states of α− and β-tubulin in microtubules define a “toggle switch” model to be explored as a novel decision-point in cell behavior. Phosphorylation of α-tubulin or β-tubulin could determine whether a breast cancer cell metastasizes to a remote site or proliferates into a primary tumor, respectively. The α/β-tubulin toggle switch could have intrinsic biological significance as well as clinical value as a therapeutic target and prognostic indicator of metastatic potential.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our 24-hour world requires people to work outside normal sleeping hours and is associated with the risk of developing health issues including hypertension; these hours induce a misalignment between the endogenous circadian system, also known as circadian misalignment. Despite these health issues related to a misalignment between the endogenous circadian system there are limited studies determining the mechanisms behind the development of these issues. Thus, the proposed studies will provide a major step in understanding the link between central mechanisms, cardiovascular regulation and associated cardiovascular risk in circadian misalignment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO MED SCIENCES
PHR: PI: Baerga-Ortiz, Abel Title: Genotoxicity and immunogenicity of the uropathogenic specific protein (usp) in the gut Project Narrative Over the last decade, there has been an explosion of interest in the role of the gut microbiota in the maintenance of human health. While the gut microbiota is generally considered to be beneficial, certain microbial strains have been found, some widely distributed in the population, that harbor toxins and other negative effectors. This proposal aims to dissect the possible damaging effects to intestinal cells of the bacterial uropathogenic specific protein (USP), a toxin originally identified in urinary tract infections, but also found in the GI tract.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: While JQ1 as an inhibitor of epigenetics showed very promising results in treatment of cancer including triple negative breast cancer (TNBC), it developed resistance in TNBC. We propose to test a hypothesis that downregulation of a protein in cell fusion named MFSD2 mediates JQ1-induced cell fusion and drug resistance. Successful completion of the project will lead to future identification of specific MFSD2 activators as drug candidates to prevent JQ1 resistance in TNBC.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The PaRtnEring to build understanding oF gEnomics Responsibly Community Health Worker (PREFER CHW) genomics research education program is a first-of-its-kind training focused on building CHW competencies in genomics to support a diverse genomics research workforce and enhance diversity of participants in genomics research. IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: This project will support the use of Tetrahymena thermophila as a tool for basic and applied biomedical research. Research conducted with this organism has contributed fundamental knowledge of key biological processes and revealed understanding of health-related phenomena including cancer, aging, (in)fertility, respiratory and neuroendocrine function. It has also proven useful for practical applications as manufacturing system for vaccine candidates and therapeutics proteins for the treatment of human disease.

PHR: Project Narrative  This project seeks to expand understanding of how decoration of Notch signaling receptors with sugars influences the formation and function of osteoclasts, bone-dissolving cells. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Chronic pain is a disabling condition that is accompanied by neuropsychiatric comorbidities such as anxiety, depression, and cognitive decline. While the peripheral alterations are well-studied, we lack an understanding of how these peripheral changes can result in long-lasting brain alterations and the ensuing behavioral phenotypes. Using a well-characterized mouse model of peripheral neuropathy, we propose to test the hypothesis that changes in brain vascular anatomy and function are major factors controlling supraspinal neuronal and glial plasticity that is a hallmark of chronic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Antibodies are invaluable in basic biomedical research and biotechnology, but lack chemical features that facilitate enzyme inhibition, covalent target engagement, and other function-disrupting bioactivities. This program seeks to advance the yeast-based biosynthesis and high throughput screening of “chemically expanded” antibodies. Our investigations will lead to inhibitors for studying how cells move, interact with their surroundings, and signal with one another while also revealing crucial principles of protein biosynthesis and enzyme inhibitor discovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Interoceptive skills serve a critical function to human health and well-being. Using novel quantitative approaches, this research will advance public health knowledge by addressing the current limitations in the measurement of interoception to strengthen the validity of a widely adopted tool for examining interoceptive sensibility in the context of mind-body interventions. The project will also contribute new information about how the dimensions of interoceptive sensibility interact to create a typology of interoceptive skills and deficits that can ultimately be used to predict distal health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE How the complexity of the brain emerges during development remains a long-standing yet poorly understood question in developmental biology. With this proposal, we will seek to integrate several cutting-edge molecular and cellular tools, such as DNA memory devices and 3D cell culture models of the developing human brain, to record the developmental signals that govern brain organogenesis at a previously inaccessible resolution and scale. The successful completion of this proposal will provide an unprecedented look into the programs underlying human brain assembly and pave way to novel therapeutic opportunities in tissue repair, cancer, and neurodevelopmental disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the cause of most hospital-acquired infections, infecting more than two million people annually and resulting in almost 90,000 deaths. Notably, the environmental versatility of P. aeruginosa, its multiple mechanisms for antibiotic resistance, and its wide range of dynamic defenses (e.g., biofilm formation), render it a most challenging organism to effectively treat. Understanding the proteins that regulate these processes (e.g., transcription factors) will illuminate new pathways and targets for the development of anti-P. aeruginosa therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Exposure therapy is the most effective treatment available for obsessive compulsive disorder, yet up to 50% of patients fail to recover because we do not understand the mechanisms underlying successful response, leading to significant variability in how clinicians conduct exposure therapy. Using machine learning to analyze patient data from real-world treatment, the current study will determine which exposure mechanisms lead to favorable clinical outcomes and what makes a good exposure for whom. Results of this study have the potential to improve personalized care for the many patients who do not remit following exposure therapy for OCD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Center for Cellular Adaptation at the University of Chicago is undertaking a comprehensive project to understand the fundamental processes that enable cells to adapt to changes in their environment, which could lead to innovative therapeutic interventions for a wide range of diseases. The research involves three main thrusts: investigating how cells adapt on very short timescales (from milliseconds to minutes) by changing the location and activity of proteins, understanding how cells adapt on longer time scales (minutes to days) by adjusting the activity of their genes, and studying adaptation on the even longer time scales of multi-generational inheritance (days to years). Through this collaborative, multiscale approach, the team aims to provide a unified framework that links adaptive processes on physiological and evolutionary timescales, potentially reshaping our understanding of cellular maladaptation in aging, cancer, and neurodegeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative In this project we will determine the roles of specialized white blood cells, called chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T cells, in promoting an immune response against tumors and reduction of toxicity in mice when combined with an FDA-approved anti-inflammatory drug and determining their potential for use in cancer adoptive cell immunotherapy. We hypothesize that transfer of these tumor-killing CAR T cells will eradicate established tumors and prevent recurrence in vivo in both mouse and human tumor models, due to their ability to 1) directly kill the tumor cells; 2) reprogram macrophage to facilitate host antitumor immune responses, and 3) reprogram macrophage to reduce toxicities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The preschool years are a sensitive period for the development of self-regulatory skills and reward-related brain activity that support socioemotional development. Maternal socialization of positive emotion is one important influence on development of reward-related brain activity in children, both of which can be impaired by maternal depression. To better understand how reward-related brain activity develops in the context of parenting, we will examine how maternal coaching of positive emotion in children of depressed mothers influences in-the-moment reward-related brain response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative – Core A The goal of this proposal is to sustain and enhance the Administrative and Faculty Development Core (Core A) of a Phase II Center of Biomedical Research Excellence (COBRE) that is focused on molecular and cellular signal transduction in the cardiovascular system within the University of Nevada, Reno (UNR). Core A houses the infrastructure to manage administrative, fiscal, and scientific aspects of the COBRE; execute a Faculty Development Plan to promote the rapid development of the COBRE’s Research Project Leaders (RPLs) from early-stage investigators to fully independent research scientists; continuously track and evaluate the progress of RPLs to scientific independence; establish and execute a Pilot Projects Program; and track and assess the success of the Research Cores.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative – High Spatial and Temporal Resolution Imaging (HSTRI) Core (Core C) We propose to expand the services offered by the High Spatial and Temporal Resolution Imaging (HSTRI) Core established during Phase I COBRE with the goal of providing instrumentation and scientific expertise that will enable COBRE Project Leaders to perform crucial experiments that are not possible in their individual laboratories. With the assistance of expert staff and unrestricted access to these instruments, we expect the HSTRI Core to greatly enhance the competitiveness of Project Leaders in future grant applications and promote their recognition and contribution to their respective field at the international level, both of which will accelerate the pace of discovery. This facility is specifically designed to meet the needs of our Project Leaders but will also enhance the overall capacity for research by serving as a campus wide infrastructure to assist researchers at the University of Nevada, Reno, and the UNR School of Medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The sympathetic nervous system, the “fight of flight” branch of the autonomic nervous system, plays a key role in modulating cardiac output. Sympathetic overactivity during disease states such as heart failure contributes to disease pathology; however, the molecular mechanisms that contribute to this overactivity are largely unknown. In this project we propose to use high-resolution single-molecule imaging techniques to investigate the dynamic regulation of sympathetic neurons on a molecular level as an avenue to develop novel therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative  Inflammation contributes to the pathogenesis of many leading causes of mortality, including heart disease and  associated pathologies such as ischemia-reperfusion injury. Neutrophils adhere to the vessel wall through  extracellular matrix interactions mediated by integrin and spread before migrating to sites of inflammation. It has  been shown that manipulating neutrophil adhesion is beneficial in various pathological settings, including  transplantation and inflammatory bowel diseases, among others. Here, we propose to investigate the  fundamental integrin activation mechanism that drives neutrophil adhesion in inflammation. Completion of this  study is expected to provide key insights into cell adhesion mechanisms and facilitate the development of novel  drugs targeting inflammation.  2

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The sinoatrial node is the pacemaker center of the heart and is responsible for generating every heartbeat that we produce during our lifetimes. To sustain the constant electrical signal generation, blood vessels supply oxygen and nutrients to the sinoatrial node that allow it to function normally. During a disease known as heart failure, the sinoatrial node undergoes many changes to its structure and function. This project will investigate how blood flow to different regions of the sinoatrial node is regulated and how flow can change as a result of exercise and heart disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative  The brain enjoys metabolic and immunological privileges due to the presence of the blood brain barrier, a formidable barricade composed of brain microvasculature endothelial cells that have cholesterol-rich tight junctions (TJs). It is not known if the central nervous system or the vasculature provides cholesterol to the TJs under normal and under conditions of heightened oxidative stress such as those noted with aging. The goal of the proposal is to define the role of high-density lipoprotein and apolipoprotein E (both recognized as cholesterol transporters) in supplying cholesterol to the TJs using a combination of biochemical, cell biological and mass spectrometric tools.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Unplanned Emergency Department visits and hospitalizations are costly and burdensome to patients and the health system. Some of these visits may be preventable by appropriately monitoring high-risk patients to generate early warnings of deterioration and unmet health needs, but current research is limited in the patient populations studied, and by a lack of integration between remote monitoring and acute care. This project will produce a machine learning framework for integrating continuous home monitoring of vital signs and activity with acute care, to guide the development of monitoring and intervention strategies for patients discharged from the hospital, and the effective use of home monitoring data when patients return to the hospital.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO MED SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Even though successful treatments including radiation, chemotherapy and more recently targeted therapy and immunotherapy are available, the leading cause of cancer deaths in women is breast cancer. The main cause is the development of metastasis, when the primary tumor has migrated and starts to grow in distant tissues. The current research aims to develop new drugs that inhibit specific biological pathways that are involved in migration, decrease the possibility of the development of metastatic tumors and improve health outcomes for cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Health Statement: Nitrite ingestion is linked to several physiological disorders in humans (hemoglobin oxidation, heart damage, endocrine disruption, etc.), but little is known about how long-term exposure to small concentrations of nitrite through drinking water affects pregnancy and embryo development. In the proposed research project, we will explore the effects of exposure to nitrite during the full gestational period, including the effects of nitrite in the maternal transfer of steroids, immune factors, and transcripts and its concomitant effects on embryo development. Ultimately our findings will lead to a deeper understanding of the mechanisms of nitrite toxicity during gestation and will help to advance guidelines for water quality parameters to be observed for consumption during pregnancy.

PHR: Project Narrative Relevance: The requested Elyra 7, SIM2 super-resolution microscopy system will increase our understanding of the fundamental biological mechanisms involved in cell division and chromosome inheritance, intercellular signaling and intracellular transport (via the primary cilium), actin-myelin architecture of neural circuits, genomic stability, organization of cell-cell junctions, cell invasion and migration in cancer, as well calcineurin phosphatase signaling, in both normal and diseased states. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Sulfolobus Spindle-shaped Virus 1 is an astonishingly stable virus, but we do not know how it or many other viruses are made to be stable. This research will use mutagenesis and artificial evolution to determine how virus proteins fit together to make stable virus particles. These results should allow the creation of highly stable nanoparticles and stabilized vaccines and may provide insights into how to destabilize pathogenic viruses, while strengthening the Portland State University research environment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Reactivation from herpesvirus latency is an understudied area with a significant impact on multiple human diseases, and emerging evidence suggests that herpesvirus latency may protect from secondary infections. I will test the hypothesis that gammaherpesvirus latency impacts host protection during prevalent pulmonary infections in a cell intrinsic manner and define relevant mechanisms; furthermore, I will delineate the impact of the microbiota on establishment and maintenance of herpesvirus latency, given the critical impact of the microbiota on immune responses and the broad use of potent antibiotics in medical practice. At the completion of this project, I expect to define the role of latency and reactivation on human immune responsiveness and develop a framework to define how the balance between the microbiota, antibiotic use, and secondary infections are influenced by latent viral infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There has been 27.6% increase in cases of depression during the COVID-19 pandemic, particularly among specific vulnerable groups. The study will collect longitudinal data from a large and diverse population of people already enrolled in the EMBARC research study and will use a variety of methods to assess SARS- CoV-2 infection and the social determinant of health (SDOH) impact on neuroinflammation that is associated with depression. The findings of this study have important implications for public health policy and practice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Cognitive decline after radiation therapy is a major complication and has been tied to multifactorial mechanism which includes loss of synapses, white matter damage, endothelial cell damage, and activation of neuroinflammatory markers within the hippocampus and pre-frontal cortex. With increase in long term survival of patients with central nervous system malignancies, there is a critical need to understand the mechanisms behind radiation induced brain injury so that therapies can be targeted to prevent post-radiation cognitive decline. Completion of this project will characterize a non-invasive biomarker of radiation induced cognitive decline that can be translated into clinical practice that can be used for monitoring of synaptic density changes and personalize treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The project is focused on the development of a new collagen-like synthetic polymer as a potential replacement of animal-derived collagen for biomedical applications such as tissue and organ engineering, drug delivery, and wound healing. The synthetic collagen-like polymer would help to eliminate the safety and contamination concerns of animal-derived collagen. In addition, the proposed synthetic route may open the door to synthesis of other polymeric biomaterials based on short repeatable peptide sequences like ELP or RGD peptides.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The ability to accurately and efficiently discriminate others’ gaze direction is critical to social development and real-world functioning, and is disrupted in many psychiatric conditions. The goals of this study are to investi- gate how widespread the problem of altered gaze perception is among psychiatric patients with difficulties in social functioning, understand how this problem contributes to different psychiatric symptoms, and discover the cognitive and brain mechanisms underlying this problem. The results of this study are expected to guide the development of treatment strategies that aim to improve social functioning and quality of life for individuals ex- periencing socially debilitating psychiatric conditions regardless of diagnosis.

PHR: The Kritzer lab addresses foundational problems in drug discovery. In this MIRA project, we describe new innovations including novel compounds that block key proteins implicated in late-stage cancers, novel classes of compounds that can degrade any cellular protein on demand, and novel methods to understand how large- molecule therapeutics enter cells and how to design them to enter cells more efficiently.

PHR: Project Narrative The U-RISE program at North Carolina Agricultural and Technical State University (NC A&T) will substantially increase the number of graduates pursuing advanced degrees in the biomedical sciences and diversify the STEM workforce. To cultivate the science identity of underrepresented students, the program will employ a persistence framework that combines an academic support system, early research experiences and mentoring, collaborative learning, and appreciative advising. The implementation of the goals and objectives of the NC A&T U-RISE program will produce a community of Ph.D. biomedical scientists who will address biomedical issues through the creation of new and innovative technologies and cutting-edge research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The major goal of this application is to define the function of Histone 3 Lysine 9 tri-methylation (H3K9me3) deposition at the provirus 3’-end during latency reactivation. Two possible models of viral gene expression regulation and host-mediated DNA damage sensing and repair will be simultaneously interrogated. Identifying the methyl transferases involved and defining the function of H3K9me3 will provide fundamental knowledge and an opportunity to sensitize cells to latency reversal therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: We will develop Sepsis Pulse, a suite of innovative tensor-based machine learning tools for the analysis of elec- tronic health record (EHR) data, with the goal of improving progress assessment, patient phenotyping, and treat- ment planning of sepsis. These machine learning tools will focus on aligning sepsis progress timelines, pheno- typing, and estimating treatment effects while accounting for the high dimensionality, sparsity, and temporality of EHR data. Sepsis Pulse will be integrated as a module within Sepsis Watch, the digital workflow utilized in Duke Hospital’s healthcare system, to enhance the quality and outcomes of patient care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Development of brown-like white adipose tissue, beige fat, helps to reduce obesity and Type 2 diabetes, as the recently identified fat can burn energy to generate heat. We will investigate the role that a protein, TRB3, and a dietary supplement, Leucine, may play in regulation of beige fat emergence and activity. Better understanding beige fat formation and the dietary supplements that affect it may lead to the development of new drugs to treat obesity and its complications.

PHR: Project Narrative Neurophysiological and psychiatric disorders lead to severe cognitive impairments in patients and have been attributed to pathological neural synchronization and abnormal oscillations in brain circuits associated with specific diseases. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative In this study, we propose to investigate the biogenesis of mirtrons in cancers and to examine the potential roles of mirtrons in the modulation of tumor immune responses. Mirtron is an emerging new RNA subclass in the field but its biological importance in humans is completely not understood. Thus, successful completion of the project will advance current knowledge of mirtrons and their involvement in the immune regulation that will inform therapeutic strategies to treat cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Cardiac arrhythmias are responsible for the death of over 250,000 people per year in the United States alone. However, the underlying mechanisms for arrythmias is still not fully understood. The goal of this project is to understand how a single mutation in a protein that regulates calcium in the heart, can cause a heritable arrhythmia syndrome called Catecholaminergic Polymorphic Ventricular Tachycardia (CPVT). Our approach is to combine a multi-scale computational approach to model molecular, cellular, and tissue dynamics in the heart.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE This research project aims to investigate the complex relationship between recurrent hypoglycemia, vascular responses, and cognitive dysfunction in diabetic rats using a novel head-mounted dual-modality photoacoustic/ultrasound localization imaging technique tailored for freely moving rats. Through a series of experiments involving diabetic rats, we intend to simultaneously observe brain vascular patterns and cognitive behaviors with the influence of hypoglycemia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Measuring the relationship between vocal pitch and the tension and stiffness of vocal tissue in live subjects could lead to a paradigm shift in the diagnosis and monitoring of a range of voice disorders, including atrophy, the scarring or stiffening of the folds, vocal fold nodules, and paralysis. To that end we propose the development of an ultrasound elasticity imaging technique to non-invasively characterize the vocal cord tissue stiffness as a function of voice pitch. The development, validation, and verification of such a technique could lead to more effective treatment and better outcomes for patients with voice disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Blood pumps and other blood contacting medical devices may cause damage to the cells within the blood itself. Pumps designers design these devices to minimize these negative effects, but no reliable method is currently available to accurately predict these effects during the design process. This project will utilize a novel device developed by our lab to improve our understanding of the effects of shear flow on blood cell viability which will provide critical information to guide the development of next generation blood pumps or other blood contacting medical devices.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative This project investigates sexual well-being, a crucial yet often overlooked element of overall health and well- being. By developing a comprehensive model and self-report scale of sexual well-being, we aim to substantially improve our understanding and measurement of this important life domain, thereby paving the way for more effective research, interventions, policies, and education. This could have implications for reducing sexual violence and risk-taking while fostering healthy relationships and improving mental health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Head neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC) is common and aggressive cancer without effective therapy. In this proposal, we will: i) focus on the crosstalk between cancer metabolism and epigenetic regulation to study the primary forces transforming normal oral cells into HNSCC using advanced organoid technology and mouse models; ii) investigate the pharmacological and dietary inhibition of the link between methionine metabolism and epigenetic network. Our work holds the promise to fundamentally transform the understanding of cancer initiation of HNSCC, while simultaneously discovering novel intervention strategies and treatment targets for this cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Increased intracellular pH, or a reduction of acid levels inside cells, is an under-recognized hallmark of cancers regardless of the tissue of origin or underlying genetic mutations. The altered chemical environment can cause aberrant activities of select proteins to promotes tumorigenesis. This project will help us understand how proteins are regulated by acid levels, and how this contributes to tumor growth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS RIO GRANDE VALLEY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The brain white matter and its characteristic component myelin have emerged as key regulators of brain function, and their disruption potentially contributes to neurological conditions observed in children with Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). Here, myelin-focused mouse genetic models of NF1 will be used to unveil developmental and functional abnormalities of myelinating cells, abnormalities which potentially impact activity and learning in a voluntary learning test. By discovering mechanisms and their precise windows of time, these studies will facilitate the establishment of early preventive or remedial treatments for neurological issues in NF1, based on maintain- ing, restoring, or improving the function of myelin.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The so-far-unavailable, combined optical tweezers/single molecule super-resolution fluorescence microscope proposed here will be housed in the well-established, open-access, shared-use Single Molecule Analysis in Real-Time (SMART) Center at the University of Michigan to serve a broad biomedical user base in the state of Michigan. The PI Walter (University of Michigan) and key collaborator Comstock (Michigan State University) are experts in single molecule fluorescence microscopy and optical tweezers combined with single molecule fluorescence observation, respectively. In addition to best-in-class force sensitivity and integrated imaging capabilities, the proposed C-Trap instrument offers user-friendly software with a streamlined experimental workflow that will advance the goals of 7 Major and 10 Minor, overwhelmingly NIH-funded User groups working on a broad range of biomedical research problems.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: The California sea hare, Aplysia californica, is a large marine snail that has proven to be an outstanding model for studies of how the nervous system functions, particularly in memory and learning, as well as in understanding human diseases that affect these functions. The National Resource for Aplysia raises and ships 8,000-10,000 animals per year to research laboratories. This proposal would continue the production of these animals and expand their usefulness for studies of the mechanisms of resistance to the type of injuries encountered in stroke and cardiovascular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will examine the self-reported, behavioral, cognitive and neurophysiologic outcomes of emerging over-the-counter (OTC) hearing aid service delivery models by comparing them to gold standard prescription hearing aids fitted by hearing care professionals. Moreover, implementation science elements such as examining the profiles of people who will choose different elements of hearing aid service delivery models, stakeholders' perspectives on barriers and facilitators to implementation as well as cost analysis of the four service delivery models will allow us to fast track the results to practice. Results of this project will provide timely information on emerging OTC hearing aid service delivery models to inform clinical practice and the policy decisions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal will characterize the drug spray to nasal cavity with both particle deposition and mucociliary clearance in consideration. We will develop a novel computational fluid dynamics model for this process validated by in-vivo data for the first time. This project will provide a robust predictive tool to investigate the drug spray to nasal cavity, improve the research capabilities in biomedical at Morgan State University as HBCU, provide high-quality research opportunities to students at HBCU, and contribute significant to PI’s research development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Streptococcus pneumoniae causes over 150,000 hospitalizations annually in the U.S., with a mortality rate of 5-7%, making the disease both a significant health and financial burden. The goal of the proposed research is to elucidate the role of a S. pneumoniae toxin in damaging the lung epithelium, a crucial event that promotes bacterial dissemination from the lungs to the blood and causes more severe disease. Understanding how this toxin contributes to more severe outcomes in patients will help us design novel therapies to combat pneumoniae and other lung infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Reducing adolescent substance use remains a critical public health goal because the majority of adult substance users begin using as adolescents. Substance use is negatively associated with socioeconomic status (SES), but we do not yet know about the associations between SES discrimination and substance use. The proposed research provides new information about the association between SES discrimination and substance use among adolescents.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Genes on chromosome 1p36, including RERE and SPEN, are deleted or altered in some people who are born with heart defects. In these studies, we will use mouse models to learn how altering RERE and SPEN leads to abnormal heart development. These studies will help us provide better medical care to individuals with heart defects and may ultimately lead to the development of new ways of preventing or treating these defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Most biomedical disciplines face a chronic shortage of skilled researchers from diverse backgrounds who are adequately prepared and motivated to pursue doctoral studies. As a minority-serving and a top ranked institution for social mobility with a recently established medical school, Sam Houston State University (SHSU) is ideally suited to address this disparity in biomedical workforce by implementing the proposed Science Trainees Advancing Through Research and Scholarship (STARS) program for the students underrepresented in the biomedical sciences (UBS). The trainees will participate in a cluster of rigorous skill and career development training programs, interdisciplinary research activities in biomedical subfields including molecular and developmental biology, microbiology biochemistry, genetics, neurotoxicology, epidemiology, and nutrition, and dissemination of research outcomes through this robust 3-year intensively-mentored program.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Retinitis Pigmentosa (RP) often results in legal blindness and is caused by more than 100 genetic mutations, making its development challenging to address all causes with gene therapy. We have screened and engineered mechanosensitive channels (EMC) from different microbial species, which upon expression in mammalian cells and retina, allows sonogenetic stimulation by ultrasound with intensity orders of magnitude lower than that required without EMC sensitization. Our sonogenetic stimulation-based approach will provide an alternative therapeutic modality to restore visual function in the degenerated retina.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: CHARLES R. DREW UNIVERSITY OF MED & SCI
PHR: Project Narrative: In recent years, electronic cigarettes (e-cigarettes) use by youth has increased at a disturbing rate. We have shown that e-cigarettes induce cardiac dysfunction associated with DNA damage in a mouse model. In this R16 grant application, we are proposing to determine the effects of e-cigarette induced DNA damage and ultimately aid in developing effective medical therapies to prevent e-cigarette-induced cardiac dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative G protein coupled receptors are therapeutic targets in a wide range of diseases and utilize G protein signaling for most of their effects. This project is aimed at using computational methods to understand the molecular mechanisms underlying G protein signaling. This provides fundamental knowledge about how these proteins work, which can help in the future in targeting their pathways for drug discovery.

IC_NAME: National Center for Emerging and Zoonotic Infectious Diseases
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE International travel may not only increase the risk of infection for an individual traveler, but may also contribute to the global spread of infections. This continuation application focuses on Global TravEpiNet -- a consortium of clinics providing pre-travel health advice, the driving force behind the Heading Home Healthy Program, and a platform for quantitative assessments of travel-related illnesses and interventions. GTEN’s mission is to advance the care of U.S. international travelers, with the goal of preserving and advancing the health of the American public.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: CK21-001 - Global TravEpiNet (GTEN): U.S. Travelers' Health Research, Surveillance, Communication and Outreach Network Supplement

IC_NAME: National Center for Emerging and Zoonotic Infectious Diseases
PHR: Project Narrative Our generation has an opportunity to unite human and animal health services in One Health initiatives to eliminate dog-transmitted rabies; a disease which drives societal inequality in low to middle income countries. Poor quality data in most rabies endemic countries clouds evidence-based policies and hampers successful control measures. This research programme drives a step change in the use of technological innovation to enhance the strategic planning, large-scale implementation and robust evaluation of dog rabies elimination strategies.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: RFA-CK-22-002, Adaptation and assessment of smartphone technology to improve the implementation and evaluation of One Health systems for rabies control and surveillance globally

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: Narrative There is a critical shortage of physicians formally trained in occupational and environmental medicine (OEM) at a time of escalating workplace and environmental hazards and exposures, highlighted by the current COVID-19 pandemic. This NIOSH TPG proposal describes the Yale OEM residency program, a long-standing highly successful and stable ACGME-accredited NIOSH-supported PM / OEM residency training program with the goal of training future OEM physician leaders in a range of OEM academic, public service and practice careers. The training program continues to evolve to train OEM physicians to address the substantial challenges U.S. workers and employers will face in the future.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Yale Occupational and Environmental Medicine Residency Training Program
