IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: The Graduate Training Program in Occupational Health Psychology (OHP) at the University of Connecticut (UConn) recruits qualified doctoral-level graduate students in industrial/organizational psychology, nursing, public health, and occupational and environmental medicine for specialized training in occupational health psychology (OHP). Trainees learn how to contribute to the OHP knowledge base and become highly capable at discovering or implementing new ways of maintaining and promoting worker health and safety. The training program entails a combination of course content and applied research training that is designed not only to equip trainees with the necessary skills to address today's occupational health problems, but also to enable them to introduce new concepts of work organization and workplace design that can enhance worker safety, health and productivity through proactive approaches to workplace interventions.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Occupational Health Psychology Training

ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative NYC CONNECT (New York City Cancer Outreach Network in Neighborhoods for Equity and Community Translation) will build on an existing community-based community-clinical linkage patient navigator program for cancer screening and treatment. We will work together with diverse community and clinical partners to identify and incorporate racial equity strategies to address systemic racism into the program in order to improve cancer prevention and screening outcomes among racial and ethnic minority and immigrant communities.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: DP21-003 NYC Cancer Outreach Network in Neighborhoods for Equity and Community Translation

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER ON BIRTH DEFECTS AND DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study will shed light on a wide variety of genetic, prenatal, early-life and family factors that influence the risk for autism spectrum disorder (ASD) and on differences and similarities in the behaviors, abilities, and health of preschoolers with ASD. It will also provide insights into the experiences of adolescents with ASD as they mature. By helping to explain the causes of ASD and how ASD affects children, youth and young adults, this project will contribute to efforts to reduce the risk of ASD and improve the outcomes of affected children.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Colorado SEED Component A & Component B

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR HIV, VIRAL HEPATITIS, STD AND TB PREVENTION
PHR: Project Narrative CDC PS-21-004 This proposed project develops, implements, and evaluates a collaborative “Data-to- Care Rx” model using pharmaceutical insurance claims data to identify persons with HIV in real-time who fail to pick up prescribed ARV medications by 30 days and 60 days, and to implement targeted evidence-based interventions at each of these benchmarks in an effort to address adherence barriers and re-engage these individuals in HIV medication therapy and primary care. This Data-to-Care collaboration is made up of four partnering organizations that will collaborate with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) – Amida Care (AC), Cicatelli Associates, Inc. (CAI), the Brookdale Center for Healthy Aging at Hunter College of the City University of New York (CUNY), and the New York State Department of Health (NYSDOH) AIDS Institute.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: RFA-PS-21-004: Using Real-time Prescription Data to Support HIV Care and Treatment Adherence in NYC

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: Public Health Relevance Epidemiology and ergonomics are two fundamental disciplines of occupational safety and health. The occupational ergonomist is concerned with identifying potential health hazards affecting the musculoskeletal, cardiovascular, mental/emotional, or other body systems, so an understanding of the epidemiologic evidence is essential. The occupational epidemiologist must appreciate the importance of exposure assessment – whether biomechanical, physical, chemical, or psychosocial - in order to characterize dose-response relationships and assess the effectiveness of interventions; and must have a sophisticated methodologic toolbox in order to unpack questions of public interest such as the health effects of prolonged sitting vs standing, population stress related to the changing nature of work, or the potential impact of occupational injury on opioid use.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Occupational  Health and Safety Training Grant

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHRONIC DISEASE PREVENTION AND HEALTH PROMOTION
PHR: Project Narrative Reducing Cancer Disparities within the Black community in Jackson, MS through Community-Led Tobacco- Related Social Norm Change will evaluate Project BAT (Black people Against Tobacco), an ongoing community-led intervention to empower low-income African American and Black communities to change social norms around tobacco utilization and promote optimal health and cancer prevention throughout the community. There is broad understanding of the function of norms around tobacco use as well as what the threshold for “tipping points” of norms generally are, but the impact of using a community-engaged model to drive social norm change among Black and minority communities remains unexamined. Through our proposed rigorous evaluation of Project BAT, which addresses the myriad environmental factors that contribute to tobacco use, we seek to demonstrate to the research community that social norms change is achievable through community-based action.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: DP21-003 Reducing Cancer Disparities within the Black community in Jackson, MS through Community-Led Tobacco-Related Social Norm Change

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Vascular cognitive impairment and dementia (VCID) is the second most common cause of dementia after Alzheimer’s disease (AD), and development of effective therapies is urgently required. The object of this application is to investigate the key role of a long non-coding RNA, Malat1, in the regulation of long-term cognitive functions, brain white matter integrity, and neuronal loss in experimental VCID. The successful implementation of this proposal will elucidate the molecular mechanism of Malat1-mediated vascular brain injury and may eventually lead us to discover novel long non-coding RNA-based therapies for the treatment of VCID.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative This project aims to understand better the neural mechanisms underlying the critical period changes that occur from adolescence to adulthood that support improvements in working memory using the non-invasive method of EEG on a normative sample and the invasive approach of direct neural measures using sEEG in healthy brain regions of epilepsy resection patients. This information will be integrated into a computational model of neocortical circuitry to elucidate the microlevel changes in brain processing that supports the transition from adolescence to adulthood when trajectories are established. Understanding normative brain changes during this developmental period is a critical first step to assessing impaired development that can lead to psychopathology, which predominantly emerges in adolescence (e.g., psychosis, mood disorders, substance use disorders).

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA SALT LAKE CITY HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: Project Narrative Polycythemia vera (PV) and essential thrombocythemia (ET) are forms of chronic leukemia caused by mutations in bone marrow cells (stem cells) that generate all types of blood cells including red cells, white cells and platelets. Patients with PV have too many red blood cells and patients with ET have too many blood platelets. Unlike the cells of other types of cancer, the blood cells in PV and ET look normal. What makes people with PV and ET sick, causing hospitalization and even premature death, are blood clots (thromboses). In this proposed research, we want to understand why patents with PV and ET have more blood clots. We intend to extend our recently published work and define the molecular mechanism of thromboses in more detail, hoping it will lead to a better understanding of the mechanism of thromboses in PV and ET and to new and better treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Older adults who take medications that cause dry mouth suffer from aggressive caries progression, especially in the roots of teeth. An innovative treatment has been developed to boost the effect of fluoride by the use of fluoride-releasing nanoparticles engineered to penetrate and bind to the cariogenic dental plaque. The high fluoride level induced in dental plaque by this treatment, without increasing the level of exposure to the ion, can reduce root caries progression in individuals with dry mouth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The experiments in this proposal will explore cellular mechanisms involved in the development of pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH), a devastating disease with limited treatment options. In particular, we will explore whether specific protein-protein interactions featuring MK2, caspase-3 and aquaporin 1 mediate changes in endothelial cell phenotype that contribute to vascular remodeling during development of PAH and that can be targeted to reverse remodeling. Such information is crucial to advancing treatment and developing new therapeutic options for this deadly disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: For this application, we have obtained strong preliminary data identifying biomarkers of ovarian cancer that can determine presence of disease 12 months before clinical diagnosis. We propose to construct a biomarker algorithm and validate its performance for identification of ovarian cancer at the early stages using samples collected as a part of the Nurses' Health Study (NHS), and UK Collaborative Trial of Ovarian Cancer Screening (UKCTOCS) cohorts. Biomarkers that pass this and subsequent validation steps could significantly shift the stage of ovarian cancer at diagnosis and reduce ovarian cancer mortality and patient care costs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Twenty to forty percent of cancer patients treated with chemotherapy develop oropharyngeal candidiasis (OPC), also known as thrush. Prevention of OPC during cancer treatment could lead to better compliance and quality of life, reductions in risk of systemic infection and decreased antifungal use. This proposal aims to identify the host and microbiome factors that contribute to OPC susceptibility in chemotherapy recipients and can serve as targets for preventive interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is an incurable disease of nerve cells that control muscles. Some patients with ALS have cognitive and behavioral abnormalities similar to frontotemporal dementia (FTD). Researchers in this program project aim to discover the cellular processes initiated by a mutation in the C9orf72 gene in order to improve the diagnosis of and prognosis for patients suffering from disorders collectively referred to as c9ALS/FTD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Oral squamous cell carcinoma (OSCC) survival has not significantly improved, and remains as low as 60% even amongst early stage OSCC patients. There is currently no reliable clinical, histologic or molecular marker to determine individual risk in patients within the same cancer stage. This study validates a risk score (the REASON score), which is constructed by combining predictive clinicopathologic factors with methylation biomarkers, in two retrospective cohorts and one prospective cohort. We use the REASON score to identify early stage OSCC patients at high risk for mortality, and determine the survival benefit of different adjuvant treatments. Furthermore, we determine the clinical utility of using brush swabs rather than tissues to perform methylation analysis, with the intent of establishing a workflow using noninvasive brush biopsy and the REASON score to predict mortality risk at the time of diagnosis.

PHR: Project Narrative The proposed study is highly significant and relevant to human health: (1) this study would provide better understanding of the biology of NINJ1 and NINJ2 by elucidating how NINJ1 and NINJ2 modulate p53-depedent tumor suppression; (2) The study would reveal a novel role of p53 in pyroptosis through regulating the NLRP3 inflammsome; (3) This study would reveal whether the NINJ1/NINJ2 pathway can be targeted to kill tumor cells carrying wild-type p53.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Jaw movements in speech and mastication rely on stable tendon-bone attachments that are zonally organized into tendon, fibrocartilage, mineralized fibrocartilage, and bone; however, very little is known about how this graded attachment tissue develops. This proposal investigates a developmental mechanism that acts on tendon-bone attachment progenitors to specify tendon over cartilage cell/bone cell fate. Knowledge gained from this study will lend insights into how tendon cell fate is established, which has implications for designing developmentally inspired strategies for tendon attachment repair and understanding jaw tendon pathologies.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because the prevalence of insufficient sleep and obesity in childhood are excessively high. Pediatricians should promote sleep as part of obesity prevention efforts, but primary care providers currently lack the necessary tools to promote sleep. This project aims to engineer a mobile health platform for the pediatric care setting to promote sleep for obesity prevention and is relevant to the NICHD’s mission to enhance the lives of children and adolescents, and is especially relevant to a NICHD’s Child Development and Behavior Branch high-priority research area to support research on behavioral and health promotion interventions within pediatric primary care.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Using the most diverse, prospectively studied, multi-national sample to date, this study will have major public health implications in informing scientific understanding of predictors of adjustment during early adulthood, a developmental period characterized by high morbidity and mortality due to mental health problems, substance use, and other largely preventable causes, as well as opportunities for positive adaptation. The work is especially timely because we will examine the impact of COVID-related disruptions in education, work, and other important domains on young adults’ subsequent adjustment. This work will inform programming and policy to improve population health and well-being by identifying novel targets for prevention and intervention to advance the Sustainable Development Goals adopted by the United Nations to guide the international development agenda through 2030.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neurodevelopmental disorders (NDDs) affect >1% of the population and are comprised of multiple phenotypes including autism, intellectual disability, and other developmental delays. While considerable efforts have been made to understand the role of rare protein-coding variation in NDDs, there is less known about the contribution of rare noncoding variation. In proposed studies, we will further assess the overall enrichment seen for this type of variation and begin to identify specific noncoding regions with enrichment of rare noncoding variants in NDDs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study is relevant to public health because it addresses the implementation of evidence-based programs and policies (EBPPs) to prevent and control cancer within local communities across the US. Developing effective strategies to encourage local health departments’ (LHD) use of EBPPs in an ongoing manner is critical to the potential of these programs and policies to reduce burden, such as by leveraging the expertise of LHDs’ existing, local-level partnerships with academics. A project on the scale proposed has the potential to begin to shift the paradigm on how research can be quickly and effectively translated to those in the best position to use the evidence, such as LHDs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative: The proposed research focuses on the upstream regulation of barrier function mediated by Foxo1, β-catenin and E-cadherin that may be modulated by periodontitis or peri-implantitis. We will examine how they contribute to formation of tight junctions under conditions of interstitial pressure, attachment to titanium and inflammatory cues. In vivo mouse studies will further establish whether periodontal inflammation alters the localization of key molecules that maintain epithelial integrity, which will be further examined in tissue from periodontitis and peri-implantitis patients.

PHR: FIU-RCMI Overall Project Narrative Florida International University (FIU), our emerging preeminent research program in health disparities, our early-stage investigators, and our South Florida minority community partners all have benefitted from the NIMHD-funded Research Center in Minority Institutes at FIU. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE The complex mechanisms that regulate local blood flow supply to active neurons are not completely understood. Dysregulation of these mechanisms is associated with cognitive impairment and dementia, a global public health issue with significant social and economic implications. In this study, we utilize a novel approach of multiscale mathematical modeling together with experimentation to investigate how neurons communicate to the vasculature in health and in disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: AKI accounts for ~$10 billion in US healthcare costs and results in 2 million deaths annually worldwide. There are no effective clinical therapies that reduce the severity of injury or accelerate recovery after AKI. In this proposal, we will confirm HDAC8 as a therapeutic target for promoting productive repair after AKI, and develop novel HDAC8 inhibitors with improved potency, drug-like properties, and efficacy, that have the potential to advance into clinical trails to treat AKI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT(NARRATIVE( Clostridium difficile (CD), recently classified by the CDC as one of the top three “urgent” public-health threat organisms, causes significant morbidity and mortality among cancer patients and contributes to chemotherapy treatment-related adverse events. As current approaches to reducing CD infection (CDI) rates are clearly inadequate, there is a critical need to understand the basic science underlying the development of CDI in cancer chemotherapy patients. The studies proposed will expand our knowledge of Clostridium difficile host-microbe interaction in cytotoxic chemotherapy patients with the goal to identify new strategies for preventing CDI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this project is to change the treatment paradigm for diseases affecting the podocytes, cells that physically filter the blood to form the urine, by combining therapeutics development with cell-specific delivery to enhance the natural ability of the body to repair and regenerate these highly specialized cells. Accomplishing this requires a dual synchronized approach: (i) replacing lost podocytes from neighboring stem cells to increase their number, and (ii) limiting/reversing damage to the remaining podocytes, however, major knowledge gaps to achieve this goal exist, including our limited knowledge on the molecular factors stimulating PEC self-renewal and podocyte regeneration/repair, as well as options to deliver such factors to specific kidney cell types in vivo. By establishing a pipeline through which we couple cutting-edge cell delivery molecules called nanobodies to recently-discovered factors that protect damaged podocytes and promote the replacement of lost ones, we will create a new family of therapeutic entities that prevent disease in both mouse and human kidney tissue, by harnessing the body's natural abilities to regenerate this vulnerable kidney compartment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Description/ Narrative Most cancer patients still fail to respond to current checkpoint blockade immunotherapy, thus understanding the protective immune responses in long-term cancer survivors and studying the cancer immunotherapy resistant mechanisms are urgent. In this proposal, we will further characterize the durable tumor protective immune responses in melanoma survivors with dermal immune-related adverse events (irAE) and expand the study to explore the roles of microbiomes in current immunotherapy resistant cancer types. The findings of this work will reveal the durable, successful anti-tumor immune responses linking the skin irAEs with tumor immunity and provide novel insights into the key immune mechanisms of microbiomes associated long-term tumor elimination.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Just like a population of organisms, genome size and composition can change over time via births, deaths, and migrations of large DNA segments. These mutation events result in genomic structural variations among individuals that underlie many important human adaptations, such as color vision, and diseases, such as cancer. The work proposed here seeks to develop and apply powerful new computational and statistical techniques for investigating the outcomes of structural variations in humans and other species, thereby both enhancing our understanding of past evolutionary history and advancing future biomedical research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Pulmonary vascular disease is common and associated with high mortality in patients with heart failure, but the underlying pathobiology is poorly understood. We propose novel methods to identify proteins that contribute to functional status and prognosis in patients with heart failure and pulmonary vascular disease. We also propose new methods to identify and test, in patient-specific trials, repurposed treatments for this condition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Deregulation of protein phosphatases is a hallmark of many human diseases. This research plan proposes innovative approaches in proteomics, biochemistry, and cell biology to characterize the regulation of the holoenzyme Protein Phosphatase 2A (PP2A) and its regulatory B56 subunit and the role of PP2A-B56 in the regulation of Oxidative Resistance 1 (OXR1) function. The outcomes of this research plan will contribute to our understanding of the regulation of these proteins and expand potential therapeutic targets or points of intervention for B56-related pathologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Project Narrative Periodontal disease, a chronic inflammatory disease, affects about half of the US adult population and is linked to a number of serious systemic diseases. Neutrophils are immune cells that provide defense against pathogens, but they interact differently with some normally commensal (healthy) bacteria during disease, potentially allowing the bacteria to become harmful. This study will lead to a better understanding of pathogen-neutrophil relationships and will improve our ability to control periodontal disease and other chronic inflammatory diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE For over 20 years this T32 training grant has supported pre- and post-doctoral trainees interested in hemostasis and thrombosis, areas with great clinical importance as heart attacks and strokes remain the number one cause of mortality in the western world. We are requesting renewal to maintain our rich history of mentoring in this space which is supported by an extra-ordinarily strong environment with an interactive and dedicated group of innovative and experienced faculty members. The renewed T32 will provide excellent research opportunities, while providing trainees with outstanding scientific development, mentoring, career development, and training in career growth to ensure that there is a next generation of scientists interested in the blood sciences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Latinos have been disproportionally represented among COVID-19 cases and deaths in the United States. Latinos with diabetes are at particularly high risk given that diabetes is associated with poor outcomes including death. In addition, Latinos have been dramatically impacted by sequelae of the pandemic including a steep rise in household food insecurity, which leads to worsening glycemic control for those with diabetes. Effective multilevel interventions that can be remotely delivered are urgently needed for Latinos with diabetes to mitigate disparities due to COVID-19.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Succinyl-CoA Synthetase (SCS) is a component of the Kreb Cycle, which is a central feature of energy metabolism (the metabolic conversion of the building blocks of food into a chemical energy source for the cell). Deficiency of SCS is a form of mitochondrial disease that cause brain and muscle dysfunction that is associated with the reduction of mitochondrial DNA content in the cell. This project establishes a model of SCS deficiency in adult mice that will facilitate the exploration of SCS’s role in brain as well as fundamental pathogenic mechanisms resulting from SCS deficiency.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative A single episode of acute kidney injury (AKI) enhances the risk for chronic disease and long term loss of kidney function. Molecular and cellular studies identified a pro-inflammatory cell type resulting from failed renal tubule repair associated with progressive kidney disease. Blocking this cell's inflammatory properties, and ultimately eliminating the cell entirely, is projected to improve outcomes following AKI.

PHR: Project Narrative Craniofacial dystonia results in substantial disability in affected individuals. Although these disorders show evidence of being inherited, the genetics have been difficult to understand. We propose to use a combination of DNA analysis, fMRI brain imaging and cell biology to help identify the genetic risk to the development of craniofacial dystonia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Pancreatic cancer represents a so-called immunogenically “cold” tumor that is not sensitive to immune checkpoint inhibitors due to an “impaired” tumor microenvironment with multiple “defects”. In prior studies, we found that the immunogenically “cold' tumor of pancreatic cancer was converted to an immunogenically “hot” tumor by immunotherapeutic strategies including vaccine therapy and the combination of vaccine therapy and immune checkpoint inhibitor. This project will study the mechanisms of targeting reprogrammed tumor microenvironment via either T cell agonist or granulocyte antagonist to enhance the effector T cell function directly or through counteracting the immunosuppressive factors in the tumor microenvironment.

PHR: Project Narrative Vascular calcification is common in chronic kidney disease (CKD) and associated with increased morbidity and mortality. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) is a disease that is caused by structural changes in pulmonary arteries (PA) that promote high pulmonary arterial blood pressure and ultimately right heart failure and eventual death. In pulmonary tissue from experimental and human PAH we have discovered the upregulation of a novel gene, PDZ-Binding Kinase (PBK) that promotes smooth muscle cell proliferation. Specific pharmacological inhibitors of PBK reduce PAH in animal models and the goal of our studies is to define a role for PBK in the eitiology of PAH and establish the utility of PBK inhibitors as a therapeutic strategy to improve the morbidity and mortality of a disease for which there are few effective therapeutic options.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This longitudinal study seeks to examine the role of sexual identity-specific individual and interpersonal protective factors as moderators of suicide risk, especially during developmental transition periods (e.g., into high school, college, or the workforce) that may disrupt their existing support networks, among young lesbian, bisexual, and other women who love women (YLBWLW). Participants will include 780 racially and ethnically diverse YLBWLW aged 14 to 30 who complete an online survey every three months over an 18-month period, with a subset of 70 completing an individual interview to explore in-depth the effects of changes in social connections over time, especially during transition periods, on suicide risk. This research will identify modifiable individual identity- and interpersonal social connectedness-level protective factors that will guide suicide prevention efforts across different levels of influence to promote mental health and reduce deaths by suicide among YLBWLW.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: NARRATIVE Diabetes imposes significant health and cost burdens on families, communities, and states in America and vulnerable groups like race/ethnic minorities, predominantly insured by Medicaid, are impacted the worst. We propose to study whether Medicaid managed care organizations (MMCOs) influence the healthcare and outcomes of Americans with diabetes differently in 12 states and the District of Columbia based on their race/ethnicity and sex. To do this, we will develop a dataset of MMCO and state program features over 2016- 2025; use Medicaid encounter data (T-MSIS) over the 10-year period to test whether MMCO and state program features, and the COVID-19 pandemic, affected the care of adults with diabetes; and add context to these empirical findings by interviewing key stakeholders in state Medicaid offices, MMCOs, and clinicians looking after Medicaid patients with diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative Black very low birth weight infants are significantly less likely to receive mother’s own milk. The costs associated with adhering to pumping are borne by mothers and contribute to this disparity. This randomized controlled trial will test an intervention to offset costs associated with pumping and its cost effectiveness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The National Plan to Address Alzheimer's disease has identified education of dementia care providers as a top priority to address the need for quality care for the population of persons with dementia that will triple in the next 30 years. This study will test new online interactive training for nursing home staff that improves staff communication and also reduces behavioral symptoms of persons with dementia that they care for. Innovative approaches to reach care providers are essential to achieve implementation of evidence-based practices to improve care.

PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement  Human African Trypanosomiasis (HAT) is a vector-borne parasitic disease and, currently, drugs for curing the disease are few and often toxic to humans. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Narrative Transgender and gender diverse (TGD) individuals experience significant mental and physical health disparities resulting from minority stressors related to their gender identity. This study will provide a more nuanced and comprehensive understanding of a range of minority stressors that confer alcohol abuse and drug use risk and mental and physical health disparities while also highlighting potential etiologic mechanisms. Results derived will make a major contribution toward the evidence base required to develop effective, culturally informed, and gender-affirming treatment and multi-level prevention efforts specific to TGDAs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Opioid use disorder and obesity are major comorbid public health concerns that are increasing in national prevalence, and that convey increased risk for negative health outcomes in patients. It is not known if dietary intake among individuals with obesity might underlie differential sensitivity to opioid drugs causing differences in therapeutic effectiveness for pain management or leading to the development of opioid use disorder. This proposal will use animal models to evaluate the effects of eating a high fat, low fat or ketogenic diet on sensitivity to the therapeutic, rewarding and adverse effects of morphine, as well as overlapping brain regions implicated in reward, feeding and nociception.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research will explain how Latinx adolescents’ experiences of adversity tied to the U.S. anti-immigrant environment, activity space marginalization, and COVID-19 pandemic influence later health risks and social mobility as Latinx youth transition to adulthood. Building on Caminos, an ongoing study of 547 Latinx youth and, for 50% (n = 271) of them, their mothers, study activities will include collecting five additional annual time points of survey data, hair and salivary cortisol, and waist circumference. Findings will inform policy and practice by identifying (1) family, biological, and behavioral health stress processes that explain links between adolescent adversity and health risks and social mobility and (2) community and interpersonal, family, and youth protective factors that mitigate adversity impacts on later health risks and social mobility.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Helicobacter pylori is a type of bacteria that infects the stomach of half of the world’s population. It causes chronic inflammation, and can lead to peptic ulcer disease as well as progression to precancerous stages and to stomach cancer, the third leading cause of cancer deaths worldwide. Our Servicemen/women are frequently exposed to H. pylori when deployed to areas where this infection is very frequent, and they can acquire pathogenic strains that are harder to treat and associated with carcinogenesis. Antibiotics are not useful once precancerous lesions occur. We will further investigate mechanisms, discovered by our Lab, by which H. pylori causes inflammation that leads to tissue injury, DNA damage, gene mutations, and thus carcinogenesis. Using novel model systems, we will focus on dysfunction of polyamine molecules and their role in aberrant responses in epithelial cells that can undergo neoplastic transformation. Our studies will result in new understanding of H. pylori-induced disease and rational strategies for risk assessment and prevention of disease progression.

PHR: NARRATIVE There is a pressing need for new therapies for obesity and type 2 diabetes, either alone or to complement current treatments. This proposal will establish the molecular mechanisms underlying control of glucose homeostasis by a newly discovered adipokine. Our project is anticipated to lead to a better understanding of how glucose is regulated by insulin-independent pathways, ultimately leading to facilitate the translation to human clinical applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Nurse AMIE Project Narrative Rural patients with metastatic cancer are less likely to have access to high quality supportive care. This may have a negative effect on survival and well-being. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Although most subcutaneous, dermal and marrow adipocytes primarily exist in temperatures well below 37oC, the role of environmental temperature has largely been neglected in our consideration of their molecular and functional characteristics. Our preliminary data indicate that adaptation of cultured adipocytes to cooler temperatures causes profound changes to their molecular and physiological characteristics. Further exploration of these adaptive mechanisms may help uncover novel mechanisms of adaptive thermogenesis and identify targets for pharmacologic interventions to increase energy expenditure and combat incidence of obesity and diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative A majority of patients with Tuberous Sclerosis Complex (TSC) develop kidney angiomyolipomas (AMLs) that can cause renal insufficiency and life-threatening spontaneous hemorrhages, for which the only current therapy is everolimus. Everolimus has limited anti-tumor efficacy, and tumor re-growth frequently occurs after treatment is interrupted due to side effects. In order to investigate the mechanisms of tumor resistance to everolimus therapy, we have generated AML tissues from patient-derived induced pluripotent stem cells, which we will use to test novel therapies with increased efficacy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Proper control of gene expression is critical for organismal development, cellular response to environmental signals or stress, and the prevention of disease states. The proposed work seeks to identify fundamental mechanistic principles that underpin the control of gene expression at the level of RNA synthesis. Thus, these studies will provide key insights into the cellular mechanisms that govern development, enable cells to respond to environmental signals or stress, and that prevent the emergence of disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Base excision repair (BER) is a critical process for preventing the mutagenic and lethal consequences of DNA lesions such as oxidative base damage and abasic sites. BER pathway requires a tight communication between repair proteins. To better understand the mechanism of DNA damage processing that is not always precise, this proposal will elucidate how DNA repair proteins coordinate to execute accurate repair of DNA damage at biochemical level and atomic resolution.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: More than three-quarters of the 30 million Americans with type 2 diabetes (T2D) are unable to meet recommended levels of physical activity, and current intensive programs to improve physical activity have been difficult to integrate into real-world clinics. We propose a randomized controlled trial of a remotely delivered program that uses positive psychology exercises (designed to increase optimism, motivation, gratitude, and confidence) combined with a standard physical activity program. If this new combined positive psychology program is more successful than the standard physical activity program alone in boosting activity, it could eventually be used in routine clinical practice to improve the health of people with T2D.

PHR: There is a critical need to expand the biomedical science workforce in order to solve problems more effectively, drive innovation, and address health disparities. The Ohio State MARC program will train undergraduate students to conduct rigorous research from ‘molecules to society’ and at the same time engage them in community and confidence building activities with other students and biomedical researchers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Our Program will provide M.D., M.D./Ph.D. and Ph.D. post-doctoral fellows with state-of-the-art research training in common and rare lung diseases affecting the pediatric and adult populations. Lung diseases such as lung infections including bacterial and viral pneumonia, acute respiratory distress syndrome, genetic diseases of the airways including cystic fibrosis and primary ciliary dyskinesia, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, asthma, environmental lung diseases, and lung diseases with an environmental component such as allergic lung diseases are common and are associated with devastating morbidity, mortality and use of health care dollars. Our Program offers 48 highly qualified faculty in 7 departments to serve as mentors and co-mentors for our trainees and provides a highly multidisciplinary pulmonary scientific community that creates an outstanding opportunity for trainees to develop their technical and intellectual abilities as scientists and to become independent investigators within the national community, pursuing important questions about the pathogenesis and course of lung diseases in pediatric and adult populations and developing novel therapies.

PROJECT_TITLE: UNC Research Training Program in Respiratory Diseases and Critical Care
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: NHLBI Institutional Training Mechanism Study Section[NITM(JA)]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In our first period of funding, we proposed the use of cardiopulmonary bypass as a cell delivery system in infants with CHD as a new approach for improving neurological impairments in children with CHD. We have generated critical information for bench-to-bedside translation: however, the mechanisms underlying the therapeutic action of bone marrow-derived mesenchymal stromal cells (BM-MSCs) still remain largely unknown. The overarching goal of this renewal proposal is to establish detailed molecular signatures from critical cell populations for tissue repair and regeneration at single cell resolution after BM-MSC delivery; we will then use those molecular signatures as roadmaps to identify novel molecular entities within the exosomes derived from BM-MSCs that account for the disease-modifying bioactivity in tissue injury after pediatric cardiac surgery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PI: Buelow, Hannes E.  Project Relevance  Nerve cells receive their input by way of elaborately branched structures termed dendrites, which are defective in numerous neuropathological conditions such as certain forms of mental retardation or autism spectrum disorders. While significant progress has been made in regard to many aspects of neural development, much remains to be learned about basic aspects of dendrite development. Here we propose to investigate novel mechanisms of dendrite development using a combination of C. elegans molecular, genetic, imaging and biochemical approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Loneliness is associated with a 26% increased risk of mortality and morbidities including heart attack, stroke, depression, anxiety, distress, and pain. The current research proposes to reduce loneliness in care partners of persons with Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) and AD-related dementias through increasing care partners’ sense of meaning and purpose in life with concepts from Meaning-Centered Psychotherapy, delivered via a web-based platform. Through effectively addressing loneliness, and decreasing the likelihood of the negative health outcomes with which loneliness is associated, this work has high potential to reduce the burden of age-related disease, consistent with the National Institute on Aging’s strategic direction over the next 5 years.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative Non-prescribed use, for cognitive enhancement (e.g., while studying) or recreation (e.g., partying), of stimulant medications by young adults is a prevalent problem; this Schedule II controlled medication is usually obtained from peers with prescriptions, yet little data are available to explain this diversion behavior. Efforts to prevent stimulant misuse are therefore missing key information. The proposed research will study diversion behavior among young adults with ADHD and its longitudinal predictors to improve the prevention of stimulant misuse and its associated adverse medical and legal consequences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Recent information indicates that the health of fathers can influence the health of his offspring, via nongenetic (epigenetic) mechanisms. In this proposal, we will use a mouse model to test the hypothesis that paternal obesity and hyperglycemia can modify epigenetic marks in the sperm, and that these changes in sperm affect early life development and ultimately increase disease risk in offspring. Moreover, we will test whether using medications or dietary strategies to lower body weight and glucose in the father can improve health of offspring, and identify the mechanisms responsible for such changes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Alzheimer's disease (AD) is the most common form of dementia and commonly affects older adults. The proposed research focuses on the early prediction of AD and the identification of potentially new AD biomarkers in tear, saliva, and blood by developing a novel multimodal biosensing platform enhanced by artificial intelligence techniques. Thus, this proposal is related to the mission of NIA that is to improve the health and well-being of older adults through scientific and innovative research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative One major hope for diabetes therapy is to generate a large number of functional, transplantable β-cells from patient-derived human pluripotent cells (hPSCs) in vitro, but current protocols still lack consistency between different hPSC lines. Here we propose to use cutting-edge single-cell genomic technologies to characterize the individual variations between many hPSC lines at molecular level. This study will lead to better understanding about the disease causes and novel therapeutic opportunities.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many neurological conditions, including neurodegenerative diseases, and mental illnesses present with prominent alterations of social interactions that reflect malfunctioning of core neural circuits. Our project focuses on characterizing a small set of neurons located in a complex deep brain center that regulates many core functions, including defense from predators, social and emotional behaviors, satiety, and neuroendocrine control. Our research will shed light on how these neurons might regulate social behaviors in health, and it has the potential to provide insights into interventions that aid diagnosis or ameliorate symptoms of altered social behaviors in disease states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Type 2 diabetes is typically managed by steadily escalating pharmacotherapy to keep pace with disease progression. GEM is an alternative intervention that could help some people prevent this cycle by empowering them to significantly improve their overall health, capitalize on GEM’s positive psychological benefits, and manage their diabetes with no or less medication. Because there are more than 1.6 million new cases of Type 2 Diabetes in the U.S. every year that contribute to individual morbidity and mortality and the 327 billion dollar annual cost of the disease, GEM could diminish this burden on the health care system and save millions of dollars annually, while reducing misery among patients and their families.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative This project empirically examines novel predictions about harmful extinction bursts, which are poorly understood and impede treatment success with many behavior disorders. It seeks to fill existing gaps in basic/theoretical knowledge about extinction bursts through a rare and close collaboration between basic and clinical scientists. The project closely aligns basic and clinical research to increase the clinical relevance of basic studies, which in turn should lead to more effective clinical treatment of extinction bursts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Effective messaging to counter misinformation and encourage healthy behaviors, including COVID-19 vaccination, must accommodate differences in preferences, habits, and behaviors across minority populations experiencing health disparities. This proposal aims to build a computational framework to measure heterogeneity in information exposure and engagement during COVID-19; to model the predictors of highly engaging and persuasive messages (including sources, linguistic choices, and content); and investigate the response to social media misinformation through pragmatic qualitative methods to counter misinformation and promote healthy behaviors. While we focus our proposal on COVID-19 vaccination and compare misinformation exposure and attitudes based on race (Black and white) and urban vs. rural populations; the approach is adaptable and will establish a nimble and responsive paradigm for precision public health messaging beyond COVID-19.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: NATHAN S. KLINE INSTITUTE FOR PSYCH RES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This project aims to enhance our understanding of the role of the CA2 region of the hippocampus in different forms of epilepsy, further validating CA2 as a novel target for treating seizure disorders. We previously found that genetic-based manipulations that silence a portion of CA2 (dorsal CA2) reduce the frequency and duration of seizures in a mouse model of temporal lobe epilepsy (TLE). Here we aim to improve on our ability to treat seizures by silencing a different region of CA2 (ventral CA2) strongly implicated in seizure activity in humans, and by examining the role of CA2 in a genetic mouse model of epilepsy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Little is known about the effects of the physical, social and built environments on risks for stillbirth. Minority and low-income populations are differentially exposed to ambient air pollution and other neighborhood-level stressors and suffer what has been termed “double jeopardy.” The overall objective of the proposed study is to evaluate the impact of source-specific exposures to multiple air pollutants using innovative Bayesian spatial multivariate receptor models, neighborhood deprivation and residential greenness on stillbirth, and to evaluate effect modification due to race/ethnicity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The discovery of new and effective treatments for cardiovascular diseases requires the identification of novel disease mechanisms. This proposal aims to enhance our mechanistic insights of vascular calcification by focusing on the activation of autophagy pathway to prevent the development of artery calcification in humans. Success in identifying the specific molecules in this pathway implicated in the development of calcification will provide new targets for treatment of peripheral arterial disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative We seek to establish a new MARC Program at East Carolina University (ECU) to provide an innovative and collaborative training environment that fosters professional development for underrepresented and disadvantaged undergraduates towards biomedical careers that require PhD and MD/PhD degrees. The program combines high-impact educational experiences for undergraduates with a strong interdisciplinary biomedical research program spanning nine departments in the College of Arts and Sciences and the Schools of Medicine and Dental Medicine. The program will broaden career options in biomedical sciences for undergraduates particularly from first-generation and ethnic minority backgrounds, which will increase social mobility and support the rapidly expanding regional biomedical and biopharmaceutical industry in the region.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative  Understanding how complex regulatory processes function in young cells and during aging will ultimately help delay many age-related diseases. Specifically, accumulating evidence suggests that immune cells, such as neutrophils, can be directly regulated by sex-steroid hormones, thus influencing immune responses – yet their impact remains dramatically understudied. This project aims at understanding how sex-hormones modulate neutrophil function throughout life, with the goal to, in turn, take advantage of this knowledge to reverse key aspects of immune dysfunction across biological sex.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Monoubiquitination (Ub) of histones is an important post-translational modification (PTM) that regulates multiple DNA-related processes including DNA replication, transcription, and repair, and aberrant regulation of histone Ub is strongly linked to the pathogenesis of diverse diseases. However, the ability to map the distribution and dynamics of histone Ub signals has been challenged by a lack of high-quality detection reagents. Here, EpiCypher is developing UbSensors as next-generation affinity reagents to enable genomic mapping of monoubiquitinated nucleosomes and advance our understanding of histone Ub signaling.

PHR: The Human Milk Concentration (HMC) device will allow for the exclusive use of mother’s own milk when nourishing vulnerable preterm infants in need of high nutrient intake. The ability to fortify feedings with mother’s own milk, allowing the transfer of vital nutrients found only in mother’s milk to the child, can reduce illness and improve overall long-term health benefits for preterm infants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Depression is prevalent, debilitating, and costly, and maternal depression is one of the most established risk factors of depression in offspring; however, the genetic and environmental risk factors tied to intergenerational risk are complex and largely unspecified. I will conduct a multimodal, dyadic research design to examine a potential neurobehavioral pathway from depression in mothers to the development of increased depression risk in young children. This study has relevance for identifying children at greatest risk for depression development according to neural indicators and proposing a behavioral target for intervention in mother−child processes in order to mitigate risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will uncover mechanisms of epilepsy – a disease that directly affects roughly 1.2 % of the US population. We will gain insight to neural mechanisms of epileptic activity and how such activity impacts impaired memory processing. This work speaks directly to the 2020 NINDS epilepsy benchmark area 1: to understand the cause of epilepsies and related neurological conditions – in this case, impaired memory.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: This study will determine if specific PTSD symptoms have varying associations with adverse T2D and CVD outcomes, including mortality, in patients with comorbid PTSD and T2D/CVD . We will determine if large, clinically meaningful PTSD improvement is associated with a lower risk for adverse T2D and CVD outcomes and test whether measures of T2D/CVD disease management mediate the association between PTSD improvement and adverse outcomes . We expect our results will eventually lead to T2D and CVD treatment guidelines that incorporate treatment of PTSD as a component of T2D/CVD disease management.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Damaging more than just the skin, burn injuries can lead to sepsis and multi-organ failure, often stemming from a breach in the intestinal epithelial barrier allowing translocation of bacteria and bacterial products into systemic circulation, triggering excessive inflammation in critical organs like the lung. Advanced age is an independent risk factor for mortality after burn injury, even in patients with relatively small burns, in part, because elderly burn patients are unable to combat infectious challenges, like pneumonia, a common complication seen after traumatic injury. By identifying mechanisms responsible for early damage to the gut barrier after injury and tracking dysbiosis and eventual restoration of the fecal microbiome in both our murine model of burn injury and in older burn patients, we hope to reduce the impact of this post-burn pathophysiology in patients who are at risk of developing lung infections and respiratory failure

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The goal of this project is to i) test novel myeloid activating therapies (CANDI) which have shown remarkable efficacy in proof-of-principle in glioblastoma studies and ii) improve our understanding of the immune environment by repeat sampling and analysis using recently developed highly multiplexed novel imaging methods. The new methods will allow us to perform in depth studies and will likely lead to new insight and experimental therapies in this devastating disease. Ultimately, we hope to improve our temporal understanding of the glioblastoma microenvironment and apply the gained knowledge to the design of future trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Title: Targeting androgen receptor nuclear localization in prostate cancer Castration-resistant prostate cancer (CRPC) is currently incurable and is the second leading cause of cancer death in American men. Androgen-independent activation of the androgen receptor (AR) remains the major driving force leading to CRPC. Characterization and development of a novel nuclear AR degrader (NARD) may lead to new approaches to prevent and/or treat CRPC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: We propose to study how adhesion receptor integrins, particularly platelet integrin aIIbb3 (also called GPIIb- IIIa) and leukocyte b2 integrins, transmits signals into cells to induce cellular responses, which cause thrombosis and inflammation leading to diseases such as heart attack and sepsis. By exploring integrin signaling mechanisms, we will also investigate the new approaches to develop dual anti-platelet and anti- clotting drugs that do not cause bleeding, and to develop dual anti-thrombotic and anti-inflammatory drugs that do not cause bleeding for treatment of heart attack, stroke as well as sepsis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias continue to be a critical public health issue because they are prevalent and have significant emotional, relational, and financial costs. Purpose in life is a psychological resource that buffers against ADRD at every stage of the disease and may be a powerful target of intervention because it is malleable and its positive correlates wide-reaching. It is now necessary to identify the putative mechanisms of action that explain how purpose leads too healthier cognitive outcomes to develop effective interventions for healthier cognitive outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There are many patients of a-thalassemia, current therapies are insufficient for many of them and there are very few studies on a-thalassemia; in addition, no severe mouse models are available to study this disease and to test new therapies. Our goals are to generate new mouse models to investigate this understudied disease and to test if a newly generated lentiviral vector that expresses the human a-globin gene can correct mice affected by severe forms of a-thalassemia. Our proposed work will address these knowledge gaps by developing, characterizing, and validating mouse models and gene therapy vectors for treating severe a-thalassemia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The emergence of precise physical patterns during embryonic development is critical for the birth of a healthy and fully functional organism. The present application addresses this inherently multidisciplinary problem in the context of looping of the small intestine, a process driven by mechanical buckling of the initially straight tube that allows the lengthy intestine to be packaged within the abdomen. Advancing our understanding of how molecular cues control forces to shape the embryo, and the potential biological importance of the forces themselves, may shed light on the underlying causes of congenital disorders such as midgut volvulus, and provide inroads to the manipulation of forces to engineer tissues and organs in the lab.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Asthma is an important public health problem among Dominican and Puerto Rican adults in the U.S. Altered gene expression in airway epithelium may lead to dysfunction of epithelial integrity and function, abnormal immune responses, and -ultimately- asthma and asthma morbidity. Identifying epigenetic and transcriptomic determinants and/or markers of asthma outcomes in nasal (airway) epithelium from Dominican and Puerto Rican adults should have major implications for disease prevention and management in these underserved ethnic groups. .

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The kidney filters and processes the blood to maintain the proper fluid environment for all body cells. For kidney filtering units, nephrons, to function and convey fluid, they must make new connections to existing tubules and generate functional kidney "plumbing". Making connections will be particularly important to make it possible to engraft new, stem cell derived nephrons to an existing kidney. We aim to show how interconnection happens and how this process can be stimulated to allow new, implanted kidney tissue to replace the function of damaged kidneys, preventing complete kidney loss and averting kidney failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative/Public Health Relevance Based on a longitudinal sample of 200 participants who have been followed for over 40 years beginning before birth, the proposed research will examine prospectively the impact of adversity and social support on adult indicators of aging. We will test the effects of timing and chronicity (i.e., onset and trajectories) of adversity on adult cognitive, neurobiological, and epigenetic markers of aging as well as the moderating influence of relationship support, especially positive early caregiving, on these associations. Understanding the mechanisms by which adverse experiences negatively impact adult functioning and accelerate aging and the role of social relationships in ameliorating these relations will inform policy and contribute to the development of targeted approaches to prevention and intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our overarching scientific premise is that Alzheimer’s disease interventions and pre- symptomatic disease diagnostics remain elusive, in part, because we still do not understand exactly how top genes are driving disease. Our group seeks to help develop a pre-symptomatic disease diagnostic and a meaningful therapy by identifying specific molecular modifications, and therefore specific mechanisms, driving disease using long-range optical DNA mapping and sequencing technologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite increasing prevalence and potency of marijuana use in pregnancy in the US, little is known regarding biological pathways underlying its impact on offspring neurodevelopment in humans. We propose to compre- hensively interrogate the genomic features of the placenta--a key organ which regulates the in utero environ- ment--to elucidate biological pathways underlying the impact of prenatal marijuana on newborn growth and neu- rodevelopment. Results from this study offer potential to (a) identify high-risk groups, (b) identify new biomarkers of exposure and fetal harm, and (c) identify novel molecular targets for intervention efforts to improve pregnancy and long-term offspring health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project seeks to develop new computer algorithms for designing protein structures and predicting protein interactions. The rationally designed proteins that we create will have potential uses as molecular scaffolds in a wide range of biomedical applications including diagnostics and cellular therapies. By predicting the interactions between T cell receptors and antigens, we aim to better understand how the immune system discriminates self from non-self in the context of infectious and autoimmune disease and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This is an Academic-Industrial partnership project between scientists at the University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center and Philips Research Hamburg and Philips North America. The partnership has been formed with the goal of translating a novel molecular Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) method, Chemical Exchange Saturation Transfer (CEST), into a reliable imaging technology for the characterization of Small Renal Masses (SRMs). Achieving this goal will allow improved diagnosis, prognosis and treatment, will cut unnecessary biopsies and complications, thus improving patient outcomes and decreasing treatment financial and psychological burden.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Our proposal utilizes mouse genetic, live-cell imaging, flow cytometry, biochemistry, and molecular biology approach to identify 1) the mechanism that regulates the recruitment and disassociation of PARP2 from the DNA damage sites, 2) the impact of trapped PARP2 on DNA repair and DNA replication, 3) the effects of PARylation/MARylation defective PARP2 on erythropoiesis, hematopoiesis, Trp53/CHK2 mediated clonal expansion. The ultimate goal is to understand the newly identify structural role of PARP2 in hematopoiesis and cancer therapy and to mitigate the on-target bone marrow toxicities of clinical PARP inhibitors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Mutations can be small single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) altering a single DNA base or they can be larger structural variants (SVs) involving the duplication or deletion of large segments of DNA. SV mutations can underlie human diseases and disorders but we know little about the frequency with which SV mutations arise, the evolutionary forces that act on SV mutations, and how they influence evolutionary change. This work will improve the accuracy of model organism-based investigations of human diseases and developmental disorders by discovering the frequency with which SVs are generated in different populations, studying how population genetic forces act on SVs and examining how SVs diverge across the tree of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Vascular disease resulting from hypertension is a leading health problem in the US; yet, it remains unknown how hypertensive changes in the composition of vessel extracellular matrix (ECM) and mechanical properties regulate receptor trafficking and vascular reactivity. There is a critical need to develop an engineering platform capable of patterning ECM structure, composition, and cellular alignment in 3D to build a perfusable vascular network with native biomechanical properties to investigate the interplay between biomechanical forces and biochemical signaling in hypertensive vascular disease. This proposal will use FRESH 3D bioprinting and a newly developed biomechanical strain sensor to 3D bioprint a functional resistance artery and create an ECM- based vascular microfluidic platform to improve our understanding of hypertensive disease progression.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project seeks to develop more accurate models that predict the risk of repeat hospitalizations among patients with diabetes. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: In a collaboration between the University of Cape Town and Columbia University, we will investigate the clinical utility of an automated visual method of assessing the cervix for the purposes of screening for cervical cancer in HIV-positive women in South Africa. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The human gut is home to a diverse microbial community that plays a critical role in maintaining our health and reducing susceptibility to disease. This project aims to quantify the ongoing evolutionary processes that shape the genetic composition of this community within the lifetime of a single host. A quantitative understanding of this process will help us predict how gut microbiota will respond and recover from perturbations such as drugs or diet, and will be crucial for the development of personalized microbiome-based therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative In this proposal, we aim to establish the role of a specific protein called frataxin that we believe promotes the development of a deadly yet mysterious disease of the blood vessels in the lung, pulmonary hypertension (PH). Interestingly, naturally occurring mutations in frataxin cause a syndrome called Friedreich’s ataxia, where associated heart disease is linked with PH; thus, we plan to determine how those mutations directly promote lung blood vessel dysfunction in these patients. If successful, our work could shape genetic and molecular principles of how multiple types of PH develop and drive development of new medications for PH controlling frataxin activity.

ORG_NAME: HUGO W. MOSER RES INST KENNEDY KRIEGER
PHR: We propose to upgrade our 11.7T MRI scanner to state-of-the-art hardware and software that will benefit a large group of researchers at Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine and Kennedy Krieger Institute. The scanner provides a core magnetic resonance facility within an interdisciplinary environment for the investigation of disease models, either their mechanisms, possible treatments, or the development of methods to diagnose them. These include conditions such as cancer, Alzheimer’s Disease, Huntington’s Disease, Parkinson’s Disease, glycogen storage disease, hypoxic ischemic injury, peripheral artery disease, kidney disease, traumatic brain injury, hydrocephalus, and others.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  African American men have an increased risk for both prostate cancer incidence and mortality. Although socio-economic status and other environmental and cultural factors likely contribute to this racial disparity, emerging evidence has shown an important role of genetic and epigenetic factors in the pathogenesis of African American prostate cancer. In this study, we propose a series of experiments to directly test our central hypothesis that aberrant androgen signaling activation in both prostatic epithelia and stroma promotes prostate cancer initiation, progression, and hormone refractoriness in African American patients through dysregulation of insulin-like growth factor-1 and Wnt signaling pathways, which should directly impact the current paradigms and lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies to improve clinical outcomes for African American prostate cancer patients.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will develop a bench-to-industry-to-bedside pipeline for training biomedical engineering students to bridge the gap between biotechnology research and clinical settings. By incorporating team-based learning experiences and addressing workforce skill gaps, this project aims to enhance biotechnology design education and meet the increasing demand for molecular and cellular therapies. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative More than 20,000 people in the United States are diagnosed with myeloproliferative neoplasms every year. Currently, we lack the tools to identify which patients will progress to acute leukemias and the only existing cure is allogeneic bone marrow transplant, a risky procedure that is feasible in only a small subset of the patients. Here, we propose a comprehensive research program to characterize individual cancer cells and reconstruct the history of disease progression in each patient, ultimately, identifying patient-specific targeted therapies that eradicate the cancer cells or hinder their growth.

PHR: The importance of a mechanistic understanding of the underlying complex interactions of microbes, mucins, metabolites, and transport phenomena cannot be overstated; infections of human mucosal layers are a critical global health problem with a greater burden of disease than cancer, heart disease, malaria, and HIV [7]. Our team of experts in computational modeling, microbial physiology, and mucus biology is well poised to tackle this complex problem. We will establish a framework for computational modeling of metabolism and transport in mucosal environments, resulting in the potential for more effective antibiotic targeting and ultimately strategies to treat diseases in which a disrupted mucosal interface is an important factor.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) burdens over 16 million US adults and frequently results in recurrent emergency department visits and hospitalizations due to poor care transition support after initial COPD exacerbations. Our study will use innovative and rigorous implementation science methods to identify real-world solutions to decreasing COPD acute care revisits by concurrently studying care transition program intervention delivery methods (virtual versus in-person) and mentored implementation approaches (virtual or in-person). Lessons learned from this study could transform the way in which care is delivered to millions of COPD patients across the US and could even be applied widely to improve the effectiveness and sustainability of other multi-level, hospital-based programs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: We are investigating how universal regulatory mechanisms control response to environmental chemicals, nutrition and disease. Specifically, we will determine how metabolites of nutritional fatty acids can reduce sensitivity to environmental chemicals and disease. Our work emphasizes controlling chronic toxicities and disease such as pain, fibrosis, and Parkinson’s disease by modulating endoplasmic reticulum stress.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The link between AD and age-related oral health problems is still poorly understood because changes in the cortical and biomechanical control of oromotor behavior in healthy aging and pathological aging have not been investigated. The proposed research is relevant to public health because disambiguating changes in the orofacial sensorimotor-cognitive neuronal network in healthy aging from pathological aging is expected to increase the understanding of potential contributing factors to the onset and progression of AD and the cortical areas that are vulnerable to AD. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to NIH’s mission of earlier identification of individuals who may be at risk for developing late-onset AD/ARD and to find potential avenues for the evaluation of pharmacological or cortical therapies for AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Current HIV prevention strategies that require daily oral dosing are burdensome to the user and, consequently, are often not followed. We will use state-of-the-art chemical synthesis, drug screening, biomedical device engineering, and pharmacology research to build on our previous successes in these areas and develop a long-acting, six-month implant system for sexual HIV prophylaxis. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will lead to a rigorous selection of new, potent anti-HIV compounds that will be formulated for delivery from an implant system and tested in relevant animal models, with the potential to significantly improve clinical practice for HIV prevention and, possibly, treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative There is a dire need in developing new molecular paradigms leading to drugs with increased selectivity, min- imizing undesired adverse effects, drug resistance, and environmental toxicity. Photopharmacology increases drug selectivity by using controlled light-activation of a drug at a given time and location in the body. We will use computational methods to study the membrane disruption mechanism of light-driven molecular nanomotors and optimize their molecular structure, leading to the next generation of nanomotors that can be used in pho- topharmacology for treatment of cancer, antibiotic resistant bacteria, and for controlled drug delivery through nanolipids.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because medications are vital for long term management of human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) and medical and mental health conditions which are common in people with HIV. Prescription cap policies imposed on our most vulnerable populations, such as low income Medicaid beneficiaries, may force them to go without treatments or decide between which treatments to use. Ultimately, these decisions can have adverse effects on their health and the responsible allocation of public funds.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Vision impairment due to progressive loss of retinal ganglion cells and degeneration of optic nerve is among the most prevalent ocular diseases that affect world population. Our study aims at elucidating the DNA “blueprints” that are responsible for the activation of genes involved in retinal ganglion cell formation, which is critical for advancing cell-replacement strategies in affected patients.
