IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE As available genomic data continues to scale exponentially, speed and accuracy are crucial for computational pipelines that process large collections of eukaryotic and microbial genomic sequencing data. This project will develop the improved sequencing sketching algorithms that are necessary to enable the continued ability to gain biological and biomedical insights from this data in a practical and cost-effective way, with a particular focus on large-scale comparison of genomes in both the whole-genome and metagenomic settings. These new computational tools will enable understanding of the differences and evolution between human, model organisms, and other eukaryotes and improved analyses of metagenomic environments such as the human gut, which are necessary steps on the road to precision medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Selecting the most important information in a stimulus-rich world is a fundamental function that the brain must perform, and one that is essential to attention, decision-making, and perception. This proposal investigates the role of an evolutionarily conserved midbrain network in stimulus competition and spatial selection, with a focus on specialized cholinergic and inhibitory neurons within it. Results from this work will inform our understanding of how the brain processes complex sensory scenes and achieves stimulus selection, dysfunctions of which are associated with psychiatric disorders including ADHD, autism and schizophrenia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ROSALIND FRANKLIN UNIV OF MEDICINE & SCI
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal is relevant to public health because there is a significant unmet need for new treatment approaches for anxiety disorders. The bed nucleus of the stria terminalis (BNST) has emerged as a key brain region translating prolonged exposure to uncertain threats into sustained fear; hence the factors that regulate the BNST activity have untapped potential as novel therapeutic targets. This proposal is relevant to NIMH mission because it explores the integrated role of vasopressin and oxytocin receptors in the BNST in fear processing and will contribute to better understanding of the neurobiology of anxiety disorders.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our long-standing predoctoral Developmental Biology Training Program prepares creative and rigorous scientific leaders. Development biology research reveals mechanisms that go awry in congenital defects and adult diseases, including many cancers that arise from uncontrolled developmental programs. A detailed understanding of these diseases, and thus the rationale design of innovative diagnostics and therapeutics, depends on multifaceted training of the next generation of developmental biologists.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE The Environmental Health Bioinformatics (EHB) T32 training program leverages the unique confluence of strengths in Data Science and Environmental Health Science at NC State to train scientists fluent in this critical interdisciplinary space. This data-intensive training program will produce scientists ready to meet the emerging challenges in environmental health research, including the ever-expanding exposome, understanding of variability between individuals, rational integration across massive data sets, and study designs that incorporate diverse community goals and needs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: 220.8 PROJECT NARRATIVE Latino men who have sex with men (MSM) have one of the steepest increases in new HIV diagnoses nationally, likely because intersectional stigma towards their ethnic, sexual, and gender identities (i.e. adherence to masculinity norms) uniquely amplify HIV risk in this population and impede uptake of effective HIV prevention strategies (i.e. routine HIV testing, PrEP use). Social network analysis is a highly innovative method for studying how intersectional stigma is experienced from members of Latino MSM’s social network and will be able to assess from whom and under what social contexts stigma reduction interventions can promote novel opportunities to improve HIV testing and PrEP use among Latino MSM to reduce HIV incidence in this group.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative According to the World Health Organization, there are 1.7 billion cases of diarrheal diseases every year and approximately 1.5 million children’s deaths. The rapid identification of the pathogens that cause infectious diarrheal disease at the point-of-care (POC) may save lives and improve health outcomes by enabling prompt treatment with appropriate drugs. We propose the development of a low-cost, point-of-care stool sample preparation and DNA amplification and detection device to identify which pathogens are causing the infectious diarrhea so that patients can be treated at the clinician's office with the right drugs, right away even in resource-limited settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative EBV-associated cancers represent an important unmet medical need. New therapeutic strategies are required to improve patient outcomes. We have developed small molecules inhibitors to EBNA1 to treat EBV latent infection driving EBV-associated cancers. We now propose to better understand how tumor cells respond to these inhibitors and enhance their efficacy by rational combinatorial therapies and structure-based chemical modifications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Women are at greater risk for developing cognitive impairment compared to men, implicating a role for estradiol. While studies indicate that psychosocial stress exposure, including social adversity, increases risk for deficits in executive function, the mechanisms underlying this risk remain unknown. The current study aims to address this gap in knowledge by characterizing the effects of social status on estradiol’s ability to modulate neuroinflammation and cognitive and memory function in females.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Genetic epilepsy has a strong linkage to loss of function of GABAA receptors, the primary inhibitory ion channels in the central nervous system. Numerous clinical variants cause protein misfolding and reduced functional surface expression of GABAA receptors. Here, we propose to elucidate the molecular mechanism of GABAA receptor biogenesis and use the principles acquired to correct the function of pathogenic variants, representing a novel strategy to treat epilepsy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative:  Neurobrucellosis is the most morbid complication of Brucella infection in humans, but studies on neurobrucellosis are scarce due to the lack of relevant animal models. Here, we present the first murine models of neurobrucellosis in which Brucella is able to colonize the brain, induce inflammation, and impair neurologic function. In this proposal, we will investigate pathways involved in the pathogenesis of neurobrucellosis, and potentially identify targets for complementary therapeutics for neurobrucellosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative Whole genomic sequencing (WGS) surveillance has been shown to detect serious outbreaks that are otherwise unidentified by traditional infection prevention methods. Bacterial plasmids often contain multiple genes that encode for antimicrobial resistance and be readily transferred between bacterial species, which can then be transmitted between patients (transfer to transmission [T2T]), events that are not detected by traditional genomic epidemiologic methods. In this application, we propose to develop the methods for detecting T2T events and determine their utility as part of WGS surveillance in the hospital.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative We will expand a research infrastructure to support the integration of nursing care plan data to large complex datasets with patient and clinical level data. Through this expanded research infrastructure, we will be able to create predictive models with nursing, clinical, and environmental data for unplanned readmissions of older adults with Alzheimer’s Disease and Alzheimer’s Disease-Related Dementias. We are confident that this study will be a model for the development of new research-data infrastructure and will allow us to learn the improvements nurses, physicians, and other providers can make to prevent readmissions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Multiple Sclerosis is the most common form of non-traumatic neurologic disability among young adults with a world-wide prevalence of ~2.5 million and requires an environmental trigger for disease to occur. We have identified a statistical association between epsilon toxin producing strains of Clostridium perfringens and Multiple Sclerosis. In this application we will determine the cellular/tissue targets of epsilon toxin, compare and contrast the clinical phenotype, immunopathology, and neuropathology of experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis induced by epsilon toxin versus pertussis toxin, identify genes induced or suppressed by these toxins, and determine the function of these genes in overcoming CNS immune privilege using endothelial cell specific loss-of-function mutant mice.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: Project Narrative This project aims to investigate the contributions of c-di-GMP and its effector protein PlzA to gene regulation and motility of Borrelia burgdorferi at different moments of its enzootic cycle. Results from these studies will increase our understanding of how B. burgdorferi responds to vector and host signals to regulate expression of virulence genes. Our findings may lead to the development of novel strategies to curtail the spread of Lyme disease, alleviating the impact of this disease in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Individuals living with HIV continue to experience cognitive symptoms that impact daily function despite treatment with antiretroviral therapy and research thus far has heavily focused on cognitive impairment rather than earlier time points prior to the development of impairment. Additionally, our findings show that decreased myelin, a key component of white matter in brain, may be injured in individuals living with HIV at risk for developing cognitive impairment. We will focus on a unique cohort of young adults, ages 18 to 34 years, living with HIV and evaluate the pathology underlying brain injury in this cohort using a new imaging sequence that focuses on myelin content, blood markers of inflammation, and standardized cognitive assessments over time to better understand the cognitive trajectory and risk factors for suboptimal cognitive performance in young adults living with HIV.

PHR: Project Narrative Approximately 6-8 million people are infected with Trypanosoma cruzi, the etiologic agent of Chagas disease. Cardiomyopathy is the most frequent clinical manifestation of Chagas disease and is characterized by the development of scar tissue (fibrosis). We will explore whether polyphosphate released from the infective stages of T. cruzi is involved in the generation of fibrosis impacting the pathogenicity of the parasite.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Despite their prominent roles in the pathophysiology and treatment of pain, addiction and mood disorders, the mechanisms by which opioid receptors (ORs) control neural circuits and behavior remain poorly understood in large part due to limitations of classical pharmacological techniques which lack spatiotemporal control, subtype-specificity, pathway-specificity and targeting to genetically-defined cell types. In this proposal, we will develop a family of photopharmacological strategies for genetically-targeted optical control of native ORs to probe the cellular and circuit mechanisms of mu-OR-mediated anti-depressant treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative (relevance to public health) Myelin oligodendrocyte glycoprotein (MOG) antibody disease (MOGAD) is a newly identified syndrome that is characterized by circulating autoantibodies targeting MOG, yet the role of these autoantibodies in disease pathology is not understood. In order to effectively treat patients with MOGAD, we must understand the disease mechanisms, and importantly how they vary from patient to patient. Our investigation aims to define two major contributors to MOGAD pathology, both of which focus only on the specific cells and antibody molecules that make direct contributions to the disease; to that end, we propose to clone disease-causing autoantibodies and cells from patients and test them with a set of assays to define MOG autoantibody- mediated mechanisms, as means to ultimately predict treatment response, monitor disease progression, and enable personalized therapeutic decisions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This pilot study addresses HIV recombination, a critical problem in HIV epidemics and global disease surveillance. Through the development and validation of two new methods, we aim to address the limitations of the HIV recombination classification system and fulfill the knowledge and technology gaps needed for predicting virus recombination and emerging recombinant clusters to assist public health decision making.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heart failure is the leading cause of death patients with congenital heart disease (CHD), and identification of those CHD survivors who are at-risk of heart failure is critical to improving morbidity and mortality. We will establish a community- based cohort of 600 CHD survivors, NC-DEFINE, to study the social and genetic determinants of heart failure. If successful, this study will aid in the identification of patients with CHD at-risk of HF so that interventions can be made.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The innate immune response is a critical first line of defense in our cells that exploits features unique to foreign molecules to accurately detect pathogens while avoiding unwanted self-activation. We propose studies that will define the molecular features of RNA molecules that drive activation of one important component of this cellular defense system. Fundamental studies like these are a critical platform for development of new and better therapeutic strategies based on a more complete understanding of our cell’s defense pathways, and the mechanisms by which pathogens are able to counteract them.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The studies we propose here should lead to the development of urgently needed vaccines that overcome the barriers for successful mobilization of CD8 T cell responses against clinically important intracellular pathogens such as HIV, Ebola, and Dengue viruses for which no vaccines are currently available. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project proposes to identify in vivo direct targets of androgen and WNT signaling during bladder carcinogenesis. Bladder cancer incidence is three times higher in men than in women but the underlying cause remains largely unknown. Using split DamID, this project will reveal crucial drivers of bladder carcinogenesis in males.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this project is to investigate how non-human primates learn and represent information about serial order using inferential reasoning. We propose that serial order is learned using cognitive maps that support inference and thus allow organisms to adapt to novel circumstances. Health Relatedness: These experiments are relevant to Schizophrenia, Autism, Alzheimer’s disease, and other conditions whose patient populations have cognitive deficits, specifically those related to reasoning.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Changes in Meibomian gland (MG) lipid homeostasis have been linked to a range of ocular diseases, such as MG Dysfunction (MGD), Dry Eye syndrome (DES), chalazia, high triglycerides/low waxes syndrome (HTLW), and other pathologies. In our previous projects we focused our efforts on identification and characterization of genes and enzymes that are involved in the biosynthesis of meibum (which we termed meibogenesis), but we have not attempted to elucidate the mechanisms of its induction, regulation, and decline. In this new project, we will address these questions by conducting comprehensive characterization of meibogenesis in developing and aging MG of mice and humans, to find its triggers and key regulators, which could lead to new therapeutic strategies for curing various ocular pathologies, such as MGD, DES, HTLW, and others.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: Project Narrative: Despite the success of combination antiretroviral therapy (cART), HIV-1-associated neurocognitive disorders (HAND) continue to afflict patients on cART, with a significant proportion exhibiting neurocognitive decline. A history of substance use disorder (SUD) may alter the progression and exacerbate HIV-1 neurocognitive decline. We will critically test how a history of SUD alters the neurocognitive and neuropathological sequelae of HIV-1 infection. The basis of our approach is to identify how infection of microglial cells leads to alterations in the fronto-striatal circuitry following SUD and HIV-1 infection, focusing on mechanisms of dendritic spine loss - a key neuropathology of neuroHIV in the current cART era.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: The research outlined in this proposal will determine how circadian clocks control electrical coupling in the photoreceptor network. We will use several new mouse lines to investigate how electrical coupling in the photoreceptor network changes with the time of day and what effect this has on retinal input to the brain. Electrical coupling mediated by Cx36 gap junctions plays a critical role in many brain circuits and functions, thus we anticipate that the ability to control Cx36-mediated coupling may have useful clinical potential.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: DEEP SOUTH CENTER FOR ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE, INC.
PHR: Project Narrative The HBCU and Communities Consortium Hazardous Waste Worker Training Program is uniquely designed to reach populations for training that, due to poverty and or racism, have been disenfranchised and excluded from opportunities existing within a society that has a unique history especially in the South that is teeming with the vestiges of racial inequality and social injustice in ways that continue to manifest in social and environmental determinants of health and well-being. The training program is informed by research and history on the intersection of race and place and the program also addresses basic inequities in resources for different communities across the country (rural vs urban) as well as differences in priorities for municipalities and city agencies, with training being first to be cut. Additionally, the Consortium is unique in its make-up in that it includes Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) and Community Based Organizations (CBOs), that by design, serve the selected target populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal presents a strategy to elucidate the inhibition mechanisms of first-in-class therapeutics that target intrinsically disordered proteins, which represent an enormous pool of potential drug-targets largely considered “undruggable” by conventional structure-based drug design approaches. This work will increase our understanding of how to rationally design small molecule drugs to inhibit intrinsically disordered proteins and will provide new avenues to therapeutic interventions for currently untreatable diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Primary open angle glaucoma (POAG) is one of the most common causes of blindness in the United States. Elevated intraocular pressure (IOP) is a leading risk factor for POAG and lowering pressure is the only effective treatment for this devastating disease. This proposal will investigate a gene variant in a protein called thrombospondin-1 to gain a better understanding of its role in IOP regulation in normal and glaucomatous eyes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Large-scale variant-level functional data can substantially reduce the clinical burden of variants of uncertain significance, but no infrastructure exists to capture and present this data to clinicians in a manner that can be incorporated into standard clinical variant interpretation workflows. We propose to leverage our leadership in both large-scale functional assay technology development and clinical genetics to address this critical challenge by building and testing the infrastructure and knowledgebase that will empower clinicians to integrate variant-level functional data into clinical practice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (APOE U19: OVERALL) The overarching theme of this U19 project is to understand the biology and pathobiology of apolipoprotein E whose gene represents the strongest genetic risk factor for Alzheimer’s disease and several other aging- related conditions. The U19 will take advantage of the strengths and existing synergy among its multi- disciplinary and multi-institutional investigators to elucidate how apolipoprotein E isoforms have profound effects on functional outcomes at the molecular, cellular, and systems levels, and how these pathways can be targeted for therapy. This U19 project will also engage the broader scientific community by sharing knowledge, resources, and data through a web portal and by promoting collaboration through an annual ApoE Symposium.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Immunotherapy is an exciting new approach to solid tumors and active investigations are underway for glioblastoma (GBM). The role of immunotherapy in the context of the current standard of care is unknown and our project will study the effects of local and systemic chemotherapy on the immune system and the antitumor immune response. We will perform our study in the preclinical and clinical setting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The cells and tissues of the human body age at different rates depending on their precise anatomical location and environment. We currently do not have a full understanding of this “heterogeneity” and how it contributes to overall human aging or the enhanced risk of diseases with age. The proposed San Diego Nathan Shock Center will provide a robust infrastructure to facilitate and promote the systematic study of cell and tissue heterogeneity in human aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immune responses protect us from infections but on the other hand can be destructive, leading to autoimmune diseases such as type I diabetes or rheumatoid arthritis or allergic responses such as asthma. Although, during the last 50 years, a tremendous amount has been learned about the immune response still much remains to be discovered. Thus, the goal of this Grant is to train predoctoral and postdoctoral fellows in further research on the basic mechanisms of the immune response, and application of such training to translational research.

PROJECT_TITLE: Training Program in Immunology

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: Project Narrative Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) may be an effective treatment modality for severe neuropsychiatric symptoms (NPS) of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD). Using a nationwide, longitudinal cohort design, this study aims to examine associations of ECT with NPS and other key clinical outcomes among adults with ADRD in nursing homes. Findings will inform more effective clinical guidance on ECT use in nursing homes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: In our original project, we established that portal vein pressures can be quantified noninvasively in humans using an innovative ultrasound based technology (i.e., SHAPE) and that this method can be successfully implemented using modified hardware across multiple sites. Hence, this renewal study bring together scientists and clinicians from Thomas Jefferson University, University of Pennsylvania and University of Bern with a premier manufacturer of ultrasound scanners (GE) in order to further develop SHAPE for the noninvasive evaluation of portal hypertension and to establish the clinical utility of SHAPE for the management of portal hypertension.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: New tools in Genomic Medicine – polygenic risk scores, platforms to capture family history, and advanced electronic phenotyping – offer the prospect of early identification of people at especially high risk of common diseases. The eMERGEgram network is being formed to address this opportunity and in our application to join this initiative, we outline methods to allow the network to develop genomic risk assessments using these new tools; a plan to engage, recruit, and retain 2,500 subjects to receive these assessments; and methods to study outcomes in those designated high risk and those designated average risk. By enhancing our understanding of new methods to create and deliver genomic risk assessment, this project will enable prevention and early treatment of people at high risk for common diseases.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: NARRATIVE While anti-SSA/Ro-associated fetal complete (i.e., 3°) atrioventricular block (AVB), identified in the 2nd trimester in an otherwise normally developing heart, is fatal in a fifth of cases and for those who survive requires lifelong pacing, reversal of incomplete block is possible but challenging to identify given only once weekly echocardiographic surveillance. This study comprises three steps: 1) screening anti-Ro positive mothers for high-titer antibodies which are thought to confer greater risk of fetal AVB; 2) teaching mothers with high titer anti- Ro to monitor the fetal heart rate and rhythm at home and arrange immediate feedback on perceived abnormalities; 3) treating fetuses whose mothers detect abnormal monitoring confirmed to be incomplete AVB by echocardiogram. The purpose of our study is to find out whether the level of anti-Ro/SSA can predict fetuses at greatest risk, if mothers can themselves identify reversible fetal cardiac injury by home monitoring, whether expeditious treatment of fetal incomplete AVB can restore normal rhythm, and finally if weekly echocardiographic testing is necessary to surveil for AVB.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Resilience is a key predictor of successful aging and also acts as a buffer to disaster exposure; however, successfully aging in areas that are prone to disasters is an emerging public health challenge, especially for community-dwelling older adults who lack the resilience needed to bounce back from these disruptive events. The goal of this project is to test a conceptual model that estimates how individual disaster resilience mediates the relationship between disaster exposure and successful aging, and use qualitative data to inform the design and piloting of a tablet-based intergenerational intervention to increase the disaster resilience of older adults. With a growing number of older adults aging in areas prone to hurricanes, floods, wildfires and heatwaves, increasing disaster resilience will provide community-dwelling older adults with the resources they need to successfully age-in-place, despite mounting environmental risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Cancer is a leading cause of death worldwide, and lymphoma is one of the most common form of blood cancers in the world. An understanding of HDAC11's role in regulating anti-cancer immunity will pave the way for developing potential new strategies to treat lymphoma patients. The proposed research is relevant to the NCI's mission to develop fundamental strategies and acquire knowledge that will improve healthcare and alleviate human suffering from cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: The International Association of Fire Fighters (IAFF) has been a partner with the National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences (NIEHS) Worker Training Program (WTP) since 1992, delivering over 1,630 classes and training more than 33,542 workers likely to respond to hazardous materials incidents, in an effort to prevent work related harm and improve worker health and safety. In addition to delivering highly technical training for HazMat incident response (e.g., Confined Space Rescue and Operations, HazMat Technician), the IAFF remains committed to delivering holistic training to address all aspects of worker safety including emerging topics such as occupational cancer risks, opiate and substance abuse disorders, behavioral health awareness, suicide prevention, and improving individual/community resiliency. The IAFF is committed to addressing these issues, by: continuing and improving the training and education of all potential responders (public, private, volunteer, community partners) who may be impacted by HazMat emergencies; utilizing innovative technologies for class delivery; and conducting ongoing quality control and program evaluation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal will develop powerful and interpretable statistical methods for elucidating regulatory mechanisms and functional impacts of transcriptome variation at population and single-cell scales. Our unified framework for associating genetic variants with transcript variants (reflected by changes in a gene’s isoform abundances) will lead to a more powerful and accurate elucidation of the molecular mechanisms of disease/trait-associated genetic variants found by the genome-wide association studies. Our novel methods for studying temporal gene expression dynamics at the single-cell level will allow the interrogation of cellular heterogeneity in biological processes such as immune responses and carcinogenesis, and our simulator will support the systematic evaluation of computational tools for single-cell research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project narrative Delay to hospital presentation after stroke symptom onset prevents African American patients from being eligible for stroke treatments that reduce disability. Previous educational interventions designed to educate African American patients about stroke and the importance of calling 911 have mostly been delivered community-wide or in a group format, settings that do not adequately address individual reasons for hospital delay. This project will determine whether delivering stroke education individually to African Americans at high risk for stroke improves recognition of stroke symptoms and intent to call 911 if stroke symptoms should occur.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Brain image data collected by the neuroscience community will continue to grow dramatically over the next 5-10 years. Increases in data volume will come from a push to image physically larger volumes such as whole brains from humans (and other primates) and from higher speed for smaller specimens. The Brain Image Library (BIL) is an important public resource for sharing this data by providing a persistent and scalable repository for microscopy data generated by brain researchers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Despite strong consensus that early, specialized intervention for children with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) can have a dramatic impact on outcomes, the public health system’s capacity to provide such services is severely challenged by the rapid rise in ASD prevalence. The goal of this research is to increase timely and equitable access to ASD-specialized early intervention during the critical first three years of life by capitalizing on the existing infrastructure of the Part C Early Intervention (EI) system, which is publicly funded and available in all U.S. States. This project will train EI providers to use an evidence-based, inexpensive, parent-mediated intervention that can improve child and family outcomes as well as mitigate the substantial economic costs associated with ASD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A subset of Asthma patients with specific inflammatory profile (neutrophils) in their sputum, with scarring of the airways, develop resistance to therapies and are at higher risk of death. This project addresses the exact contribution of the inflammatory mediator named “LIGHT” in lethal asthma. It aims to identify the mechanistic underpinnings of severe asthma, explain why patients become resistant to standardized therapies, and test a novel therapy neutralizing LIGHT to treat this severe refractory disease.

PHR: The goal of the Community College Consortium for Health and Safety Training (CCCHST) is to help the nation be better prepared to prevent and to respond to hazardous materials incidents through the training of instructors serving workers from business and industry; students from community and tribal colleges and technical schools, including first responders; transitioning military; and members of community-based and faith-based organizations in targeted communities. CCCHST will make NIEHS-approved training nationally available through over 100 CCCHST organizational members, prepared through a Train-the-Trainer model program, to offer hazardous materials and disaster preparedness instruction in nearly all states of the nation. Over 250,000 workers, students, and citizens, prepared by CCCHST instructors over a five-year period, will understand how to protect themselves and their communities when working with hazardous chemicals and hazardous situations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although small-molecule antiretroviral therapy (ART) drugs effectively control an HIV infection, there are drawbacks to their use, including their inability to prevent HIV-associated neurological disease in many patients. We have previously shown that expression of the exceptionally broad and potent antibody-like inhibitor eCD4, expressed from a gene-therapy vector, can protect from challenge with and often control infection of HIV model viruses. Here, we will determine if we can apply this approach to effectively treat the neurological consequences of HIV infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: At birth, the infant intestines (gut) are exposed to and colonized by thousands of different types of bacteria. Recent studies have hinted at the potential for these early colonizers to influence brain development and behavior. It is not known what chemical messages are sent by the gut bacteria to cause such changes in the developing brain. It is also unknown when during rapid changes in infant brain development these messages have their greatest impact. Our study is designed to identify factors during pregnancy that influence the earliest gut colonization in infants, what chemical messages are created by the bacteria, and how the presence and timing of such signals impacts brain development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative There has been little innovation in the development of the new analgesic drugs that target novel mechanisms of action. We will focus on the structure-activity relationship studies, biological evaluation, behavioral testing, and optimization of the new dual inhibitors of soluble epoxide hydrolase and fatty acid amide hydrolase enzymes, to increase the levels of anti-inflammatory and analgesic metabolites in the body. Through in vitro and in vivo studies, we aim to demonstrate that the designed dual inhibitors are effectively inhibiting both aforementioned enzymes simultaneously, are metabolically stable, and can produce pain relief in a rat model of chronic inflammatory pain with the potential to become novel, safe, and effective non-opioid treatments for patients suffering from chronic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE An understanding of the fundamental mechanisms that control animal development and behavior is key to an understanding of many aspects of human health and disease. This project aims to reveal molecular mechanisms that mediate behavioral responses by the experimentally tractable roundworm Caenorhabditis elegans to the environmental stress of oxygen deprivation (hypoxia) and the environmental cue of multichromatic light (color). C. elegans shares many genetic, molecular and cellular features with more complicated animals, including humans, and these studies should provide insights concerning both fundamental aspects of human biology and disease processes as diverse as blindness, heart disease and cancer.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There are high rates of both HIV infection and obesity in pregnant women in South Africa. Dolutegravir, an integrase inhibitor antiretroviral drug, has been associated with excess weight gain and metabolic derangements. We will study the impact of dolutegravir taken during pregnancy, a critical time during which exposures may influence long term health, on the metabolic health of women living with HIV and their young children in South Africa

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative There is a public health need to develop novel, culturally adapted interventions to reduce alcohol consumption among Latinx hazardous drinkers with comorbid clinical anxiety. The proposed R01 study will draw upon National Institutes of Health (NIH) treatment development guidelines (Stage 1) to translate and innovate past work to address a major public health priority. Specifically, we propose to develop (Phase IA) and test (Phase IB) the effectiveness of a brief, integrated, single-session, computer-based, culturally adapted personalized feedback intervention (PFI) designed to enhance knowledge regarding adverse anxiety-alcohol interrelations, increase motivation and intention to reduce hazardous drinking, and reduce positive attitudes and intention regarding anxiety-related alcohol use among Latinx hazardous drinkers with anxiety within community-based health clinics.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There continues to be a severe shortage of physician scientists who hail from the field of Obstetrics and Gynecology, yet there is a growing number of pressing women’s reproductive health issues that would greatly benefit from targeted investigation. Since 2005, in our first 3 funding periods of the Northwestern University WRHR Program, we have successfully developed and fostered the growth of an outstanding mentored career development program highly conducive to transitioning Obstetricians and Gynecologists to become independent investigators. Here, we continue to build on our successes and strive to continue and improve this Program, thus generating the highest quality of successful OBGYN trained physician scientists.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Given the limited success of our current lifestyle approaches to treat overweight and obesity, it is important to rigorously evaluate novel and practicable strategies to increase weight loss in adults. The optimal time of day to exercise is a question that is receiving increasing attention in the media and lay press, with articles touting the weight loss benefits of morning exercise without supporting scientific evidence. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will provide a robust dataset regarding the impact of morning versus evening exercise on weight loss and compensatory behaviors, and will allow clinicians and public health experts to advise patients on the optimal time of day to exercise to promote weight loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Eye movements play a central role in how we interact with the world; looking, inspecting, navigating, and reaching all rely on integrating how our eyes are moved with what the brain does with the images formed on the back of the eye. This project will enable a new line of research to uncover the brain mechanisms that allow large and small eye movements to support visual processing of spatial information. Disruption of these eye movements by disease or brain injury may be a sensitive indicator of cognitive dysfunction and an unrecognized component of sensory, developmental, and learning disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: This application proposes to study how early life variations in quality of maternal care and social environment contribute individually and interact to influence adult cognitive and behavioral outcomes from developmental exposure to lead. Proposed studies will also examine alterations in brain epigenetic profiles and gene expression patterns in different brain regions, and how these biological effects relate to the expression of cognitive and behavioral deficits following exposures to lead and different early life experiences. A goal of this work is to provide information on the extent to which social and environmental interventions might mitigate the cognitive and behavioral damage produced by developmental lead exposure and to establish a biological framework that support these interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE HEALTH SCI CTR
PHR: Public exposure to radiation due to large-scale radiation incidents is a rising global concern, but there are no FDA-approved therapeutics for radiation injury. Therefore, we propose to conduct studies to uncover the cellular and molecular mechanisms involved in radiation-induced innate immunity dysfunction. The outcome of these studies will identify a new medical countermeasure to treat radiation injury by targeting innate immune dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: OVERALL: PROJECT NARRATIVE The mission of the University of Florida Health Cancer Center (UFHCC) is to prevent, detect, and ultimately cure cancer and address the unique challenges of the cancer burden faced by the population we serve by facilitating innovative, collaborative, transdisciplinary cancer research. UFHCC will achieve these goals through discovery and research innovations in cancer mechanisms, prevention, screening, and treatment, while training the next generation of cancer scientists and leaders and engaging the communities and populations we serve.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: The Sustainable Workplace Alliance and its alliance partners will provide model training to better protect workers, first responders and citizens in underserved communities that have been negatively impacted by pollution, blight and emergency events. These vulnerable populations are unlikely to know their rights to a safe workplace, the inherent risks of the work they do, the dangers of misuse of opioids, the hazards created by pollution or hazardous materials, and the most effective ways to protect themselves from these harms. This model training and outreach program is designed to reduce injuries and death and to place disadvantaged citizens in viable jobs in the environmental and construction industries.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to develop technical advances necessary for increasing the field of view of adaptive optics ophthalmoscopes, in order to overcome a barrier for detecting the earliest signs of eye disease. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Diabetes and its renal complications are becoming epidemic in the U.S. population. The central hypothesis of this proposal is that the cGAS–STING pathway contributes to the progression of diabetic kidney disease (DKD) and sexual dimorphism observed in type 2 diabetic nephropathy (T2DN) rats. This proposal will explore sex differences in T2DN rats and the role of the cGAS-STING pathway in kidney injury, potentially uncovering a new therapeutic target for DKD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The vision of the CardioPulmonary Vascular Biology (CPVB) COBRE program is to develop effective approaches to prevent and treat vascular diseases affecting the pulmonary and cardiovascular systems through better understanding of disease mechanisms. This will be accomplished by serving as an interdisciplinary center which promotes collaborative research and provides excellent technical support and resources to investigators. The overall mission of the CPVB COBRE program has been to build the human and technical infrastructure and services that serve as catalysts to increase research in cardiopulmonary vascular biology in the state.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose an innovative training program in basic and translational Women's Reproductive Health Research for Obstetrics and Gynecology-trained MD and MD/PhD-physician scientists in an exceptional research environment. The program's mission is to offer rigorous basic and translational laboratory research training coupled to structured career mentoring to junior faculty members of the Baylor College of Medicine Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology. The ultimate goal is to prepare the future academic research leaders in Obstetrics and Gynecology who are prepared to ask and comprehensively address the most important research questions that when answered can ultimately improve women's health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Borderline Personality Disorder (BPD) is a common psychiatric condition that increases risk for poor social and work functioning and for suicide. The core problems underlying BPD are not known; understanding the mechanism of this illness is critical to improving outcomes. The proposed studies will use neuroimaging methods and novel computational modelling approaches to define the brain basis of BPD pathophysiology and to lay groundwork for developing new therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Age-related macular degeneration (AMD), the most common cause of blindness among the elderly, is initiated by retinal pigmented epithelial (RPE) degeneration due to lysosomal dysfunction. Dysfunction of lysosomes can affect the normal functioning of the cellular clearance process to cause disease. This proposal will determine the extent that transcription factor EB (TFEB) activation by gene therapy can restore lysosomal function, RPE degeneration, and an AMD-like phenotype using an AMD-like mouse model and in human-iPSC derived RPE cells from AMD donors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Dysregulation of blood stem cells leads to failure of blood cell production. We identified a new pathway, endoplasmic reticulum associated degradation (ERAD), as a critical regulator to maintain blood stem cell functions. The proposed studies will identify the mechanism by which ERAD promotes blood stem cell functions, and provide new insights into how blood stem cell functions are maintained, which potentially can inform novel approach for blood cell regeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: OVERALL: PROJECT NARRATIVE The mission of the Massey Cancer Center (MCC) is to reduce the state cancer burden for all Virginians by addressing the confluence between biological, social, and policy drivers through high-impact, cutting-edge research; person-centered care across the continuum, from prevention through survivorship; community integration; and training the next generation of community-centric researchers and healthcare professionals. The core of this mission has been supported by the National Cancer Institute’s Cancer Center Support Grant (CCSG) since 1975, and the MCC is seeking renewal of this award for another five years. The CCSG supports efforts across the MCC senior and programmatic leadership; administration; community outreach and engagement; cancer research training and education coordination; promotion of center-wide diversity, equity, and inclusion; shared resource support and management; clinical research infrastructure; and developmental funding to supporting team-based, transdisciplinary research strategies focused on well-defined, catchment area priorities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative This Renewal proposal will use intersectionality and life-course frameworks to assess how risks and disparities in maternal morbidity 1) accrue across multiple forms of marginalization and 2) accrue across multiple pregnancies over time. We will use causal inference and community engagement approaches to 3) translate our results to potential actionable next steps to improve maternal health and eliminate disparities. We will examine severe maternal morbidity, its precursors (hypertensive disorders of pregnancy, anemia, cesarean birth), and its subtypes (hemorrhage-, infection- and hypertension-related severe maternal morbidity).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  While in utero ethanol exposure causes a well-described complex of conditions, there is also mounting evidence and concerns that some outcomes, including reproductive outcomes, are also detectable in the third generation following initial exposure. However, how a memory of ethanol exposure is initiated and then transmitted to future generations is currently not well understood. Our work will identify the epigenetic and metabolic underpinnings of ethanol’s transgenerational reproductive effects which will lay out a strong foundation for the implication of these pathways in a human context.

PHR: Relevance Previous interventions have not focused on social network overdose prevention approaches for people who use opioids (PWUO). PHR: NARRATIVE Systemic fungal infections represent a significant and growing public health problem. In the United States, invasive fungal infections are now one of the 10 leading causes of death (7th) even ahead of mortality due to tuberculosis. Our proposal addresses the significant gap in knowledge in understanding the genetic basis of variation in human immune response and susceptibility to inhaled fungal infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative: Young people living with HIV in adolescence through emerging adulthood (ages 16-28 years) have the lowest rates of regular engagement in HIV care and adherence to HIV medications of any age group, with Black and Latinx individuals experiencing the greatest barriers to favorable HIV health outcomes. To provide a detailed understanding of the factors that promote or impede HIV management in this group, we will follow Black and Latinx youth/emerging adults living with HIV, half with optimal HIV health outcomes at enrollment (undetectable HIV viral load) and half without, for 18 months. Participants will engage in structured assessments, in-depth qualitative interviews, real-time ecological momentary assessments in two-week bursts, and biological tests (HIV viral load tests, drug tests), and a Youth Advisory Board comprised of youth living with HIV will help interpret findings in order to inform new policies, health care service practices, and interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed study will contribute to developing useful methods to identify people at high long-term risk of ADRD early in their midlife and to understanding the shared etiologies of sensory and cognitive changes. This project’s results will inform about potential pathways for prevention of ADRD to promote healthy brain aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Diabetic retinopathy blinds approximately 12% of diabetic patients each year and its incidence is expected to increase. While there are currently no therapeutic strategies directed at its early stages, there is accumulating evidence that retinal photoreceptors are involved in the pathogenesis of diabetic retinopathy and are major contributors to diabetes-induced local inflammation in the retina. This project aims to study the responses of photoreceptors to hyperglycemia and interventions that address this pathway with the potential to be effective in the early stages of diabetic retinopathy to prevent the development of vision-threatening pathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcoholism remains a leading cause of death and disability, in need of new therapeutic interventions. The proposed research will focus on innovative approaches to inhibiting the enzyme catechol O-methyltransferase (COMT), which has been linked to alcohol use disorder (AUD), and could provide a new pathway for addressing this devastating disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: 8. Project Narrative The use of antipsychotic drugs in pediatric populations has increased dramatically over the past 30 years despite a lack of basic research documenting the effects of these drugs on brain and behavioral development. This research will use laboratory rats to ascertain whether early-life antipsychotic drug administration leads to greater behavioral and neural sensitivity to opioid drugs in adulthood. This research will provide scientists, policy-makers, and practitioners with critical information regarding the impact of prolonged antipsychotic drug treatment during development on the risk of substance abuse in later life, as well as offer transformative research experiences in neuroscience to college undergraduates in Kentucky hailing from groups underrepresented in biomedical science.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Incidence and prevalence of Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) in the United States is increasing steadily and has recently become a third leading cause of death in the U.S. Quercetin a dietary chemical found in foods such as apples and onions is a natural product with potential anti-COPD properties, but its therapeutic effects in COPD are not studied. This research will help us determine whether quercetin reduces inflammation without having side effects in COPD. This study will also provide necessary information for future treatment studies with quercetin for COPD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: CENTRE HOSPITALIER DE L'UNIVERSITE DE MONTREAL (UNIVERSITY OF MONTREAL HOSPITAL)
PHR: Loss of vision in glaucoma results from the death of retinal ganglion cells (RGCs), the neurons that convey visual information from the retina to the brain. RGC dendrites, the fine processes that connect neurons within the retina, retract soon after glaucomatous injury. Here, we propose to investigate underlying mechanisms and strategies that promote RGC dendrite regeneration leading to cell-cell communication and restoration of neuronal function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Narrative  The cornea of the eye has a curved surface that allows it to focus light on the retina, and abnormal corneal curvature causes visual problems such as myopia, hyperopia, astigmatism or keratoconus. We plan to use a simple model system, the fruit fly Drosophila, to investigate how the cells that produce the cornea generate its normal curvature. We will then test whether the same mechanisms are involved in the development of the mouse and human cornea, which would enable us to use this system to gain insights into human visual disorders.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: The primary goals of the proposed Harvard K12 Women’s Reproductive Health Research Career Development Program are to: 1) recruit a diverse group of obstetrician- gynecologist physicians of high motivation and talent for academic medicine, 2) provide them with the best resources, scientific environment, intensive training and mentoring in all aspects of high-impact and socially responsible research conduct; and 3) advise them on grantsmanship and career development and see them through a successful transition to an independent research position. The public health importance is related to meeting the Nation’s biomedical, behavioral and clinical research needs and enhanced by the special attention to biological factors associated with disparities in reproductive health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Narrative Unlike mammals, zebrafish exhibit a remarkable ability to regenerate retinal neurons that were lost to injury or disease and therefore, can recover vision when blinded. Key to this regenerative response are Müller glial cells that produce multipotent progenitors for retinal repair. Our research aims to identify the mechanisms distinguishing pro-regenerative Müller glial cells in zebrafish from non-regenerative Müller glia in mammals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The Western Region Universities Consortium (WRUC) provides training to protect workers and communities from exposure to hazardous materials/waste, including chemical, biological and radiological materials; and to prevent, prepare for and respond to emergencies. Programs are implemented through a cooperative agreement with the National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences and support the goals of U.S. government agencies such as the EPA, OSHA, DOT, NIOSH, DHS, and FEMA. WRUC partners with state and local agencies, tribal entities, and communities in West Coast states, Alaska, the Southwest and along the U.S.-Mexico border to promote public health and environmental sustainability in the region.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Exposure to a new type of flame retardant chemicals is increasing in the United States despite concerns that these chemicals may change hormone levels and brain function in humans. We will observe how children exposed to various levels of flame retardant chemicals may have different thyroid hormone levels, intelligence, and ADHD behaviors. We will also investigate how being exposed to mixtures of chemicals like old flame retardants, new flame retardants, and lead may have different effects on human health outcomes than exposure to single chemicals alone.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Program Director/Principal Investigator (Last, First, Middle): Strakowski, Stephen M. NARRATIVE Bipolar I disorder typically emerges during adolescence or young adulthood. Using longitudinal study of ventral brain network in youth with or without a familial risk for bipolar I disorder, and with or without childhood maltreatment, we propose to define how brain developmental abnormalities evolve to produce bipolar I disorder. IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Retinal images captured with adaptive optics scanning ophthalmoscopes are severely distorted due to constant involuntary eye movement. In this project, we propose to develop low-cost high-speed instrumentation and software to compensate for this movement to improve the understanding, diagnosing, and management of eye diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative A vaccine to prevent HIV-1 infection is only likely to be effective if it includes components that are able to stimulate the human immune system into producing antibodies (designated bNAbs) that can neutralize the infectivity of multiple strains of the HIV-1 virus. To stimulate the production of bNAbs, we make proteins known as SOSIP trimers that are based on the only part of the virus that is targeted by bNAbs, the envelope glycoprotein (Env) on the viral surface. In this project, we propose to continue to make and study new and better versions of the SOSIP trimer, for our own research, to provide to collaborators and to donate to other scientists who now use SOSIP trimer designs for their own vaccine-development or related research programs.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Proper endometrial repair after menstruation is necessary to allow for subsequent menstrual cycles and pregnancy. The uterus is prone to diseases including endometrial cancer and endometriosis that may result from improper regulation of endometrial repair. This work will provide important information about normal endometrial repair mechanisms so as to better understand how mis-regulation may contribute to uterine diseases and infertility in women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiac fibrosis, or the accumulation collagen, occurs almost universally in all cardiac diseases and can contribute to the worsening of heart failure. There are no therapies for cardiac fibrosis. In this proposal, we will determine the role of SLIT3-ROBO1 signaling in cardiac collagen regulation as well as in the pathogenesis of cardiac fibrosis. Results of this study will increase our understanding of how cardiac fibrosis occurs and may identify novel targets for antifibrotic therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Affective symptoms are at the core of numerous neuropsychiatric disorders, but their neurobiological basis is not well understood. Aberrant functioning in a dynamic brain network that supports emotions may underlie affective symptoms. A more fine-grained understanding of this network will be critical for advancing neuroanatomical models of emotions and for guiding the development of novel treatments for affective symptoms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: OVERALL – Project Narrative The proposed OAI Consortium: Hazardous Waste Worker Training Program (HWWTP) and Environmental Careers Worker Training Program (ECWTP) aim to promote public health and prevent work-related harm through safety and health training to underserved populations and communities. The training advances the NIEHS mission to address hazardous waste site safety under the authority of the Superfund Amendments and Reauthorization Act (SARA). Both components work towards achieving the broad goals of Healthy People 2020 to “create social and physical environments that promote good health for all” and to support community health by “minimizing the risks to human health and the environment posed by hazardous sites.”

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will determine how ethanol drinking is differentially affected by the dynorphin/kappa opioid receptor system in the nucleus accumbens shell across its rostro-caudal axis. Using a multidisciplinary approach, we will investigate the hypothesis that activation of kappa opioid receptors in the rostral shell elicits a hedonic state and inhibits ethanol drinking, by preferentially modulating serotonin, while activation in the caudal shell instead drives a dysphoric state and increases ethanol drinking, by preferentially modulating dopamine. The results of these studies could ultimately have transformative implications for public health, by facilitating the design of pathway- specific therapeutics to revolutionize treatment for alcohol use disorder.

PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE The proposed software will help developers overcome the limitations of current computing hardware to design more accurate deep learning models for use in clinical diagnostics. The ability to analyze these images in their entirety will accelerate the development of accurate AI based diagnostics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative  Upper-limb paresis is the most common impairment following a stroke affecting 75% of stroke survivors, which can be more prominent in one of the two limbs. It is clinically important that stroke survivors continue to practice the use of the stroke-affected limb in their home and community settings to maintain the functional level learned in the clinic, but currently, there exists no effective, practical clinical tool. In this project, we propose to develop and validate an mHealth technology that will monitor real-world upper limb activity by leveraging our novel finger-worn accelerometer sensors and provide individually-tailored feedback to encourage affected limb use.

PHR: NARRATIVE Heart failure (HF) is a chronic condition leading to >1 million hospitalizations in the U.S. per year due to fluid build-up in the body’s tissues including the lungs. Approximately half of patients with HF have a preserved pump function (HFpEF) and this group of patients is especially difficult to diagnose and treat. Our research is aimed at understanding how lung ultrasound examinations can improve the early identification of lung fluid in HFpEF in order to better guide therapy, improve quality of life, and reduce hospitalizations for fluid overload.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The ε4 allele of the apolipoprotein E (APOE) gene is the strongest genetic risk factor for Alzheimer disease. ApoE4 exacerbates not only amyloid pathology but also tau-mediated neurodegeneration. Our proposal seeks to identify small molecule apoE4 inhibitors, thereby reducing apoE4-related pathogenic effects for AD therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE High levels of interparental conflict account for much of the increased risk for mental health disorders and problems in children who experience parental separation/divorce, which has significant individual and societal costs. This project combines prior research and new input from family court judges, administrators, and service providers, and high-conflict parents to design and pilot test a contextually appropriate, scalable intervention to reduce post-separation/divorce interparental conflict. Results of this research will provide the foundation for an R01 that will support a large-scale trial of this intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal investigates the mechanisms by which visual information is selectively filtered in a arousal state- dependent at the first synapse between eye and brain. We will test the hypothesis that serotonin plays an important role in modulating the strength of different channels of retinal information. A detailed understanding of this process will be important for understanding how attention to visual stimuli can be restored in neurological disorders such as stroke and optic nerve injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Multiple sclerosis, a neurological disease affecting the brain and spinal cord, also impacts the eyes, causing visual impairment and decreasing quality of life. Through study of newly discovered changes in the eyes of people with and without multiple sclerosis this work will establish how this, and other neurodegenerative diseases cause visual impairment. We will also develop objective and non-invasive measures of eye structure that will help treating physicians predict clinical progression and treat visual symptoms in affected people. Furthermore, this work will develop retinal imaging techniques that simplify detection of structural and functional changes that will be applicable to the study of more patients with more diseases, and by more physicians and researchers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Protecting macular retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) and photoreceptors could preserve central vision in patients with the dry form of Age-related Macular Degeneration (dry-AMD). We will investigate the role of the modified form of erythropoietin, EPO-R76E, in suppressing dry-AMD phenotypes. Understanding the molecular impact of EPO-R76E in the RPE will open new therapeutic avenues for preventing or perhaps reversing vision-loss in dry- AMD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: The Training Program in Environmental Health Biostatistics at the Harvard T. H. Chan School of Public Health prepares pre-doctoral and postdoctoral fellows for research in the application of biostatistics, statistical genetics and genomics, and data science to the environmental health sciences. The Program combines first class training in biostatistical theory and methods, formal training in computer science and environmental health, practical experience in environmental health collaborations in interdisciplinary team science settings, and rigorous training in reproducible science. The Program provides trainees with skills necessary for scientific leadership in interdisciplinary settings, focusing on skills for project management, grant writing, and other skills needed for scientific leadership.
PROJECT_TERMS: Biometry;Training
PROJECT_TITLE: Graduate Training in Biostatistics

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Targeting the molecular interactions of structural exopolysaccharides in bacterial biofilms is a promising new approach to treat persistent and hospital acquired infections resulting from biofilm infections. This proposed research will develop new tools to identify critical protein- exopolysaccharide binding interactions that occur in live bacterial biofilms and will also identify novel biocatalyst capable of breaking down biofilm exopolysaccharides through functional metagenomic screening and through protein engineering to improve the catalytic activity of existing biofilm dispersal agents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Hirschsprung disease is a life-threatening birth defect where the enteric nervous system is missing from distal bowel. Symptoms and outcomes vary quite dramatically among affected children, but the reason for varied Hirschsprung disease symptoms and outcomes is not known. We discovered serendipitously that an inbred Hirschsprung disease mouse model lives 5-fold longer in Philadelphia than in Montreal and now test the hypothesis that diet, gut microbes and metabolites influence fundamental Hirschsprung disease mechanisms to impact bowel barrier function and survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative  Minimally invasive liver surgery (MILS) has many potential advantages but liver deformation leads to significant difficulties in localizing tumors and avoiding main vessels accurately. This project aims to develop a novel surgical navigation approach as a tool to guide MILS intraoperatively. Novel computer vision and machine learning algorithms, including GPU-based non-rigid simultaneously localization and mapping (SLAM), learning- based landmarks recognition and non-rigid registration will be developed to compensate for live deformation and map preoperative data to the patient’s anatomy in real-time during MILS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Program Director/Principal Investigator (Last, First, Middle): Liu, Yiming  Over the past years numerous microRNAs have been reported as biomarkers associated with various medical conditions. The current golden standard for microRNA assay, i.e., quantitative reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-qPCR), has disadvantages such as inadequate assay accuracy and high-assay costs. We propose herein to develop a novel analytical strategy based on the reliable UPLC- MS/MS technique to achieve highly sensitive absolute quantification of targeted microRNAs in biological samples, thus fostering the biomedical research and full validation of these emerging disease biomarkers. IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Atopic disease is a major public health problem affecting up to 20% of the world’s population, with a substantial psychosocial and economic burden for children and families and rising prevalence in recent decades; child atopic risk has been associated with maternal antenatal anxiety, yet we know little about the biological mechanisms that may underlie this association. This study will examine both maternal and child immune activity from pregnancy through the first year (through stimulated immune cells, the cytokines they produce, and gene expression in cord blood), and will determine dyadic immune activity and associations with the child’s atopic risk, accounting for elements of anxious parenting in the postnatal environment. These findings will shed light on the biological pathways contributing to risk for atopyin children, and may lead to novel interventions to ameliorate both maternal symptomatology and child risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Narrative This project develops and tests a novel platform strategy that has been designed to reduce the undesired toxicity of antibody-drug conjugates (ADCs). Nine ADCs are currently approved for use in treating cancer in the United States, and more than 100 ADC agents are in current clinical testing. The strategy introduced in this proposal is expected to increase the tolerability of ADC therapy, allowing increased safety and efficacy in the treatment of cancer; if successful, the approach may be applied broadly, potentially providing benefit to large populations of cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Suicidal behavior is a major public health problem in the United States with rates deaths by suicide and suicide attempts increasing over the past 10 years. While there have been multiple calls for increased research into the causes and interventions to reduce suicidal behavior, effective research has been limited by the small number of researchers trained to conduct high quality suicide research. This application proposes a post-doctoral training program that will train young investigators to conduct cutting edge research regarding suicidal behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The overall objective of this proposal is to test, using a cluster-randomized RCT, the impact and sustainability of a health system leadership alignment strategy to achieve successful integration of an evidence-based, task-shared mental health treatment model into general medical care in Malawi. Leadership alignment is an essential ingredient for successful mental health integration but has received extremely limited attention in low and middle income countries. This project will make a major contribution to our understanding of the role of leadership alignment in advancing evidence-based mental health integration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: We will examine if DHA/AA controls neurovascular development in phase 1 ROP by improving mitochondrial and peroxisomal fatty acid oxidation; little work has been done in this area. We have preliminarily found a large beneficial effect of DHA/AA vs. AA only and DHA only on promoting normal retinal vascular formation which is suppressed during hyperglycemia- induced early changes in phase I ROP, leading to later proliferative disease. DHA/AA supplements may prevent ROP.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: N. gonorrhoeae, the infectious pathogen that causes gonorrhea, is the second most common reportable disease in the US, and its incidence and resistance to antibiotics are rising at an alarming rate. These clinical outcomes are determined by multi-protein assemblies that mediate neisserial growth, human cell adhesion, host invasion and clinical persistence. Using innovative functional proteomics, computational, and biological methods, our project aims to generate a systems-wide understanding of key protein macromolecules involved in gonococcal pathobiology, revealing new targets to combat gonorrheal infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The purpose of this proposal is to test a new cellular therapy for chronic norovirus infection in patients undergoing hematopoietic stem cell transplant and in patients with primary immunodeficiency. By using banked T cells targeting norovirus, we hope to resolve norovirus infections, and also better understand how T cells confer protection to norovirus, which may help future cellular therapy and vaccine studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE It has become increasingly clear that there is a need to improve the current version of oncolytic virotherapy for a better clinical benefit. We plan to develop a strategic three-pronged immune-virotherapy to overcome the two major hurdles hindering cancer virotherapy - the relatively weak therapeutic activity and lack of means for effective systemic delivery, and the developed strategy can be translated into the clinic in the near future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Parkinson’s disease (PD) affects more than one million Americans, and there is no therapy that slows the progression of any feature of this age-related, relentlessly progressive neurodegenerative disease. There is now class II evidence that deep brain stimulation (DBS) slows the progression of rest tremor when applied in early-stage Parkinson’s disease. Before proceeding to a multicenter, randomized clinical trial, this study will quickly fill gaps in knowledge needed incorporate neuroimaging and wearable biosensors into an outpatient therapeutic washout in order to objectively evaluate the underlying progression of Parkinson’s disease.
