IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative Developmental biology is the study of how organisms self organize to produce mature life forms. It has always been an important discipline within Biology, and with the growing interest in understanding pediatric disorders and the introduction of stem cells for medical therapies, it is now more timely than ever. This broad based training program is designed to train the next generation of developmental biologists who will advance our understanding of normal developmental processes and thereby make it possible to harness the promise of stem cell therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Precisely controlled migration of lateral plate mesoderm cells after gastrulation contributes to proper hematopoietic cell fate specification and lineage survival. The ultimate goal of this project is to understand how syndromic blood anomalies arise from defective LPM patterning. As proxy, we seek to understand the mechanisms causing Thrombocytopenia with absent radius (TAR) syndrome, a rare, complex congenital blood anomaly, that manifests with defects in blood (thrombocytes), forelimb, and heart, kidney lineages, which are all seemingly unrelated phenotypes, but are specified cell lineages of the LPM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the significant public health burden associated with out-of-hospital cardiac arrest (OHCA), our understanding of the trajectory of long-term recovery and key contributors to survivorship and reaching a `new normal' after OHCA is limited. POST- ICECAP, an ancillary study to an ongoing NIH funded trial, will be the first, and certainly the largest study to describe the recovery in the most diverse group of OHCA survivors. It will comprehensively assess the relationship between the initial severity of the OHCA, critical care interventions, inpatient rehabilitation, and social determinants of health with improvement or deterioration in dependence on others for everyday activities, cognition, and quality of life in the first 12 months after survival from OHCA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The prime objective of our National K12 “Diabetes-Docs: Physician-Scientist Career Development Program” (DiabDocs) is to train and foster the development of diverse physician-scientists for productive and impactful diabetes research careers with a specific focus on type 1 diabetes (T1D). Our K12 program is designed to provide: 1) a mentored research experience, 2) research project support, and 3) career development training, including directed attention to diversity, equity and inclusion. We are confident that we will attract the highest caliber of applicants and mentor them toward impactful careers in academic medicine as skilled physician-scientist leaders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: In the aging US population, there is an increasing incidence of bone marrow disorders such as Myelodysplastic Syndromes (MDS). Since these diseases often progress to more aggressive therapy-resistant leukemias, they place a significant burden on the healthcare system. Our work aimed at defining the functional role of bone marrow endothelial cell signals in supporting MDS growth and progression may open up new therapeutic avenues to halt the progression of these bone marrow failure disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE With cancer as the second leading cause of death in the US, there remains a pressing unmet need for new, more effective cancer therapeutics. Trethera has developed a small molecule drug, TRE-515, that inhibits deoxycytidine kinase (dCK), a rate limiting enzyme in the salvage pathway of nucleotide biosynthesis. Cancer cells utilize the salvage pathway to support rapid proliferation. TRE-515 holds an open IND and has been piloted in a dose escalation trial to establish preliminary dose, safety, and tolerability. The proposed Phase 1 dose expansion clinical trial will deploy a plasma deoxycytidine (dC) assay and a novel PET probe dCK imaging approach as complementary biomarkers to monitor drug activity and assess preliminary antitumor activity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: During the development and aging of the blood forming system, blood stem cells change, and this is reflected in differences in the types of blood diseases that affect infants, children, and adults. Many blood diseases are characterized by inappropriate activation of infant/juvenile programs of blood formation in the young or mature adult. This proposal is focused on understanding the molecular control of how blood stem cells normally change during development and aging and how this process is disrupted in blood disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: A multiphase optimization strategy (MOST) will be used to conduct an optimization trial among people who inject drugs (PWID) and are newly enrolled on medication for opioid use disorder (MOUD). We will assess the impact and cost of four promising intervention components (Attention, Executive Functioning, Memory, and Information Processing). The components are designed to accommodate cognitive dysfunction such that participants can better process and utilize intervention content, thus leading to enhanced PrEP adherence and HIV risk reduction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: Project narrative. RNA is an intermediary molecule that transmits genetic information encoded in DNA and the precise regulation of its decay is critical for normal cellular homeostasis and RNA therapeutics. Our identification of novel elements and factors that control RNA decay will be instrumental in understanding the molecular underpinnings of gene expression. This work will provide insight into a fundamentally new mode of controlling RNA metabolism and provide a framework for previously unknown approaches of modulating gene expression in normal and disease states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreatic cancer is the third leading cause of cancer deaths in the U.S. with 57,600 new pancreatic cancer cases anticipated in 2020 resulting in a projected >$3 billion burden to the healthcare system. The dismal five year survival rate of just 10% for pancreatic cancer patients is due in large part to ineffective drug targets for highly complex and desmoplastic tumors of pancreatic cancer. This project has high translational value as it seeks to develop more effective anti-cancer agents targeting the cancer even within the protective stroma using sophisticated in vitro and in vivo model systems that will contribute to the goal of increasing pancreatic cancer patient survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Peptide receptor radionuclide therapy (PRRT) with [177Lu]DOTATATE improves quality of life and survival in patients with advanced neuroendocrine tumors; however objective tumor regression is infrequent and complete responses are exceedingly rare. On the other hand, exciting-emerging evidence suggests that PRRT with alpha-emitters has the potential to extend PRRT to tumor regression and even complete response. In this study we propose to develop a new theranostic pair using [203Pb]PSC-TOC (imaging) / [212Pb]PSC-TOC (alpha emitter) for image-guided dosimetry based personalized therapy for neuroendocrine tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Hydrocephalus is a disorder causing excess accumulation of cerebrospinal fluid in the brain, treated by using shunts to divert cerebrospinal fluid out of the cranial cavity. Our team of bioengineers, neurosurgeons, and experts in neurophysiology and biostatistics will identify patient subpopulations which correlate with a high degree of contact between the shunt catheter and tissue; then, we identify the conditions in which cause obstruction by this tissue being mechanically pulled in or biochemically grown in. By studying correlations in the patient population and causations using a benchtop model, we embrace a multi-disciplinary approach that will provide a better understanding of the mechanisms leading to shunt failure so that we can inhibit that response from occuring.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: OVERALL – NARRATIVE This Project Program Grant proposal aims to advance our knowledge of “sex as a biological variable” in bladder cancer—globally one of the top cancers that disproportionately affects males more than females. Our proposal is the only nationwide coordinated multi-investigator effort focused on uncovering the biological mechanisms that drive sex-related biology in bladder cancer. Successful completion of the proposal will offer novel biological insights that lay the foundation for therapeutic strategies that account for a patient’s sex while improving efficacy of existing treatments such as immune checkpoint blockade therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT 1 – NARRATIVE It is unclear why men develop many cancers (such as bladder cancer) more often than women, even after adjusting for known risk factors such as smoking. We discovered that dysfunction within the adaptive T cell immune response strongly contributes to male-biased tumor aggressiveness; this dysfunction is modulated by male hormones that reduce the anti-tumor response in T cells. The goal of this project is to characterize the sex- specific differences in T cell response to tumors and use this knowledge to improve cancer immunotherapy in both men and women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: AFC Project Narrative The Workplace Safety Training Program of the Alabama Fire College proposes to provide training to Native American and public sector emergency response personnel that will prepare them to safely respond to hazardous materials releases resulting from transportation and industrial incidents, natural and manmade disasters, and illicit drug use and manufacture. Both target populations are charged with responding to such emergencies by Environmental Protection Agency, Occupational Safety and Health Administration, Department of Transportation, and Department of Homeland Security regulations, but do not have sufficient budgets and resources to provide such training. The proposed project will bring critical training to over 6,400 responders in both populations that will help them to better protect themselves and the communities they serve.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Self-disturbances and social impairment are two core features of schizophrenia that contribute to the heavy personal and societal burden of long-term disability, but there are currently no effective interventions to ameliorate social deficits or self-disturbances of schizophrenia despite their detrimental impact on functional outcome.  We will examine a quantifiable component of self-disturbances (self-other boundary) in relation to interpersonal distance regulation by implementing multisensory integration tasks in an immersive virtual reality environment and by utilizing functional neuroimaging to characterize underlying mechanisms that may lead to anomalous self-other processing and social disconnection.  Elucidating how maladaptive social interactions may arise from basic problems of multisensory integration (i.e. disrupted self-other boundary) could lead to a more precise treatment targets, and therefore, contribute towards reducing social disability of individuals with conditions that disrupt self-other processing such as schizophrenia.

PROJECT_TITLE: Spatial Self Boundary, Interpersonal Distance and Social Impairments in Schizophrenia

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT 2 – NARRATIVE While the incidence of bladder cancer (BC) in men is nearly 4 times greater than in women men, women present with more advanced BC at diagnosis and have worse outcomes after treatment. Interestingly, in other cancer types, loss of the Y chromosome (LOY) is associated with increased risk of death in men, suggesting that the Y chromosome suppresses tumor aggressiveness yet the roles of Y in development, growth, progression, and therapy response remains to be determined, in any cancer type. Here we build upon our discovery that BC with LOY is more aggressive in animal models and is associated with worse prognosis in BC patients, to test the hypothesis that this is because LOY allows tumors to evade the immune system, which will provide the knowledge to develop novel and more effective precision therapies against this aggressive form of the disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Despite strong consensus that early, specialized intervention for children with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) can have a dramatic impact on outcomes, the public health system’s capacity to provide such services is severely challenged by the rapid rise in ASD prevalence. The goal of this research is to increase timely and equitable access to ASD-specialized early intervention during the critical first three years of life by capitalizing on the existing infrastructure of the Part C Early Intervention (EI) system, which is publicly funded and available in all U.S. States. This project will train EI providers to use an evidence-based, inexpensive, parent-mediated intervention that can improve child and family outcomes as well as mitigate the substantial economic costs associated with ASD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Geographic atrophy (GA) is an advanced form of nonexudative or dry AMD that is characterized by loss of retinal pigment epithelial cells (RPE) and attenuation of choriocapillaris (CC); there is currently no therapy for GA. Our studies in the past grant period document the proinflammatory nature of the GA choroid with activation of macrophages and mast cells and that the mast cell activation alone is sufficient to create a GA-like phenotype in rat. The proposed studies focus on C-reactive protein (CRP), one of the proinflammatory molecules in GA choroid, and how CRP affects mast cells, choroidal macrophages, and retinal pigment epithelial (RPE) cells and CC endothelial cells, two cells that die GA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: DNA methylation plays a critical role in hematopoiesis, the process leading to the production of functionally specialized blood cells and is frequently deregulated in blood cancers such as myelodysplastic syndromes; however, treatments currently available to correct abnormal DNA methylation are highly toxic and non-specific, because the molecular players controlling DNA methylation establishment during hematopoiesis are largely unknown. This proposal is relevant to Public Health because it will identify key molecular switches of DNA methylation involved in normal hematopoiesis to develop in the future a targeted and non-toxic strategy to correct abnormal DNA methylation in disease states. This highly innovative approach will be instrumental in providing the long-awaited targeted therapeutic agents for the treatment of myelodysplastic syndromes, or other disease triggered by aberrant DNA methylation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT 3 – PROJECT NARRATIVE Bladder cancer is a highly sex-biased disease that disproportionately affects males, but the underlying mechanism remains largely undefined. In this Project, we aim to uncover the overlooked epigenetic basis of observed sex differences. We expect to identify sex-biased epigenetic pathways that can be used to develop future sex-specific bladder cancer screening and treatment to ultimately mitigate existing sex disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Harnessing a patient’s immune system to attack melanoma is remarkably successful. In one promising approach T cells are harvested directly from the patient’s tumor, expanded to very high numbers in the laboratory where they can be rejuvenated, and returned to the patient to fight their cancer. As this is only effective in approximately half of patients with advanced disease, here we develop a novel, safe and efficient method to further boost these tumor-reactive T cells by mRNA reprogramming.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE BRAIN pioneers are people who take on significant risk as participants in first-in-human or early neurotechnology studies for the sake of helping to further science. Their willingness to try invasive and non- medically necessary devices, their investments of significant time and energy, and their close relationships with study teams, typically built over 3-5 years of intensive experiments, make them relatively unique as research participants, yet relatively little neuroethical attention has been focused on the structures of support, from researchers and family members, that enable BRAIN pioneers to successfully participate in neural device trials. This study will identify forms of family and researcher support that are integral to the well-being of BRAIN pioneers, and produce recommendations for best practices that will help shape future trials and contribute to a smooth translation into the clinical sphere.

PHR: ADMINISTRATIVE CORE – NARRATIVE The Administrative Core (Admin Core) will provide critical services to support the overall integration and management of this P01 Program Project Grant that is distributed among two academic research institutions. The Admin Core will oversee and manage the progression of research milestones across the three Projects and two shared resource Cores. IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The comprehensive Women’s Reproductive Health Research at Stanford offers OB/GYN junior clinician- investigators an individually tailored program of didactic research methods and mentored career development to bridge the transition to academic independence. The primary goal is to develop diverse, highly trained, creative and productive independent investigators in reproductive science to address the increasing opportunities in this field. Having this program embedded in Stanford’s rich culture of innovation and collaboration provides an exceptional environment to empower the next generation of independent investigators who will advance reproductive health for all.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: CORE 1, SYSTEMS PATHOLOGY – NARRATIVE The overarching goal of the Systems Pathology Core is to process and analyze high quality biospecimens, including murine and human clinical specimens, to address Program aims. The core will act as a high-quality biorepository and provide (1) multiparameter histology and pathology services and (2) provide flow cytometry and single cell analysis services. The Systems Pathology Core will work closely with the Administrative Core and the Data Science Core, which will provide robust data management and analysis of the data acquired.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Environmental cues associated with alcohol can promote problematic drinking and relapse even after treatment. We recently used a novel behavioral paradigm to successfully prevent relapse in rats with moderate-level exposure to alcohol. In the current proposal, we will test the generalizability of our procedure using rats with a history of alcohol dependence and probe the neural substrates for successful prevention of relapse.

PHR: Mitral regurgitation (MR), the most frequent form of valvular heart diseases, results in depressed left ventricular (LV) systolic function, which is not responsive to medical management. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Abdominal pain is a common symptom of gastrointestinal disorders and there are few effective treatments. This proposal will test how specific hormones generated by bacteria that normally live in the bowel signal to gut nerves to influence pain sensation, and whether altering this signaling could be a new strategy for treating abdominal pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this proposal, we aim to develop a new class of therapeutic candidates for AD based on soluble amyloid precursor alpha (sAPPα)-enhancing analogs of tropisetron (F03) that we have in-hand, as well as new optimized analogs for their ability to decrease the phospho-tau/total-tau (p-tau/t-tau) ratio in human SH-SY5Y neuroblastoma cells, primary neurons from 3xTg Alzheimer's disease (AD) model mice, and human iPSC- derived neurons; prioritized compounds would undergo ADME and oral brain permeability analyses to select lead candidates for acute and chronic efficacy studies in 3xTg-AD and ApoE4-5XFAD mice. The multifunctional properties of 5-HT3 serotonin receptors antagonism, α7 nicotinic acetylcholine receptor agonism, and binding to the extracellular domain of APP along with kinase inactivation would be evaluated. The key goal is to identify advanced lead candidates with oral brain bioavailability, sAPPα enhancement and p-tau/t-tau lowering that affect both amyloid and tau pathology and improve cognition for treatment of AD and tauopathies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative. The proposed research will advance our understanding of how effective immune responses enable macrophages to kill M. tuberculosis. This work is relevant to public health because understanding how macrophages contribute to control M. tuberculosis infection will have significant implications for the development of novel immune based therapeutics and vaccines. Thus the proposed research will help contribute fundamental knowledge that will reduce the enormous burden that tuberculosis imposes on public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Perturbations within the dopamine neurotransmitter system of the brain is broadly linked to neurological disorders, mental illness, and addiction. The way distinct dopamine systems are regulated at the circuit, molecular, and pharmacological level remains poorly resolved. We will use advanced genetic and pharmacological techniques to determine how dopamine subsystems within the ventral tegmental area are regulated that will provide important insights for therapeutics development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will examine the efficacy of a videoconference-delivered cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), Memory and Attention Adaptation Training (MAAT) vs. an attention control condition (supportive therapy; ST), in a large, multi-site, randomized controlled trial (RCT) to improve subjective and objective cognitive functioning in breast cancer survivors with chemotherapy-related cognitive dysfunction (CRCD). Another goal of the research is to use functional MRI (fMRI) to evaluate underlying changes in brain activation patterns that are believed to be associated with positive effects of MAAT. If successful, results of this work will: (1) produce an evidence-based treatment that can be immediately disseminated to cancer centers and other healthcare settings to treat CRCD and (2) help inform further treatment development through improved understanding of mechanisms that promote CRCD recovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This dietary intervention study will examine the effect of a prescribed, laboratory-prepared, home-delivered Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension (DASH) diet intervention on novel and clinically important markers of heart failure status in older adults. Given the high human and economic costs associated with heart failure complications among older adults, the clinical testing of a nutritional intervention represents a much needed, low-cost, and prudent strategy likely to improve heart failure outcomes. This project will contribute to fundamental knowledge to advance heart failure patient care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will further our understanding of SLC13A5-associated citrate transporter disorder by establishing and characterizing Drosophila and mouse models for the disease. These studies will provide evidence supporting the complexity of SLC13A5 disease mechanisms as well as designing potential therapies for this disorder. Using our novel models, our multidisciplinary approach will characterize phenotype-genotype relationships and molecular mechanisms underlying SLC13A5 disease, and use the power of Drosophila genetics to design new therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project explores the effect of chitin, a widespread environmental polysaccharide, on the post-acute sequelae (PASC) of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) infection. Since chitin is normally degraded by chitinases present in the airways of mice and humans, we will characterize chitinase-producing epithelial cells in mouse models of SARS-CoV-2 infection, and test whether altering chitinase activity influences the severity and persistence of disease induced by SARS-CoV-2 infection. Understanding how environmental chitin influences long-lasting pathology after SARS-CoV-2 infection may lead to the identification of new biomarkers and therapeutic targets associated with PASC and differential COVID-19 disease outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Among community-living older adults, falls are a leading cause of injury, disability, injury-related death, and high medical costs. Using data from the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services and data collected from over 12,000 women enrolled in the Women’s Health Study who wore an accelerometer during waking hours for a week, we will evaluate if metrics of daily living gait and physical activity inform the prediction of injurious falls.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The impact of Maternal immune activation (MIA) during pregnancy on the brain development in humans is largely unknown. We propose to use the Generation R cohort, a cohort with a large sample size and long follow-up period, to combine detailed clinical information on infections during pregnancy and inflammatory biomarkers with structural and functional brain imaging and detailed assessment of cognition, behavior and psychopathology in the adolescent offspring. While a positive association could lead to targets for prevention and aggressive treatment of infections during pregnancy, negative findings or threshold effects could provide reassurance to pregnant women and their families.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Glaucoma is a leading cause of blindness; however, current treatment strategies are not sufficient to prevent progressive injury to specific nerve cells (called optic nerve) and continuous loss of visual function. The proposed project aims to determine the disease-causing importance of a molecule (called cFLIP) by modeling glaucoma in specific mouse strains lacking this molecule in glia (that are adjacent to nerve cells) and testing the effects on inflammatory nerve injury (that can be induced by glia). We expect that the information collected through this project will eventually help develop new treatment possibilities for millions of Americans suffering from this blinding disease and will also be useful in various other fields of medical research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Ending the HIV epidemic within 10 years is an achievable goal but may not be possible without improving the extent to which substance use services are implemented into HIV service settings across the nation. This large-scale experiment will test the impact of an innovative strategy that was found to be highly effective and cost-effective for improving implementation of substance use services in non-HIV service settings. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with a new diagnosis of acute myeloid leukemia (AML) confront substantial psychological symptoms as they cope with a sudden and life-threatening diagnosis that requires immediate disruption of their lives and an urgent 4-6-week hospitalization to initiate intensive chemotherapy. Despite their immense burden, interventions to address the needs of this vulnerable population are limited. This proposal seeks to assess the efficacy of a patient-centered, self-administered, digital app (DREAMLAND) for improving patient-reported quality of life and psychological distress during this challenging hospitalization for intensive chemotherapy and in the long-term.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic kidney disease is a gradual loss of kidney function, which is a major cause of morbidity and mortality in the US. Once kidney damage occurs, it results in incomplete removal of toxic products made by our microflora, termed uremic toxins, which accelerates disease progression. Chronic kidney disease is linked to changes in the composition of our microflora (dysbiosis), but it remains unclear whether these compositional changes accelerate disease progression. Successful completion of the proposed research will reveal the ecological causes of dysbiosis and determine whether dysbiosis has causative effects on chronic kidney disease progression. This information will be a critical first step for translating advances in microbiome research into clinical intervention.

PHR: Project Narrative Implicit bias is a well-documented contributor to healthcare disparities that lead to poorer health outcomes, higher infant mortality rates, and chronic disease in racial and ethnic minority populations. There exists a clear and critical need to reimagine how we approach engineering training to improve cultural competency and facilitate patient-centered, economical solutions accessible by all people regardless of race and socioeconomic status. The objective of this proposal is to establish a community- centered medical device innovation program that leads to creative, interdisciplinary problem solving of multidisciplinary engineering-nursing design teams.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Continuous glucose monitoring (CGM) and ambulatory blood pressure monitoring (ABPM) data are increasingly used in clinical trials, but conventional crude summaries of these data are not sufficiently sensitive for capturing possibly heterogeneous treatment effects. We will develop novel machine-learning methods to improve the characterization of CGM and ABPM data features. PHR: Project Narrative: This proposal is to fund a complete refurbishment of the McLean Hospital 9.4T / 400 mm Tesla Agilent Pre-clinical Magnetic Resonance Imaging system; this scanner is the only actively shielded 400 mm pre-clinical magnet in the world and provides imaging from mice through large NHP for the McLean and Boston area research communities. PHR: Recognizing challenges in people living with HBV and HIV needing to take daily pills for virus- free survival, this research has potential to bring about a transformative change in the outlook for individual living with viral hepatitis and carry the risk of liver cancer. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Exposure to organophosphate nerve agents (OPNAs) causes acute seizures and brain injury in the long term. The current medical countermeasures are inadequate to prevent seizures-induced brain injury and its mechanisms are not well known. We, therefore, investigate the molecular mechanisms of brain injury to identify novel therapeutic targets for neuroprotection and disease-modification in the rat OPNA model.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The research proposed here, which requires high-sensitivity state-of-the-art biophysical spectroscopic technique to enable the study of protein structure and functional dynamics, will lead to a better mechanistic understanding of a variety of physiological and disease processes. It will also contribute to the development of novel antibiotics and cancer therapeutic agents, and to the design of safer and more effective drugs targeting a broad spectrum of diseases. Additional avenues of research are expected to be uncovered once the success of the initially proposed projects is evident, fostering further opportunities for new interdisciplinary science.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Updating Ultrasound Imaging Instrument at University of Illinois at Chicago PROJECT NARRATIVE  High-speed and high-resolution ultrasound imaging provides sensitive and dynamic detections of anatomical architectures and physiological functions in small animal models for researching human biology and disease. To sustain and expand the high volumes of productive basic and translational research at the University of Illinois at Chicago (UIC), we seek support for a VisualSonics Vevo F2 high-resolution 4- dimensional small animal ultrasound imaging system. This instrument will replace an end-of-life Vevo 2100 system to update a crucial core facility that supports multiple NIH-funded research programs at UIC.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This application supports the purchase of a next-generation 7 Tesla whole-body human MRI scanner at the Athinoula A. Martinos Center for Biomedical Imaging to replace our 22-year-old prototype 7 Tesla scanner that will soon be decommissioned. The new instrument – a Siemens Terra.X 7 Tesla scanner – will support at least 20 NIH-funded investigators at the Martinos Center and the greater Boston area community. This whole-body MRI scanner is designed to function with a next-generation removable positron emission tomography (PET) camera with an order of magnitude improvement in PET sensitivity, thereby serving both the ultra-high field MRI and PET imaging communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed study investigates the role of the nuclear receptor subfamily 4, group A, member 1 (NR4A1) in pain resolution, and aims to provide a translational validation of NR4A1 as a new, non-addictive, therapeutic target for postoperative pain and low back pain, two pain conditions at high risk of opioid abuse. Additionally, the study will reveal SPP1 as a novel biological and functional biomarker for future testing and improve of multiple NR4A1 agonists aiming to prevent and treat chronic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative A new and promising treatment for antibiotic-resistant bacterial infections is phage therapy, in which the viruses (bacteriophages) that normally infect bacteria are used to eradicate specific pathogens. The long-term success and efficacy of such efforts depend critically on a deeper, more complete understanding of how bacteria can respond to and evade infection by bacteriophages. This work focuses on the development and application of a powerful, large-scale functional screening approach to rapidly pinpoint the anti-phage defenses systems in a diverse collection of 1,500+ E. coli strains, including many pathogenic strains.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: NARRATIVE We are developing a new training program for biomedical engineering (BME) students that will cultivate their Engineering Habits of Mind (EHoM) and serve as a bridge to a career in medical device research and development (R&D). This experiential learning (EL) opportunity will consist of a clinical immersion conducted in rural and urban healthcare facilities to identify unmet medical needs with a focus on understanding the social determinants of health (SDoH) and promoting health equity. In parallel, student teams will build prototyping skills by working on existing R&D projects to improve healthcare with our clinical partner and lead design, fabrication, and proof-of-concept testing through simulated use verification and validation activities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Approximately three million people are exposed to acute organophosphate poisoning every year world-wide. Due to a lack of research tools available, there is still a lack of knowledge surrounding the molecular short- and long-term effects of acute organophosphate intoxication. We propose the use of a novel mouse model and matrix assisted laser desorption ionization mass spectrometry imaging to study these effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Breast-resident microbes are proposed to be largely attributed to translocation of gut microbes and play critical roles in regulation of breast pathophysiology; however, t here have been mostly correlative and speculative studies for the roles and origins of breast microbiota. The proposed project aims to substantiate the direct roles of breast microbiota in breast pathophysiology. The proposed study is relevant to public health because it will justify a new breast cancer treatment or prevention strategy focused on breast microbiota.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We have recently established that standard immune checkpoint therapies targeting PD-1, alone or in combination with targeting either anti-CTLA-4 or anti-LAG-3, can result in the hyperprogression of renal malignancies driven by loss of the SMARCB1 tumor suppressor gene. In the proposed project, we will harness our unique collection of longitudinally collected patient tissue samples and robust preclinical models to elucidate the mechanisms driving hyperprogression and inform the next generation of immunotherapeutic strategies for SMARCB1-deficient renal malignancies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Colon cancer is characterized by a prominent dynamic interaction between host and gut microbes through secondary metabolites such as bile acids, which has been shown to promote tumor initiation and progression, facilitate inflammation and reshape the gut microbiota community. The research proposed here aims to better understand how tumor risk factors including diet, inflammation and gut microbiota converged on BAs-FXR axis and modulate macrophage intrinsic responses to intestinal inflammation and tumor growth. This integrative approach to interrogate this dynamic host immune landscape with host-and-microbe communicating metabolites will shed light on not only the etiology of colitis-induced colon cancer, but also identify new therapeutic targets and biomarkers.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE High-parameter cytometry and in-depth imaging analysis can yield critical insights into the complexities of biological processes, diseases, and treatments. By evaluating both suspended and tissue biospecimens with measurements of 40+ protein features at once with high customizability and in a relatively cost-effective manner, mass cytometry as a unique discovery platform has been significantly empowering multiple key research efforts at Johns Hopkins University. Leveraging the current infrastructure of Johns Hopkins Mass Cytometry Facility, this proposal seeks to fund a CyTOF XT as the second mass cytometer to meet the rapidly growing demands in a wide-breadth of NIH-funded research activities including multiple cancer research programs, bioengineering, computational biology, and dermatology at Johns Hopkins.

PHR: Acquisition of a modern 800 MHz NMR spectrometer will provide essential new capabilities in high throughput fragment-based drug discovery, 19F NMR, and NMR-based structural biology to six major users and many minor users at Vanderbilt University, supported by NIH funding. It will be used for probing biomolecular binding interactions, and structural and dynamics studies of complex biological macromolecules.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: VA has a strong commitment to transitioning into a Learning Healthcare System characterized by the alignment of science with clinical priorities, the development of rapid and efficient studies, and the leveraging of existing data to deploy and evaluate innovations and best practices. The Center for Evaluation and Implementation Resources (CEIR) will help with this transition by providing administrative support for rapid evaluations based on operational priorities, the coordination of training opportunities in program evaluation and implementation science best practices, and the provision of consultations on project methods, partnerships, and funding. The combination of these services will support the development of core skills among VA employees in evaluation and practice implementation and support the adoption of evidence-informed program management consistent with Evidence Act expectations.

PHR: Project Narrative In this proposal, the Robert Wood Johnson Medical School/Rutgers Biological Mass Spectrometry Facility is requesting funding for a mass spectrometer. This instrument will greatly enhance the ability of scientists on the Piscataway and New Brunswick campuses of Rutgers University to conduct cutting-edge biomedical research and will provide access to cutting-edge technology for many new junior Faculty recruits at Rutgers. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Ferroptosis represents a vulnerability in certain cancers with acquired resistance to therapies. Based on my preliminary results, I aim to study the role and mechanism of mitochondrial calcium signaling-mediated acetyl coenzyme A metabolism in the regulation of ferroptotic cell death and antitumor immunity. Understanding the consequence of cancer cell ferroptosis affecting tumor microenvironment will be instrumental for the generation of new therapeutic approaches for cancer treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT (PROJECT NARRATIVE) The essential task of synthesizing all the proteins encoded in an organism’s DNA is executed solely by the ribosome and its associated translation machinery (TM). Using a powerful combination of fluorophore-labeled biological components and experimental approaches unique to the applicant’s and their collaborators’ laboratories, this proposal aims to elucidate aspects of the process through which the TM executes and controls protein synthesis that have thus far remained difficult or impossible to investigate. Because the bacterial TM is the target of many clinically relevant small-molecule antibiotics and dysregulation of the human TM plays a causal role in several human diseases, including numerous viral infections and cancers, the results of these studies are expected to identify new targets and strategies for the development of next-generation antibiotics and small- molecule therapeutics for treating viral infections, cancers, and other human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Periodontal diseases are common chronic inflammatory disease, afflicting up to 50% of the adult population in the United States and associated with systemic diseases, such as diabetes and cardiovascular disease. The proliferation of anaerobic bacteria below the gumline is central to disease progression, with Porphyromonas gingivalis being implicated as one of the primary endogenous pathogens. We are studying how this bacterium controls the production of its surface polysaccharides and membrane lipids, which are key determinants of its virulence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Overall this project provides direct relevance to public health by facilitating new insights through the development of a novel mobile framework to be used in current clinical practice for non-invasive direct assessment of the left ventricular end diastolic pressure. The novel biologically-inspired device will significantly impact the current known methods for detection, monitoring, prevention and treatment of heart failure, and support evidence-based clinical practice. The project will help reduce health disparities in the area of heart disease, assist in providing preventive cardiac care, assist in improving access to care, assist in early diagnosis of the risk of heart diseases and it will significantly impact the current known methods, technologies, treatments, and address critical barriers to progress in the field.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Large disparities in the number of underrepresented students pursuing careers in biomedical science still exist. The Monell Science Apprenticeship Program (MSAP) 2.0 strives to positively influence the science career decisions of students from underrepresented backgrounds who represent different genders, economic strata, races, ethnicities, and physical and mental abilities. IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this project is to evaluate a new method by the subconjunctival injection of DSP nanoparticles for treating nitrogen mustard (NM)-induced corneal injury. Therapeutic interventions to treat NM-induced ocular injury has not been identified yet, which highlights the need to develop new treatment options for vesicants- induced corneal injury. The sustained releasing DSP-PLA-NP could be effective in preventing corneal NV, corneal ulceration, corneal opacity, suppressing inflammatory and angiogenic markers after NM exposure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative While enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) is widely used in clinical laboratories for disease biomarker screening and quantification, substantially improving their limit of detection without adding complexity has been a grand challenge. The proposed research aims to overcome this challenge by developing a unique signal generation system for ELISA. If successful, this work will significantly advance ELISA technology, enabling it to detect biomarkers at minute concentrations.

PHR: NARRATIVE This project will digitize the 1960 full-count Census and use the resulting microdata to complete the largest longitudinal data infrastructure in the United States. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Previous reports demonstrated an aberrant accumulation of oral microbes in the gut of patients with colorectal cancer (CRC). However, how this ectopic gut colonization by oral microbes occurs and how this event with affects the pathogenesis of CRC remain poorly understood. This project will elucidate the mechanisms by which oral microbes colonize the gut and promote the development of CRC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative The plasma levels of the blood clotting protein, Von Willebrand Factor, contribute to an individual’s risk of both bleeding or abnormal blood clotting. Most of the variation of plasma von Willebrand Factor levels in humans is determined by genetic variants. This project uses up to date synthetic DNA techniques to determine the effect of mutations in the VWF gene and loss of function in other secretory pathway genes on plasma VWF levels.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  We will implement the use of student health care professionals in the role of ‘clinical TAs’ in four required undergraduate biomedical design courses as well as develop training for student health professionals on design thinking and the work of biomedical engineers. By reversing the default approach of immersing BME students in health care settings, we expect to accelerate the development of design skills including how they gain understanding and insight from user interactions throughout the design process. We ground our approach in research on collaborative design to increase the skills of multiple stakeholder groups to effectively engage in team-based biomedical design that leads to better needs and solution identification. 2

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Olfactory networks are implicated in a number of neurological diseases including Alzheimer’s, Parkinson’s and epilepsy. Furthermore, SARS-CoV-2 has recently been identified inside piriform cortex of primates infected with COVID, and has been shown to impact olfactory cortical networks with human piriform cortex, a major focus of this grant. The research proposed in this grant aims to determine electrophysiological properties of networks involved in encoding features of odor stimuli, which will lead to better understanding of the brain areas involved in these neurological diseases.

PHR: Project Narrative: Neurodevelopmental disorders, including microcephaly and autism, as well as neurodegenerative diseases, including Alzheimer’s, and cancer result in significant human suffering and impose significant annual costs on the US health care system and society as a whole. IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative  NMR spectroscopy provides a means to identify, observe, and study the interactions of molecules important to human health. The proposed acquisition of a new spectrometer at Vanderbilt University will support researchers in the chemical and biochemical sciences who are working to identify natural products, advance drug candidates, understand the toxicity of chemotherapeutics, and develop molecular probes. This new instrument will modernize NMR infrastructure on campus and assist in training a new generation of chemists and chemical biologists.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: To investigate the rapidly advancing ketamine landscape, this study will integrate data on 1) prescribing,  medical use, and misuse, 2) recreational use, and 3) population-level data on availability and adverse events  including poisonings and death. This will include monitoring of ketamine prescribing practices, availability via  legal and illegal channels, and drug diversion, with additional focus on patterns of illicit use among high-risk  populations. Results will inform policy to curb availability, as well as prevention, treatment, and harm reduction  efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE It is well-established that dysregulation of dopamine, noradrenaline, and serotonin signaling underlies many neurological and neuropsychiatric disorders, but there are fundamental gaps in the understanding of the mechanisms that control the release of these chemicals in the brain and how these chemicals signal at the level of synapses. The proposed research is relevant to public health because our incomplete understanding of the ion channels and circuits affected by dopamine, noradrenaline, and serotonin represents a key barrier to treating neuropsychiatric disorders (including cocaine use disorder), which currently lack efficacious therapeutics.

PHR: NARRATIVE The Center for Lung Biology and Disease was established through a Phase I Center of Biomedical Research Excellence award. Our Phase I proposal, aimed at providing Promising Junior Investigators (PJIs) an environment that maximizes their potential to contribute to advances in lung disease research, was successful in launching 6 new scientists in independent research careers. This Phase II proposal will continue programs established in Phase I, with an overarching goal of promoting research to unravel life-threatening respiratory diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Narrative  The population of older individuals is increasing at a faster pace than all other age groups. Nevertheless, the quality of life and ‘healthy aging’ (i.e., freedom from chronic diseases and good functioning at individual and group levels) may be as, if not more important, than the number of years added to our lifespan, for both individuals and society. This makes it essential to understand the mechanism and identify factors contributing towards healthy aging. Here we will examine the role of abnormal time of eating (a common lifestyle factor that affects circadian rhythm) in accelerating aging by modulating intestinal barrier damage, microbiota dysbiosis, gut leakiness and pancreas damage. Microbial signaling networks and their interaction with host biological rhythms as targetable mechanisms involved in aging will be studied. Findings from these experiments will identify intervenable mechanisms to prevent organ damage by age.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We are requesting funds to purchase an Zeiss LSM 980 2p ready microscope system, to replace a -10 year old heavily used microscope system within the Advanced Light Microcopy core at the University of Colorado Anschutz medical campus. This system will enable the continued use of vital microscopy capabilities that are required by >140 NIH-funded investigators, which is represented by the innovative research performed by major and minor users. The ALMC is well placed to maximize the use of this system based on our extensive experience working with advanced microscope systems, highly skilled staff, knowledgeable faculty and strong institutional support.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this project is to establish the manufacturability, analytical validation, and clinical utility of the OcclusionChip in providing comprehensive functional characterization of red cell biorheological properties and assessment of patient-specific response to emerging targeted and curative therapies in sickle cell disease. With this Administrative Supplements to Promote Diversity, our goal is to provide a mentorship, advising, and a unique research experience to Ms. Madeleine Tincher. This opportunity will prepare her for a future career as a successful translational researcher and entrepreneur.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Over 200,000 children have a 911 Emergency Medical Services (EMS) activation for respiratory distress each year, most of whom have acute wheezing. Early treatment in the prehospital setting could more rapidly relieve respiratory distress symptoms, prevent hypoxia, reduce invasive interventions, and reduce the need to be hospitalized, thereby facilitating earlier return to normal daily activities. This proposal is for a pilot trial that implements ipratropium and dexamethasone into a prehospital treatment bundle for children with acute wheezing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. The experiments in this proposal will examine the functions of memory B cells that live in the lung and respond to influenza infection and compare them with memory B cells that live at systemic sites. We will also determine how various vaccination strategies enhance or impair the formation of memory B cells in the lung, experiments that are critically important for understanding how and when vaccines should be administered in the respiratory tract.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We test fundamental ideas about how the circadian clock modulates skin regeneration and aging and how these processes are affected by time of feeding. Skin aging causes skin fragility and delayed wound healing, a common cause of chronic wounds in the elderly, which poses a major public health problem in the aging population. This work may lead to new ideas about how to maintain skin strength and regenerative ability into old age.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: OVERALL- Narrative Older adults are disproportionally sensitive to infection and also suffer from elevated levels of cancer and of certain types of autoimmunity. A decline in immune function decisively contributes to this vulnerability, and a decline in T cell function and maintenance is responsible for much of that decline. This Program is designed to continue to significantly contribute to fundamental knowledge of T cell aging, but more importantly to yield one or more combined interventions that improve immune defense against infection in aged mouse models, paving the way for interventions to improve T cell immunity and healthspan in older humans, providing also for substantial health care and overall economy savings and benefits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill Intensive Summer Research Training in Emergency Medicine (ISTEM) program will allow eight medical students per year to experience public health and medical research first-hand in topics related to emergency medicine and patient care of the heart, lungs, and blood. This program will provide the opportunity to gain relevant experience and insight into the research field directly under well-published, grant-funded mentors while maintaining strict guidelines and expectations. The value of this program will be immeasurable as ISTEM will influence the future direction of upcoming physician researchers early in their academic career.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To dissect the functional roles of distinct neuron-types in animal perception and behavior, targeted recording techniques that operate at the physiologically relevant spatiotemporal scales should complement current approaches of functional manipulation. Here, we propose to use our new suite of genetically encoded fluorescent voltage indicators for concurrent, high-speed, multipopulation recordings to understand the role of distinct visual cortical interneuron-types in attentional modulation of sensory processing during visually guided behavior. Our proposed work will enable real-time comparisons of the voltage dynamics among and between distinct interneuronal ensembles that contribute to visual gain modulation and establish multipopulation voltage imaging as the preferred method to reveal these interactions at cellular-resolution and millisecond timescales.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Homologous recombination is a DNA repair pathway, which plays crucial roles in genetic disorders, cancer and aging, thus, inhibitors of homologous recombination are expected to be more lethal to rapidly growing cancers than to more slowly growing healthy cells. As a first step towards developing targeted therapies that can be used to modulate homologous recombination it is essential to understand the basic biochemical properties of the proteins involved and more fully define their impact on DNA metabolism. To help extend our understanding homologous recombination we have developed a powerful new experimental platform based on state–of–the–art optical microscopy that allows us to address questions in biomedical research that cannot be tackled with more traditional experimental approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Disturbance of the normal rhythm of the heart is a common ailment, especially among the elderly, and these life-threatening cardiac arrhythmias are treated by antiarrhythmic drugs. In this project, we will determine the structure of the cardiac sodium and calcium channels, which initiate the heartbeat, analyze the structures of their different functional states, image antiarrhythmic drugs in their sites of action on sodium and calcium channels, and elucidate the structural changes caused by mutations in these ion channels that induce life-threatening arrhythmias. Our results will help to understand the normal function of sodium and calcium channels, their dysfunction in arrhythmias, and the ability of antiarrhythmic drugs to terminate and prevent cardiac arrhythmias, with important implications for discovery of next-generation antiarrhythmic drugs with greater safety and efficacy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Our laboratory studies the structures and mechanisms of site-specific enzymes that act on DNA and RNA targets, and further employs protein engineering to develop novel protein folds and functions and to challenge our understanding of protein form and function. We will renew and expand our research mission by pursuing three new directions that will expand upon our approaches for such studies. We will answer basic questions surrounding the evolution, recognition mechanisms and engineerability of sequence-specific microbial RNA endonucleases and eukaryotic retrotransposons and will address the unsolved problem of accurately designing highly polar biomolecular interfaces achieve the balance of affinity, specificity and reversibility found in many biomolecular interactions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Deaf children learning American Sign Language (ASL) perceive both language input and information about the world through the visual modality, so they must learn to divide and allocate their visual attention between people and objects in order to learn new words. In the proposed project we will investigate how the timing of parent input relative to child attention supports word learning, and how deaf children learn to divide and allocate their visual attention to learn new words. Findings from this project will inform parents, teachers, and early intervention specialists working with deaf children by documenting optimal strategies to support word learning.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: There is an ever increasing need to develop better tools to facilitate the management of controversial cystic pancreatic lesions detected incidentally by imaging. We propose to use a new analytical technique (DEST) to study circulating extracellular vesicles (EV) in patients with incidentally detected intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasms (IPMN), precancerous lesions of the pancreas. This will allow us to discover the make-up of EV in clinical specimen, facilitate the management of controversial lesions and detect individuals with high likelihood of malignant progression. The ultrasenstive vesicle detection method has the potential to transform early pancreatic cancer research and clinical practice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: In all vertebrate embryos, the neural crest gives rise to the sensory, autonomic and enteric nervous system, craniofacial skeleton and melanocytes of the skin. Not only does the neural crest have the capacity to form an amazing number of embryonic cell types, but also neural crest stem cells persist in adult tissue. For example, a population of these cells, called Schwann cell precursors, have been found closely associated with peripheral nerves and are present throughout the body, where they have been shown to differentiate into various derivatives including neurons, glia and pigment cells. Because neural crest cells are involved in a variety of birth defects such as Hirschsprung's disease, cleft palate and various types of cancers, like neuroblastoma, melanoma and pheochromocytoma, the results of this proposal regarding neural crest cell diversification across vertebrates will provide important understanding of the normal development of these cells that can later lead to disease states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: HENRY M. JACKSON FDN FOR THE ADV MIL/MED
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal seeks to organize genes that have been linked to alcohol-related phenotypes into biological modules to elucidate novel pathways implicated in alcohol use and alcohol use disorder. The proposal will then explore drug-protein interactions with these implicated targets to identify promising drugs for repurposing to treat alcohol use disorder. Finally, the study will leverage access to the entire Veterans Affairs electronic health records to explore if the impact of exposure to any of these drugs leads to improvements in alcohol use disorder and thus justifies follow-up testing in clinical trials for potential repurposing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Steatosis, the earliest manifestation of alcohol-associated liver disease (ALD), is often benign and reversible. However, it is widely believed to be the precursor to fibrosis, cirrhosis and cancer and therefore is a prime target for therapeutic intervention. The goal of this proposal is to examine the mechanistic role of gut hormones in the development of alcohol-associated hepatic steatosis. We will investigate how a gut-hormone, ghrelin, whose circulating levels are increased by alcohol consumption, can affect the activity/levels of other hormones to alter the gut-adipose-liver interactions to ultimately lead to the development of hepatic steatosis. Successful completion of the proposed studies will help us to gain mechanistic insights into understanding ghrelin’s role in modulating the organ-organ interactions to promote the development of alcohol-associated hepatic steatosis and hopefully provide some strategies to prevent ALD pathogenesis and progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic alcohol exposure produces tolerance to alcohol’s aversive properties, which functions to release the brake on drinking, contributing to difficulty controlling consumption. The neurobiological mechanisms underlying this effect are not well understood but likely include alterations in neural circuits involved in aversive signaling. The project proposed in the current application will examine the role of inputs from functionally distinct subregions of the medial prefrontal cortex to the rostromedial tegmental nucleus in driving chronic tolerance to alcohol’s aversive properties.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is a common condition of severe respiratory failure precipitated by a variety of insults (e.g., Covid-19 and other respiratory viruses, sepsis, and pneumonia), with hospital mortality of 30–40% and significant morbidity among survivors. ARDS randomized clinical trials (RCTs) have been hampered by (1) analyses that yield a strict binary conclusion concerning treatment efficacy, (2) inadequate statistical methods to assess heterogeneity of treatment effect among varying patient types, and (3) death- truncated non-mortality outcomes such as length of stay. To offer more intuitive probabilistic interpretations of an intervention’s efficacy and thus maximally leverage the information learned from a trial, the researchers will apply a suite of Bayesian causal inference and machine learning methods to 29 international and NIH/NHLBI- funded multicenter ARDS RCTs to (1) determine the probability that the tested interventions produce benefit or harm on the absolute and relative scale for both mortality and non-mortality clinical outcomes, (2) quantify the degree of confidence in these conclusions, and (3) identify clinically meaningful subgroups most likely to benefit.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Brain metastasis represents the last stage of cancer, for which there are no therapies to date. We have found that ablation of regulatory T cells, which infiltrate primary tumors and metastasis and correlate with poor prognosis, strongly suppresses brain metastasis, and control reactive gliosis. A better understanding of the mechanisms controlling the cross talk among Treg cells, reactive astrocytes and tumor cells may lead to new approaches to combat this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Listeners who wear a cochlear implant exert extra effort while listening, a phenomenon that negatively impacts their quality of life, social communication, mental health, and can lead to greater levels of fatigue. The goal of the proposed research is to refine new techniques in physiological and behavioral assessment of listening effort and directly measure how momentary increase in effort can accumulate into fatigue. The results could lead to diagnostic procedures that better reflect real-world difficulties experienced by those with hearing loss and a better understanding of the mechanisms of listening effort and fatigue.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Individuals with Alzheimer’s disease (AD) often suffer from motor problems such as slowness and loss of strength. Constructing a composite score of multiple motor domains in AD can result in a marker that could be used to indicate the risk to develop the disease. In the proposed study we will use machine learning to identify which motor measures are best used together to create such a composite score, and to define the neural mechanisms that underly motor dysfunction in AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE T cell transcription factors (TFs) STAT3 and BATF play a critical role in CD4 T cell activation in response to influential cytokines; however, mice deficient for both STAT3 and BATF, but not each individual TF, developed spontaneous colitis that featured high numbers of inflammatory γδ T cells in the intestines. This recapitulates what is seen in human inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) patients and suggests that STAT3 and BATF- expressing CD4 T cells regulate intestinal homeostasis by controlling aberrant activation of gut γδ T cells to prevent IBD pathogenicity. Therefore, defining the mechanisms by which STAT3/BATF regulate this pathway will lead to identification of signaling pathways or cell surface proteins that may be therapeutically leveraged in treating IBD.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: JAMES J PETERS VA  MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative: Suicide rates among veterans with Serious Mental Illness (SMI) are intractably high, representing a serious public health concern and a critical target for interventions. Yet, at present available treatments offer only limited benefits. Thus, there remains an urgent need to identify novel approaches to address suicide risk in this population. Previous reports have linked suicide risk with poor social functioning (SF). Emerging evidence from basic affective neuroscience research has indicated effective SF is contingent on intact emotion awareness. Consistent with these findings, individuals with SMI at risk of suicide display SF difficulties along with poor emotion awareness (i.e., alexithymia). Employing a proof-of-concept design, the aim of the present study is to test the feasibility and acceptability of a novel, blended psychoeducation and digital mHealth intervention with smartphones designed to target alexithymia and poor SF to reduce suicide risk in veterans with SMI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcohol Use Disorder is a major public health concern in the United States and the causation of relapse can be explained by active avoidance of stress and anxiety. My project focuses on how exercise might manipulate a specific brain region to prevent these feelings of stress and anxiety during alcohol abstinence. In doing so, we hope to identify a simple treatment to prevent relapse during alcohol use disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  ISG15 is an important molecule in the innate immune response against a wide range of human viral and microbial pathogens, including Mycobacterium tuberculosis and SARS-CoV-2. ISG15 has three distinct and separable biochemical functions and a major goal of this project is to understand how these activities are regulated and coordinately controlled. We anticipate that this will lead to the development of novel antiviral and antimicrobial therapies for important human infectious diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Despite its importance to human health, proprioception is perhaps the most poorly understood of all the senses. This proposal applies innovative methods to gain detailed insights into the circuit, cellular, and synaptic mechanisms of proprioceptive neural processing. An improved understanding of proprioception is essential for developing therapeutic strategies to treat somatosensory disorders such as chronic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: A small protein called ubiquitin (and a small family of similar proteins) regulates the growth, division, and behavior of all human cells and those of virtually all organisms with a nucleus. Ubiquitin is attached to specific cellular proteins, and this often causes the degradation of the tagged protein; defects in the enzymes controlling these processes are known to cause human neurodegenerative disorders, developmental abnormalities, and various cancers. This project aims to deepen our understanding of the key enzymes that attach ubiquitin to and remove it from proteins and the mechanism of degrading the tagged proteins, with the long-term goal of developing therapies to treat patients suffering from neurodegenerative disease, diabetes, cancer, or certain infectious diseases.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiovascular disease is the leading cause of death among women in the United States, and women with hypertensive disorders of pregnancy have a 2-fold higher risk for cardiovascular disease later in life compared to women with uncomplicated pregnancies. This research investigates a patient-centered intervention during the postpartum period to promote engagement in cardiovascular preventive care. Leveraging the association between hypertensive disorders of pregnancy and cardiovascular disease to provide effective preventive health interventions may ultimately prevent cardiovascular death and disability among women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Narrative Alcoholic hepatitis (AH) is a severe acute form of alcoholic liver disease with a very high mortality rate. Despite years of research, the standard-of-care and mortality rate has not changed dramatically in over 50 years. Our goal is to develop new computational and experimental methods and discover new biomarkers for AH outcome that can efficiently identify at-risk individuals. A second goal of the project is to identify molecular mechanisms of AH, which could be targeted therapeutically.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The goals of our research are to identify and characterize the molecular machinery that contributes to synaptic signaling in the nervous system, with a focus on signaling mediated by the excitatory neurotransmitter glutamate and mediated by ionotropic glutamate receptors (iGluRs). Our goal is to obtain a mechanistic understanding of how neuropeptide signaling regulates the function of NMDA-type iGluRs, with a focus on specific peptide ligands and G-protein coupled receptors. These studies could provide new insights into the disordered synaptic function characteristic of many neurological disorders, identify new drug targets for therapeutic intervention, and ultimately contribute to the development of new therapeutic modalities for the treatment of neurological and psychiatric disorders.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: 8. Project Narrative Morquio A disease is a devastating systemic skeletal disease in which detailed progression and pathogenesis remain unknown. The proposed project aims to establish a non-invasive objective assessment that can be applicable to all ages of patients to better understand the progress of their disease and the most serious clinical problems (cervical instability and stenosis, tracheal obstruction, hyperlaxity of joints, hip dysplasia, and small lung capacity). The outcome of this project will lead to a more precise understanding of the skeletal/pulmonary compromise and defining clinical endpoints in this disease for future clinical trials of current or developing therapies. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The specific types and amounts of metabolite molecules present in biological systems, such as blood, serum, and tissues, provide critical information about health and disease. Metabolomics is a top-down approach, which involves identification and quantitation of metabolites in complex biological mixtures. The proposed research program aims at developing new metabolomics technologies, which are based on nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy as well as in combination with cheminformatics and with mass spectrometry, to analyze a wide range of biological mixtures more comprehensively, accurately, and efficiently and to apply these tools and make them available to the scientific community, including via public web servers and databases, with synergistic benefits also for protein science.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Amyloidosis is an under-appreciated cause of lumbar spinal stenosis in older adults and proceeds the development of transthyretin cardiac amyloidosis by many years. By systematically evaluating older adults with lumbar spinal stenosis who have previously undergone lumbar spine surgery and evaluation of pathologic specimens for amyloid, and if amyloid is present, performing tissue typing with mass spectrometry, there's a unique opportunity to identify older adults with ATTR-CA early in the course of the illness, at a time when disease modifying therapies that are most effective. The data collected in the planned studies could change clinical practice and facilitate early identification of those who develop transthyretin cardiac amyloidosis, a disorder that without recognition and treatment is a progressive, highly morbid, and fatal but with early identification is easily managed.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Immunoglobulin light chain amyloidosis (AL) is a degenerative disease that putatively arises from light chain misfolding and aggregation. AL patients, who suffer from both a plasma cell cancer and a LC misfolding and aggregation-associated proteinopathy, are often too sick to tolerate the currently available standard of care that targets the cancer component of AL. In this proposal, we seek to produce light chain kinetic stabilizer lead candidates that ameliorate the proteinopathy component of AL pathology, offering a mechanistically distinct drug candidate.
