IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE People experiencing homelessness (PEH) are at high risk for emergency department and hospital use due to gaps in care and poor communication between health and social services providers. This study will integrate and test a novel mHealth intervention, comprised of global positioning system technology and text messaging components, into a community setting in order to connect PEH with healthcare and social services. This research is significant in that it will engage end-users in refining and integrating the mHealth intervention with a community-based navigation center and employ a RCT design to test the impact of the intervention on ED and hospital visits and health and social needs outcomes.

PROJECT_TITLE: mHealth Technology to Connect and Empower People Experiencing Homelessness to Improve Health and Social Need Outcomes

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A wearable alcohol biosensor might serve health needs across a variety of domains, including aiding in the prevention of alcohol-related disorders, improving interventions for treating problem drinking, and refining outcome assessment in alcohol research. Transdermal sensors represent a uniquely noninvasive and low-cost method for the continuous assessment of alcohol consumption, but data produced by these sensors is highly complex. The current project leverages advances in transdermal technology and computational modeling to translate transdermal data and assess the accuracy of transdermal BAC estimates, thus taking a key step towards clarifying the place of transdermal sensors in our arsenal of techniques for assessing, preventing, and treating problem drinking.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative.  Given the likelihood of COVID-19 remaining an endemic disease among high-risk populations, establishing effective mitigation interventions will be critical to stemming community transmission. Criminal justice-involved individuals are extremely important to reducing community-based SARS-CoV-2 transmission due to their increased risk of contracting SARS-CoV-2 while incarcerated and their likelihood of living in congregate settings after incarceration. We will evaluate an onsite Point-of-Care SARS-CoV-2 testing and education strategy in a corrections-focused community-based organization and its impact on improving testing uptake, mitigation behaviors (e.g. mask wearing, hand hygiene, social distancing, vaccine uptake when available), and cost- effectiveness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Memory allows us to remember specific past experiences, but also find commonalities across experiences generalizable to novel situations. The proposed research will improve our understanding of mechanisms supporting memory specificity and generalization, their contribution to decision-making, and their implementation in the healthy brain. These findings will generate new predictions about the causes of a wide variety of memory impairments, such as reduced memory specificity in aging and Alzheimer’s disease, imbalance of specificity and generalization learning in anxiety, depression, and autism, and mixed patterns of impairments following a stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: I am a clinical psychologist and researcher proposing a 5-year K23 project that includes research and a training program that will allow me to acquire the knowledge and skills I need to become an independent clinician-scientist. What I discover will offer novel data to aid the translation of a prevention model of Alzheimer's disease (AD) dementia from research into routine clinical practice. I will discover how subjective cognitive complaints (SCCs) and future time perspective (FTP) are affected by learning a biomarker result (SA#1), how associations between SCCs and underlying AD pathology are affected by knowledge of an AD biomarker (SA#2), and how changes in FTP in persons with knowledge of an AD biomarker correspond to decision-making (SA#3).

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Prosocial behaviors are central to the development of children and the functioning of households. This research will examine the role of reasoning in prosocial development during the preschool years, both how reasoning develops through caregiver-child conversations and how reasoning shapes children’s judgments and decisions about opportunities to help others. By better understanding the role of reasoning in early prosocial development, families and researchers may create everyday conditions that strengthen children’s healthy prosociality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Adolescent-onset substance use disorders are linked to poorer psychosocial outcomes and are predictive of mortality in early adulthood. For this reason, it is important to identify social and environmental factors that increase an adolescent’s risk of using substances and address those factors in clinical guidance and treatment planning. This study proposes the use of digital phenotyping technology to examine the complex and growing influence of digital media, including online exposure to substance-related content, on adolescent use and procurement of drugs and alcohol.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Cardiac rehabilitation (CR) is purported to improve cardiovascular function, outcomes, and health care utilization after cardiac surgery, but (I) is used variably across patients, providers, and regions, (ii) lacks of substantial and robust evidence for benefit, and (iii) is often the target of financial incentive programs. The proposed research will shed new light on the determinants of CR enrollment after cardiac surgery, the effect of CR enrollment on clinical and economic outcomes, and impact of financial incentives on CR enrollment and subsequent outcomes. The result of this project will provide the evidence needed to develop effective programs and policies designed to improve CR enrollment after cardiac surgery, which will increase the value of cardiac surgical care.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Determinants, Outcomes, and Financial Incentives Associated with Cardiac Rehabilitation Enrollment After Cardiac Surgery

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Osteoarthritis (OA) is a common medical problem for US Veterans. More than 30% of Veterans in the VA healthcare system have OA, higher than in the general population in the US. OA is often painful, and leads to poor quality of life, making it hard to lead a fully functional life, and when it progresses, can be debilitating. Drugs prescribed to alleviate joint pain and joint replacement are the only effective treatments. However, joint replacement surgeries are expensive and even after surgery and rehabilitation, many Veterans still do not regain significant improvements in quality of life, have difficulties performing regular daily activities, need additional care and are more likely to be hospitalized. OA has a genetic component. Therefore, there is a potential to provide insight to why some Veterans develop OA and why some progress to end-stage disease with limited recovery to joint replacement surgery. We propose to follow-up our previous work where genetic analyses led to discoveries with striking potential for translation to clinical care, i.e. findings that will be meaningful to Veterans with OA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE:  This project aims to develop novel botulism therapeutics based on the use of natural neuronal receptors and trafficking patterns normally employed by the targeted toxin itself. Unlike available antibody-based therapeutics and small molecule inhibitors of the light chain metalloprotease, botulism therapeutics based on atoxic derivatives of botulinum neurotoxin (BoNT) can reach an intracellular target in a post‐exposure setting. In addition, unlike conventional, small molecule therapeutics which would equally affect all cells in the body with potentially deleterious cytotoxic side effects, the proposed atoxic BoNT-based molecular vehicle will specifically deliver a therapeutic moiety only to the cytosol of the target cells (motor neurons). This is a unique and innovative approach toward treating not only botulism, as embodied in this proposal, but also toward treating numerous infectious and neurodegenerative diseases in which therapeutic targets reside and exert their action intracellularly.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Sjögren's syndrome is an an autoimmune disease associated with local inflammation and decreased function of lacrimal and salivary glands, as well as systemic inflammation of many other internal organs. Treatment options are limited, possibly because approved treatments do not achieve immunomodulation at both local glandular and systemic sites, both of which sustain disease. Capitalizing on the novel properties of elastin-like polypeptides, we develop distinct strategies to more effectively treat local, glandular and systemic symptoms with immunomodulatory agents, and then explore their efficacy and toxicity in combination, all in murine models of the disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE This two-phased U24 proposal seeks to: 1) establish a Cardiovascular Repository-Type 1 Diabetes (CARE-T1D) program through the collection and biobanking of transplant-quality specimens from human organs donors as well as performance of quality control studies and basic histopathologic examination, and 2) serve as a Coordinating Center for evaluating tissue requests, sample distribution, and data sharing. Specifically over the first two years (phase 1), we propose to collect a complete tissue panel— heart, kidney, vasculature, and blood— from a racially diverse pool of T1D, type 2 diabetes (T2D) and age/sex-matched no-diabetes donors with cardiovascular disease (CVD), providing investigators with the necessary tissue resources to conduct extensive research on the cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying CVD development in individuals with T1D versus those with T2D or without diabetes. For phase 2 (years 3-5), we will distribute tissue samples across a network of qualified investigators, host annual meetings to promote collaborative research, coordinate data uploads to public repositories in compliance with NIH data sharing policies, and create a public facing database that allows for access, integrated viewing and analysis of comprehensive data generated using a broad range of technologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Diverticulitis is a common gastrointestinal indication for hospital admission, outpatient visits, and colon surgery in the U.S. We propose a randomized trial of a USDA Healthy Mediterranean-style Food Pattern versus standardized guidance on fiber intake for patients with diverticulitis to determine feasibility of a larger-scale effectiveness trial focused on the clinical outcome of recurrent diverticulitis; furthermore, we will examine plasma and fecal inflammatory biomarkers. Identifying a candidate intervention for secondary prevention and a biomarker of risk would have profound impacts on management and improve the lives of millions of patients with diverticulitis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Guidance of axons to their targets is an important step in neural circuit assembly during embryonic development. The proposed study will elucidate the functions of a newly identified axon guidance cue, WFIKKN2, and its receptors in neuronal wiring. By providing insights into the basic mechanisms of axon pathfinding, this work can improve our understanding of disorders resulting from nervous system miswiring, and it has the potential to inform therapeutic approaches for neural circuit repair after physical injury or onset of neurodegenerative disease.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research addresses the molecular origins of female reproductive aging, which impacts fertility, endocrine function, and overall health. We will test the hypothesis that ovarian aging is fueled by damaged DNA in the oocyte which stimulates an inflammatory response in the surrounding somatic follicular cells that is further amplified by spatial cues within the broader microenvironment. This project provides a novel paradigm for female reproductive aging, a major reproductive transition, and thus aligns with NICHD priorities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
ORG_NAME: GRADUATE SCHOOL OF PUBLIC HEALTH AND HEALTH POLICY
PHR: Project Narrative Given parks’ importance for community engagement, vibrancy and wellbeing, we will implement a community engaged, human-centered design-driven intervention that empowers and capacitates stakeholders in  predominantly Black and Latino communities to design and implement health and social strategies in newly  renovated parks as a way to enhance the social environment of neighborhoods. We will determine the impact of  this intervention on community-level health-related quality of life and mental health. This innovative study will  inform new models of community engagement, community development and park-based programs and  policies to promote population wellbeing and reduce health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (PUBLIC HEALTH STATEMENT) Alcohol Use Disorder (AUD) often worsens Intimate Partner Violence (IPV) and both cause significant negative health impact. We propose to test a combination of two behavioral interventions, motivational interviewing (MI) and behavioral couples therapy (BCT), which were shown to be acceptable, feasible and have preliminary efficacy in our previous pilot study. If this larger study, delivered by primary care nurses, also shows that the intervention is effective, it can provide an effective, low-cost way to address the problems of IPV and AUD, both in the United States and globally.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Limb amputation leads to abnormal sensory-motor cortex reorganization, which is associated with phantom limb pain (PLP). Current therapies have aimed to restore organization in the motor cortex with little focus on sensory processing, which is also crucial for effective movement. Their efficacy remains unclear. We hypothesize that restoring somatosensory cortex organization will be vital in reducing PLP. Sensory loss correlates with a small or delayed evoked potential in brain signals recorded from the scalp. We will develop and test a novel noninvasive non-pharmacological therapy which works by training a person to increase their somatosensory evoked potentials. The potentials are elicited via the mirror effect, i.e., stimulating the intact limb while viewing it in a mirror, to evoke a sensation in the phantom limb. We expect that directly training these evoked potentials will help restore effective sensory organization for the missing limb and reduce PLP, beyond the extent now possible. Future studies will explore this approach in other chronic pain conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative We propose to leverage a suite of the BRAIN Initiative tools to investigate the effect of top-down brain signals that control high-level cognitive functions on noninvasive imaging readouts. These studies will be conducted in the context of spontaneous (“resting-state”) and task-induced brain activity under healthy conditions and intoxication with cocaine. This project will deliver a stronger physiological foundation for the interpretation of fMRI signals in healthy individuals, examine the effects of cocaine on neuronal and hemodynamic brain activity, and generate further hypotheses about the ways in which substance exposure may affect fMRI readouts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diseases related to pulmonary and critical care medicine (PCCM) remain among the leading causes of morbidity and mortality, nationally; however, recent advances in molecular and cellular biology, immunology, clinical intervention and biomedical informatics are unleashing the power of scientific discovery to impact health. The UCLA PCCM Training Program (PCCMTP) is dedicated to mentored, interdisciplinary team-based training of a new generation of academic and industry leaders in basic, translational and clinical research. By deploying facilities and resources of renowned multidisciplinary mentor faculty, we will fulfill the program mission of training a cadre of investigators who will discover novel underlying basic principles of PCCM-related diseases and translate these discoveries to improve health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) is a neuropsychiatric condition that causes enormous human suffering and cost to society. Our goal is to rapidly learn more about the genetics of this disorder and how genes and environment might act and interact to alter disease risk. We propose to do this by collecting a new, large, ancestrally-diverse and well-phenotyped sample of OCD cases followed by detailed genomic analyses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Visitation bans in nursing homes were a major policy intervention in response to the COVID-19 pandemic, yet there is limited knowledge regarding their effectiveness in COVID-19 prevention or the unintended adverse effects on residents and care practices in nursing homes. By analyzing unique visitation ban data at the state and facility level, this study will provide timely information on both the positive and negative effects of visitation bans, with a special focus on residents with Alzheimer's Disease & Related Dementias, which will help policymakers better understand the full impact of this controversial mitigation measure. This is especially policy- relevant currently, because many states have passed or are considering passing laws to ensure visitation rights among nursing home residents, even during a pandemic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) affects 30-60% of alcohol use disorder (AUD) treatment patients, and those AUD patients with comorbid PTSD have poorer treatment prognosis than those without PTSD. However, there are very few PTSD-focused treatments available for AUD patients with comorbid PTSD that may reduce their PTSD symptom burden and improve AUD treatment outcomes. This project aims to fill that gap by testing the impact of a novel mobile health application combined with brief clinical support (PTSD Coach app + brief support) compared to enhanced usual care (EUC) on PTSD and AUD recovery outcomes among patients with comorbid PTSD and AUD in residential addictions treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bacterial corneal infections (keratitis) caused by the bacteria Staphylococcus aureus often result in devastating, vision-threatening complications and significantly contributes to the burden of world blindness. Currently our ability to adequately treat this disease is limited by the lack of understanding of how S. aureus initiates and maintains infection in this unique biologic niche. This project addresses this knowledge gap through a novel, comprehensive approach for the identification and validation of the key bacterial drivers of S. aureus keratitis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: The autonomic nervous system innervates the pancreatic islet and thus helps regulate glucose metabolism, but little is known about the local mechanisms of how nerves control hormone secretion from pancreatic endocrine cells. In this project we will visualize, manipulate, and record from nerves that receive and send signals to the pancreas and test how these nerves impact pancreatic hormone secretion. The results will contribute to our basic understanding of how islet biology and glucose metabolism are influenced by autonomic nerves, which is important to guide pre-clinical neuromodulatory studies to improve islet function in diabetes.

This study aims to develop strategies to promote macrophage-mediated cancer immunosurveillance by breaking macrophage tolerance, and to determine the efficacy and molecular mechanisms of these strategies. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Chronic pain experienced by children has the potential to persist into adulthood and drive drug addiction, mental health problems and suicidal behavior. The level of pain reported by children who experience headache is immense and likely poorly estimated based on lowered ability of children to articulate symptoms, potential malingering or underreporting of pain symptoms, and extensive variability in physical growth and brain development. Headache is a frequently reported and poorly understood primary and secondary disorder in pediatric subjects. The diverse presentation of headache underscores the potential for distinct mechanisms of headache presentation, thus placing emphasis on tailored treatment options. In the proposed research program, we investigate four phenotypically distinct forms of headache in youth to understand the physiological mechanisms that govern their phenotypic presentation. Taking advantage of a highly diverse and specialized research team in headache research and clinical care, findings will greatly inform the diagnosis and treatment of childhood headache and reduce future pain-related dependencies on healthcare resources.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Protein-protein interactions are essential for all biological processes and are often misregulated in disease. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal, entitled Hk Maker Lab 2.0: Inspiring Engineering Design Thinking in Grades 6 – 12 Students and Teachers, focuses on giving middle and high school students opportunities to learn about engineering design and use design to devise solutions to open-ended problems; promotes engineering design thinking and content in the classroom by training middle and high school teachers in engineering design; and will form a cohort of master teachers, who are adept in design and can impart concepts to their fellow teachers. The role of engineering in public health has been made abundantly clear by the COVID-19 pandemic and the associated technical and medical problems that engineers have been called upon to help solve, which demand the skills of a diverse workforce that can creatively meet technical challenges while providing varied views on problems. This project will directly support the development of a diverse, representative, and resilient engineering workforce that will be prepared to solve the most pressing issues in public health and medicine.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cellular metabolism is crucial for maintaining energy and whole-body energy homeostasis. A deeper knowledge of lipid metabolism will provide new biomarkers and targets to improve energetic function in skeletal muscle and metabolic homeostasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The proposed MARC at the University of Nevada, Reno (MARC at UNR) will support diverse UNR College of Science trainees by providing an Enrichment Program that will prepare them for predoctoral graduate studies in biomedical or behavioral research. The proposed Enrichment Program includes two and a half years of mentored research, hands-on training in laboratory safety, weekly seminar/discussion classes providing peer support in the preparation of applications for summer research, for NSF Graduate Research Fellowship Program (GRFP), and for predoctoral graduate training. The MARC at UNR will also support the trainees with two years of formal career development mentoring using a Matrix Mentoring Model (Self, Senior, Scientific, Peer, and Staff mentoring).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: RESEARCH INST OF FOX CHASE CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreatic Cancer is far from being the most common cancer in the USA, yet it is projected to become the second deadliest (following lung cancer) by the year 2026 and no effective therapies are available to treat this cancer. This study will identify possible routes to restore the naturally protective activity of stromal cells that neighbor pancreatic tumors, which could prevent or delay the development and progression of Pancreatic Cancer. Further, results from the study will indicate whether the proposed “stroma normalization” could be informed by systemically in patients (i.e., in blood).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Underrepresented minorities are less likely to receive independent investigator awards from the National Institutes of Health. The result is a non-diversified workforce and less emphasis on diabetes-related health disparities research. The current study (called LAUNCHED) is designed to provide underrepresented minorities with a tailored training program to increase the chance of receiving diabetes, obesity, and/or nutrition funding.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Experimental cognitive tests developed as part of the NIMH Research Domain Criteria (RDoC) initiative are liable to psychometric challenges that lead to inconsistent measurement precision, weakened effect size, and confounds in brain imaging research. This project evaluates a novel adaptive testing methodology designed to address these challenges. Products will include computerized adaptive measures of RDoC learning, control, and memory domains for use in experimental and translational studies, as well as a free and open-source programming (R) package, ‘catCog’, designed to implement the methodology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this program is to train the next generation of nurse scientists who will conduct research toward ending the HIV epidemic, while considering behavioral, socio-structural, and biomedical factors that cause disparities in HIV prevention and treatment. A group of 28 interdisciplinary faculty members with extensive HIV research experience will provide mentoring in research methods and HIV content for the four predoctoral and two postdoctoral scholars each year. This training program will advance knowledge to help end the HIV epidemic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Emphysema is a significant chronic disease with substantial morbidity and mortality and is resistant to most therapies because it is caused by irreversible anatomic destruction. Not much is known about the effects of sex differences on cellular abnormalities in emphysematous damage. Therefore, our proposal can provide critical information to assess the risk, identify the disease processes, and help develop strategies to mitigate and treat emphysema tailored with consideration for sex differences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal is to improve mental health of minority and other vulnerable populations disproportionately affected by COVID-19. In addition, we will evaluate the impact of mental health services on COVID-19 mitigation strategies such as prevention behaviors, receiving vaccinations, and safe healthcare utilization. Successful completion of this study will contribute to the NIMH Strategic Plan employing implementation science to maximize the public health impact of research for effectiveness and reach of mental health services, especially for minority groups and other underserved populations in the United States.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The Botswana CASCADE Clinical Trials Site will study strategies for preventing cervical cancer in women living with HIV. Cervical cancer is the leading cause of death for women on HIV treatment in Botswana and current approaches have not succeeded in reaching population with effective preventative services. Studies to be conducted will focus on strategies to improve access to screening, effectiveness of cervical screening, and access and treatment effectiveness of identified precancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research program focuses on the efficient chemical synthesis of structurally complex and biologically active diterpenoid natural products. The chemistry that underpins all of this work takes advantage of the inherently high chemoselectivity of modern radical chemistry, and involves two major strategic innovations: 1. cobalt-catalyzed, MHAT-induced radical polycyclizations, and 2. novel applications of hydrazones in radical bicyclizations. We leverage these key strategies to arrive at complex diterpene targets via sequences that are dramatically shorter than the state-of-the-art, and that permit collaborative biological studies in the antiviral, antibacterial, and immunosuppressive areas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is a critical congenital heart disease that affects about 1 in 2520 babies born in the US each year, and frequently requires lifesaving surgery within the first year of life and valve replacement. Due to the characteristic blood flow dynamics in TOF, fetal semilunar heart valves and their supporting structures are susceptible to flow-induced prenatal pathophysiological remodeling that alters deposition of important constituents (such as collagen and elastin) in valve leaflets, impacting their competence. Using in vivo echocardiography and correlative multiscale imaging, as well as computational and mathematical modeling, this project will establish predictive relationships between abnormal blood flow in fetal TOF and detrimental remodeling of valves, ultimately guiding lifesaving treatment strategies for babies with TOF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The Boston University Summer Institute for Research Education in Biostatistics and Data Science (BU SIBS) is a five-week in-residence program, followed by a period of continued remote research, designed to build skills and to interest undergraduates, recent graduates and early graduate students in the many exciting opportunities in the field of Biostatistics. The trainees’ future role in public health will be enhanced due to their early exposure to the foundations of biostatistical analysis, epidemiological analysis, infectious disease modeling, design and analysis of clinical trials and statistical genetics analysis within a data science framework.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Program Narrative Pregnancy is associated with a striking increase of uterine blood flow that is essential for normal fetal development as well as for cardiovascular well-being of the mother. Hypoxia during pregnancy has profound adverse effects on uterine artery hemodynamics adaptation, increasing incidence of pregnancy complications of preeclampsia and fetal intrauterine growth restriction. Yet, much remains unknown of the mechanisms underlying maternal cardiovascular adaptation to chronic hypoxia during pregnancy. Scientifically, the proposed study will augment our understanding of basic mechanisms whereby maternal cardiovascular system adapts to pregnancy and gestational hypoxia. From a clinical standpoint, the study will provide new insights and suggest new directions in the management of pregnancy complications and abnormal fetal development associated with gestational hypoxia, thereby reducing perinatal morbidity and mortality while improving maternal health and neonatal outcome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A necessary step in the development of improved OUD therapeutics is to understand the architecture and function of endogenous opioid receptor-expressing neural circuits in the brain. Despite extensive research, how these circuits maintain cellular dependence and drive brain-wide maladaptive plasticity across different stages of the addiction cycle is unclear. To address these gaps, we will map the global cell-type identity, shifting connectivity, and ensemble activity of the opioidergic networks throughout various stages of addiction. Our team-driven project will create an integrated, rapidly searchable database to be mined by other researchers to accelerate the pace of OUD research and future development of new OUD treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE At least 50% of US adults over the age of 45 have missing teeth; however, over 70% of patients must first undergo a ridge augmentation procedure to provide adequate bony structure to accept implant placement. Most dentists remain dissatisfied with existing bone grafts due to their challenging handling properties and poor predictability that often require a secondary augmentation procedure. The proposed project aims to demonstrate through translational animal testing how a novel regenerative bone adhesive scaffold can accelerate volume preserving bone regeneration in patients seeking treatment with residual ridge resorption.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: Defects in cranial neural crest development lead to a variety of craniofacial diseases and malformations affecting the face, e.g. Treacher Collins syndrome, DiGeorge syndrome, and cleft palate to name a few. In this project, I will investigate the regulation and mechanism of function of the secreted protein Draxin, which will significantly enhance our understanding of the regulation of cranial neural crest delamination and migration, providing new scientific avenues for translational research applications in the treatment of craniofacial defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The control of energy balance depends on the interplay of a myriad of central and peripheral signals that ultimately lead to the maintenance of energetic homeostasis. Lately, the reproductive neurotransmitter kisspeptin, produced in Kiss1 neurons, has emerged as a novel metabolic signal although its mechanism of action remains ill-defined. We have observed that Kiss1 neurons mediate the regulation of energy expenditure exerted by melanocortins, therefore, understanding the neuroanatomical underpinnings of the melanocortin-kisspeptin action on energy balance is the overarching goal of this proposal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal will provide Dr. Maverakis support to continue to mentor young clinical investigators from various backgrounds in patient-oriented research, especially on projects involving “omic” datasets. Dr. Maverakis' research is focused on using genetic and glycomic datasets to construct diagnostic and predictive classifiers to identify patients who will: experience a progression in disease severity, respond to a particular therapy, or develop an associated disease. In addition, Dr. Maverakis proposes to augment his current patient- oriented-research by designing and conducting early stage clinical studies to explore novel treatments and their biomechanisms.

PHR: Project Narrative This study seeks to better understand chronic pain in older adults by conducting a national survey of adults >65 years of age. The survey will determine the prevalence of chronic pain, describe the nature of chronic pain, and examine what biological, psychological and social factors contribute to chronic pain in older adults. The survey will compare those with and without chronic pain and describe over 12 months how chronic pain affects physical function, cognitive function and quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Project Narrative The Texas Experimental Cancer Therapeutic Network (TEX-CTN) will leverage the strengths of  the four UT institutions, to rationally design individualized novel cancer therapeutics through  testing within molecularly profiled populations, integrating pharmacodynamic markers in early  clinical trials, and programmatic assessment of predictors of intrinsic sensitivity/resistance and  mechanisms of acquired resistance. The TEX-CTN also is uniquely positioned to offer  participation to patients who have been traditionally underrepresented in innovative early phase  clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is a prevalent and progressive obstructive lung disease caused by cigarette smoke exposure with few effective therapies. The role of mitochondrial dysfunction and cellular senescence, a state of cell arrest, in COPD pathogenesis remain unknown and an area of high scientific interest. This work will define how adenine nucleotide translocase (ANT2), a mitochondrial ADP/ATP translocase, influences mitochondrial dysfunction that drives cellular senescence and abnormal repair of the lung epithelium, thus opening the potential for ANT as a therapeutic target for COPD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: In cancer, tumor inflammation plays a multifaceted role in disease progression and response to therapies. The ability to non-invasively image tumor inflammation would greatly enhance our ability to stratify patients for treatments. This project will develop and characterize novel diagnostic imaging radiopharmaceutical agents that enable sensitive and precise quantification of tumor inflammation in vivo.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Novel Metabolic Actions of GIP Project Narrative:  The incretin system is strategically positioned to control metabolism in the postprandial state and people with type 2 diabetes have severe impairments in the incretin axis. Heretofore, the incretin system has been viewed primarily within a glucose context and incretin action has been studied almost exclusively in b-cells. Our preliminary data demonstrates that a-cells and glucagon are significant contributors to the incretin axis and that GIP is a crucial determinant of this novel mechanism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS), a form of critical illness characterized by lung inflammation and severe hypoxia, is common and frequently leads to delirium. This proposal seeks to understand how fragments of sugars are released into the bloodstream from the blood vessels of the lung during ARDS and how these sugars cause hyperactivity of the brain during ARDS. It will then determine if brain hyperactivity caused by these sugars plays a role in delirium during ARDS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Title: Novel predictors of survival among breast cancer patients with/without HIV in South Africa Breast cancer incidence and mortality rates of breast cancer are rising in regions with high HIV prevalence. No prior large-scale multicenter, multiethnic prospective study has evaluated the impacts of HIV and ART on breast cancer outcomes in sub-Saharan Africa. These analyses will contribute to the development of evidence-based guidelines for breast cancer management among women with HIV and will yield new insights into both HIV and breast cancer

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Human papillomaviruses multiply when infected epithelial cells undergo differentiation and viral genome synthesis occurs at sites of cellular DNA damage. This proposal investigates how an RNA that does not code for a protein, and which is upregulated during epithelial cell differentiation and induces DNA damage regulates papillomavirus multiplication and if it may serve as a potential antiviral target.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Delirium is common in hospitalized older adults, leads to poor outcomes such as functional and cognitive decline, nursing home placement, and death, yet over half of delirium is unrecognized. Our current Aims will study implementation of daily nurse-led delirium screening using the Ultra-brief Confusion Assessment Method into routine care among all hospitalized older adults. Our findings will directly inform best practices for delirium identification, including in vulnerable individuals such as those with Alzheimer’s Disease and Alzheimer’s Disease Related Dementias.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Non-responsiveness (i.e., tolerance) to one’s own tissues is essential to prevent autoimmune disease. In some individuals, tolerance breaks down and the immune system destroys one’s own red blood cells; this can be fatal as these cells are required for life. This proposal will identify which pathways and T cell subsets are required for tolerance to one’s own red blood cells, and define how age and sex modify those requirements.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Anemia is a frequent complication of inflammatory diseases marked by dysregulated iron homeostasis. Inflammation-associated anemia is often refractory to treatment, and we lack a basic understanding of how inflammation and anemia influence each other. The focus of this proposal is to define the role of a novel immune-mediated pathway of iron regulation in the course and resolution of diseases involving inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative About 20% of US young adults have high blood pressure (BP), however, the optimal BP screening and treatment strategies in young adults are unknown. Many young adults are not aware of their high BP, and are not recommended for BP lowering medication, partly due to the lack of evidence. The overall goal of this study is to determine the optimal BP screening intervals and identify subgroups of young adults with high cardiovascular risk who may benefit most from BP lowering medications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Surface attached microbial communities, called biofilms, cause significant problems in environmental, industrial, and clinical settings. Vibrio cholerae, which causes the disease cholera, forms biofilms that are critical to its environmental survival, transmission, and infectivity. This research will improve our understanding of biofilm formation and biofilm-mediated hyperinfectivity, define targets to combat this deadly pathogen in both intestinal and aquatic ecosystems, and help develop tools for prediction and control of cholera epidemics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Liver transplantation (LT) is the only curative treatment for patients with cirrhosis, and racial/ethnic disparities exist regarding whom is placed on the waitlist for this lifesaving organ. Dr. Strauss will develop a data-driven and equity-focused intervention that will improve objectivity in team decision-making for LT listing. By focusing on this critical point of the LT process, more patients from vulnerable populations will have access to the waitlist and transplantation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative There is an urgent need to develop a deeper understanding of the neural basis of depression, given its tremendous societal impact. Previous work has been hampered by imprecise neurophysiological recordings and analysis methods that are difficult to generalize. Here, we leverage access to intracranial recording and stimulation studies in participants across a range of depression severity, along with novel explainable AI (XAI) tools, to shed light on this complex brain-behavior relationship, with the hope that a deeper understanding of the neural basis of depression will produce opportunities for improved therapies for this debilitating disorder.

PHR: Project Narrative It remains unknown how cells in the body detect water content, a key step for maintaining water balance critical for all terrestrial life. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative In many global settings, key populations are more likely to be infected with HIV, but less likely to be virally suppressed than members of the general population living with HIV and research shows that this is at least partly due to the multiple stigmas that act as barriers to care-seeking, prescription refills and consistent consumption of their medications. The proposed study seeks to address this problem by adapting and pilot testing a culturally appropriate, comprehensive wellness program that incorporates peer navigation and is based on our previous work in India and South Africa, to improve engagement in HIV care among men who have sex with men and transgender women in India. If successful, the proposed low-cost strategies, tailored to the needs of sexual minorities, can improve both the health of the participants, decrease the likelihood of HIV transmission to their uninfected sex partners and be adapted for use in other global settings including the US.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Peripheral artery disease (PAD) is a common and highly morbid condition that is a major cause of disability and associated with a high risk of heart attack, stroke and death. We propose to develop a large cohort of PAD patients identified using a novel method and follow them over time to better understand the trajectory of survival and clinical outcomes in these patients, assess the impact of existing treatments on patient outcomes and uncover racial disparities in care and outcomes. Our work will advance PAD research and provide important insights regarding how best to improve PAD care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The overall goal of this proposal is to use AAV liver gene therapy for the treatment of hemophilia A (FVIII deficiency) complicated inhibitory antibodies to FVIII; to this end, we will use novel canine models of severe hemophilia A that develop robust high-responding immune responses to canine FVIII. Unique to this approach is that after eradication of inhibitors and induction of immune tolerance, AAV-mediated continuous expression of FVIII will also improve the disease bleeding phenotype. The success of this approach will support this strategy for applications in hemophilia with inhibitors, the most challenging clinical scenario, and other diseases complicated by the development of neutralizing antibodies to the therapeutic protein.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal seeks to understand mechanisms that contribute to the aggressive behavior of advanced prostate cancers and to use the information obtained to improve therapy. The specific focus is neuropilin-2, a receptor for vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) on tumors that promotes chemoresistance and immune evasion. Therapeutic targeting of NRP2 has the potential to reduce the morbidity and mortality associated with advanced prostate cancers by increasing chemosensitivity and immune cell killing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Malaria is a life-threatening disease that is caused by infection from Plasmodium parasites. Resolving pathways critical to both the liver and blood stages of Plasmodium infection, such as ones that involve heat shock proteins, is critical to aid in malaria control. This project will investigate the role of heat shock proteins 90 and 70 in Plasmodium infection to advance knowledge of essential parasite processes and aid in the pursuit of novel therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There are few active antibiotics against Gram-negative bacteria due to the presence of the outer membrane surrounding these pathogens, which creates a major barrier for the penetration of small molecules. We propose to develop an innovative framework to understand antibiotic penetration and establish a metabolic labeling assay to measure outer membrane penetration that is uncoupled from inhibitory activity. Ultimately, our tools can be applied to various pathogens and to design better antibiotics for the treatment of human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Diabetes and its renal complications are becoming epidemic in the U.S. population. The central hypothesis of this proposal is that concentrations of agonists of protease-activated receptors (PARs) are increased under diabetic nephropathy conditions. Thus, the identification of mechanisms for the regulation of calcium flux in podocytes by PAR agonists, especially under pathological conditions, has clear clinical significance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Polygenic risk scores (PRS) combine genetic information across an individual’s genome to predict risk of disease. We believe that by using rare genetic variants, along with clinical, environmental, and social risk factors in addition to the PRS, we can improve the ability to predict an individual’s risk of disease. We will test our novel translational informatics methods on three types of cardiovascular disease. Using this approach for early screening will allow for the development of prevention strategies and reduction of cardiovascular morbidity and mortality.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adoption and use of mobile devices have each grown exponentially in the last decade and mounting evidence suggests that mobile devices may uniquely interfere with a parent’s ability to sensitively respond to their child’s cues. These sensitive interactions are especially important in infancy and for low-income families, creating the foundations for social-emotional development that last a lifetime. This proposal seeks to address gaps in knowledge by understanding how first-time, low-income mothers use mobile devices, and the potential associations of mobile device use with maternal wellbeing, infant regulation, and maternal-infant co-regulation, in order to ultimately promote the health of children in infancy and beyond.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cytochrome P450 (CYP) 11B1 and 11B2 synthesize cortisol and aldosterone respectively, with excesses resulting in Cushing’s disease and primary aldosteronism. Drug treatments for each disease are limited due to poor drug selectivity resulting from the high similarity between these enzymes. This proposal aims to define differences between CYP11B1 and CYP11B2 active sites and interactions with common redox partner adrenodoxin, advances that may facilitate more effective drug design.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Preeclampsia is a devastating cardiovascular disease in pregnancy and despite decades of research the reasons that pregnant women develop preeclampsia are not well-understood and treatment options are limited. Clinical studies have long identified that the hormone leptin inappropriately increases in preeclampsia, and we recently showed that leptin induces hypertension, vascular dysfunction and adverse fetal outcomes, the characteristics of preeclampsia, in pregnant mice. The focus of our studies will be to understand why leptin increases in preeclampsia, and also, to investigate the vascular, placental and endocrine mechanisms via which leptin causes the adverse cardiovascular and fetal outcomes of preeclampsia, which may lead to better clinical therapeutics for this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Narrative. SOURCE (SPIROMICS Study of Early COPD Progression) is an NHLBI funded study of the early manifestations of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) in young (30-55 years) individuals. Based on the knowledge that the small airway epithelium (SAE) is the earliest site of pathology of COPD, the focus of this ancillary proposal is to characterize the disordered biology associated with SAE differentiation in a subset of 100 SOURCE participants and correlate this dysfunction with the abnormal early COPD small airway phenotypes characterized in SOURCE. The goal is to identify biologic processes in the pathogenesis of the airway abnormalities in early COPD that could serve as future targets for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROTOCOL NARRATIVE The Makerere University Walter Reed Project (MUWRP) in partnership with the U.S. Military HIV Research Program (MHRP) proposes to implement CASCADE clinical trials in central Uganda as a UG1 Clinical Research Site. Leveraging MUWRP’s clinical research experience, resources and pluripotent infrastructure and resources, as well as MUWRP’s Comprehensive HIV/AIDS Prevention, Care and Treatment in Central Uganda (CARE) program; funded by U.S. President’s Emergency Plan For AIDS Relief (PEPFAR); MUWRP and MHRP investigators will: 1) support UG1 Research Bases to develop concepts and protocols by providing insight and input in study feasibility, clinical significance (with a local context), 2) efficiently accrue and retain participants for all clinical trials; and 3) provide operational leadership to clinical and research staff implementing protocols at selected study sites in Uganda. CASCADE clinical trials and activities conducted by MUWRP and MHRP (entitled ‘Implementing HIV/Cervical Cancer Prevention ‘CASCADE’ Clinical Trials in Uganda (CASCADE-UGANDA)) will generate invaluable evidence for novel interventions for CXCA screening and precancer treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Metabolic liver disease, affecting one in four adults in the U.S. and up to 75% of obese individuals, includes nonalcoholic fatty liver (NAFL), where lipid deposition accounts for more than 5~10% of the liver’s weight, nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), where the liver develops inflammation and fibrosis, and insulin resistance. Our project focuses on liver-resident immune cells and their release of proteins that play a major role in metabolic liver disease, presenting an exciting new idea that interferon-γ signaling in liver macrophages and their release of pro-inflammatory cytokine interleukin-12 regulate insulin resistance in the liver and other surrounding cells during the NAFL progression to NASH. The long-term goal of our research is to understand the role of macrophages and cytokines in the pathogenesis of NAFL and NASH and identify new therapeutic targets to treat metabolic liver disease in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: The overarching mission of the Center for Social Capital (SoCa) is to bring together academic institutions, community-based organizations, and a diverse group of stakeholders to reduce cancer health inequities due to persistent poverty in New York City (NYC) by promoting multi-generational health. We will conduct two complementary projects that focus on novel interventions in persistent poverty communities aimed at two structural determinants of health—education and health care—in which the interventions aim to increase social capital among youth in school settings, and patient navigators in Federally Qualified Health Centers as a means to alleviate systemic inequities The SoCa Center will leverage capacity across geographically separate groups of persistent poverty census tracts in NYC to cultivate the next generation of investigators and develop sustainable Core infrastructure to achieve cancer health equity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: NARRATIVE – OVERALL DESCRIPTION In this Program Project, we will investigate the role of trained immunity in transplantation and allograft rejection. Our preliminary clinical and preclinical data reveal a direct and causal link between allotransplantation, the induction of trained immunity, a systemic inflammatory response, and the aggravation of T cell-mediated alloimmunity. The successful completion of this application will lend support to (i) the concept that trained immunity plays an essential role in organ transplantation and graft rejection and (ii) yield effective preclinical nanotherapies and imaging approaches to treat and study graft rejection, and (iii) new hypothesis, setting the stage for future studies, including those aimed at clinically translating our findings and technologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Craniofacial birth defects are extremely common due to the complexity of craniofacial development. We will characterize how multifactorial interactions between genetics and the environment disrupt the cell signaling interactions that drive the integration of the distinct cell types with the vertebrate head. The results we obtain will translate directly to human disease, providing candidate loci for association studies, risk factors for genetic counseling and potential therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: We have derived a novel in-vitro colon organoids model to explore the hypothesis that age-dependent risk for initiation of colorectal cancers (CRC) depends upon abnormal DNA methylation and associated gene silencing. We have determined that gene silencing is functional for driving the aging-like changes and accelerating one- step transformation of older cells to cancer notably by BRAF mutations. A key ultra-translational possibility addressed in this proposal is that reversing these methylation changes and gene silencing might significantly diminish CRC risk and enhance biomarker approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this secondary data analysis proposal, we will address critical and timely questions about effects of social inequality on the brain and on substance use. We leverage existing datasets from the Adolescent Brain Cognitive Development (ABCD) study and the Minnesota Center for Twin and Family Research (MCTFR) to identify neurobehavioral deviations linking childhood socioeconomic disadvantage and substance use trajectories in adolescence and adulthood. Identifying individuals and families at the greatest risk for problematic substance use trajectories informs development of the most targeted prevention and intervention efforts possible for substance misuse and use disorder.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The UCSF Department of Surgery's T32 training grant titled “Filling a Void of Research Training for Transplant Surgeons” (FAVOR) will provide two years of funding for in-depth training in translational immunology for 2 surgery residents/year with an interest in transplant surgery, to prepare them for careers as academic transplant surgeons. The goal of the FAVOR T32 is to train and inspire a unique cadre of surgeon-scientists to translate astute observations at the bedside, in the operating room, and in the clinic into novel hypotheses that can be interrogated through immunology-focused translational research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Principal Investigator/Program Director (Last, First, Middle): Byrd, Lamont FOA Number RFA-ES-19-003 Project Narrative (Overall) The IBT Consortium represents and has ready access to tens of thousands of workers throughout the U.S. who remediate hazardous waste sites, transport hazardous wastes, handle, package, transport and warehouse hazardous materials, and respond to hazardous materials releases. The IBT Consortium is staffed by a team of experienced worker health and safety training experts who specialize in industrial hygiene, curriculum development, adult education techniques, information technology, and craft-experienced worker-trainers. The combination of access to worker populations and institutional capacities enables the IBT Consortium to deliver high quality model training that complies with the NIEHS Minimum Criteria, applicable standards and regulations as promulgated by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), and the Department of Homeland Security (DHS). IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Platelets have emerged as effector cells capable of mediating inflammation either directly or through interactions with other immune cells or the vasculature. Platelet dysfunction correlates with disease severity in many inflammatory disorders including cardiovascular disease, sepsis, atherosclerosis, and inflammatory bowel disease. The research proposed is highly relevant to public health as the mechanisms through which platelets regulate inflammation and inflammation-associated thrombosis are not well understood and therefore necessitate further study to develop improved therapies to enhance human life and wellness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: LOUISIANA STATE UNIV A&M COL BATON ROUGE
PHR: Project Narrative Cannabis misuse among Black individuals in the United States poses a major public health concern. The proposed research uses ecological momentary assessment to strive to better understand antecedents of cannabis use motivation and cannabis use and related problems among this population by examining racial/ethnic microaggressions (MAs) – brief, subtle, yet common forms of everyday discrimination due to racial/ethnic status – that may prompt Black individuals to be more motivated to use cannabis to mitigate MA- related negative affect and engage in risky patterns of cannabis use. Through this research, we also will explore mediational processes and moderators in the link between MA and cannabis use and related problems that will inform future intervention and prevention efforts for this neglected health disparities group.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Astrocytes are highly elaborate cells that are key regulators of brain development, function, and maintenance, and astrocyte dysfunction results in devastating neurological conditions. We propose to dissect a novel, evolutionarily conserved pathway that is required for normal astrocyte growth and brain function. Our work will define fundamental cellular mechanisms that control astrocyte development, their contributions to brain health and function, and should provide critical insights into our understanding of astrocyte dysfunction in human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcohol addiction is a debilitating disorder characterized by long-term changes in brain function that underlie pathological drinking behaviors. Diagnostic criteria for alcohol addiction consistently identify continued alcohol drinking behaviors at the expense of healthy alternative rewards, and continued use despite adverse consequences (“compulsivity”) as key features. We demonstrate that epigenetic enzymes, known to mediate long-term changes in brain function, are associated with individual vulnerability to developing compulsivity. The goal of the proposed studies is to determine the mechanisms by which these epigenetic enzymes reprogram the brain for alcohol disorder, knowledge that may ultimately lead to novel therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Appropriate regulation of chromatin structure and gene expression is critical for normal synaptic plasticity, and this regulation is markedly disrupted in pathological substance use disorders. Our laboratory has found that metabolites that act as key cofactors for chromatin modifying enzymes are markedly altered by drugs of abuse. These studies will identify mechanistically how metabolites and their interactions with chromatin modifying enzymes affect brain and behavior and will provide strategies for targeting the metabolome to reduce pathological drug use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Kidney electrolyte handling in females vs males over life cycle Dysregulation of fluid and electrolyte transport in the kidney is central to hypertension and cardiovascular disease progression, which are leading contributors to premature death around the globe. Na+, K+, and volume homeostasis are mediated by regulation of ion and water transporters expressed in renal tubule specific patterns; K+ balance also depends on regulation of muscle transporters. By combining experimental and computational approaches in rodents, this MPI project aims to fill important gaps in knowledge about how male and female nephrons and muscles adjust operation over life cycle to maintain electrolyte homeostasis and blood pressure in response to the challenges of development, lactation, menopause, aging, and dietary salts, knowledge that can guide the appropriate choice of therapeutic targets in both sexes across life cycle.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE-PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (FAP) is an incurable autosomal dominant genetic disease afflicting some 50,000 Americans. Hundreds to thousands of adenomas develop in the rectum and colon, forcing colectomy usually in the second decade of life, to avoid colorectal cancer. This Phase IIb proposal seeks to further the development of an oral formulation of the key regulatory cytokine interleukin-10 (IL-10NanoCap®) as a novel therapy for FAP than can safely, sustainable and conveniently deliver this potent immune signal directly to the gut.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The solid tumor microenvironment includes nerve fibers arising from the peripheral nervous system. The formation of new nerve fibers within and around solid tumors plays an active role in cancer development, progression and resistance to treatment. This proposal will explore the exact mechanisms that drive nerves to infiltrate tumors and support their growth and progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Narrative – Miami Center for AIDS Research The Miami Center for AIDS Research (CFAR) at the University of Miami Miller School of Medicine is applying for funding for 5 more years, representing a 4th renewal cycle. It is the only CFAR in Florida, a state with the highest rate of new infections in the U.S., and Miami is the epicenter of the HIV/AIDS epidemic, underscoring the need for a CFAR. The mission of the Miami CFAR is to advance HIV/AIDS research by providing scientific leadership and developing an infrastructure that fosters integration of basic, clinical, and behavioral/social sciences, promotes education and mentorship, and partners with the community and Florida Department of Health to prevent, treat and cure HIV/AIDS, ultimately to end the HIV epidemic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Our recent works with drugs which oppose glucagon action demonstrate effective lowering of blood glucose in animal models of type 1 diabetes with an unexpected and profound increase in insulin-producing beta cells. As such, suppressing glucagon production or action on target tissues (which include the liver and the beta cell) may be a viable target area for the treatment and prevention of Type 1 diabetes. Here we evaluate the ability of glucagon blockade to improve beta cell regeneration, the source of new beta cells, and the tissue-to-tissue communication which triggers the regeneration of beta cells in mouse models of T1D and human islets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARATIVE It has been hypothesized that insect immune responses can be harnessed to control the spread of vector-borne diseases. Although fleas transmit numerous deadly and debilitating diseases to humans, relatively little is known about how they defend themselves from infection under natural conditions. The proposed research aims to address basic entomological questions related to flea ecological immunology, which could aid in the development of novel control strategies for flea-borne diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Microbial interactions play key roles in maintenance of diverse ecosystems and imbalance in microbial community structure negatively impacts human health. Understanding of microbial mechanisms underlying their ability to sense and respond to competition as well as alliance will allow researchers to engineer these abilities to promote health. By using innovative and multidisciplinary approaches, we will identify and discovery new natural products that mediate niche-specific microbial interactions at the molecular, genomic, and gene expression level.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Microglial cells, which are key components of the neuroinflammatory response to neuronal injury, are thought to be important mediators of retinal ganglion cell viability in glaucoma. In this application, we will critically test the importance microglia in glaucoma; furthermore, we will use advanced RNA sequencing technology to determine if there are different states of microglia—ones that are potentially beneficial or detrimental to retinal ganglion cell survival. Together, these data will determine if targeting microglial activation is a potential treatment for glaucoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative: Pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) is a rare and incurable disease, and PAH-afflicted patients die of heart failure within 5 years of diagnosis. To understand the disease and to develop therapies for PAH, scientists currently use various animal models or cells collected from patients, but these approaches have significant limitations. We recently developed a new PAH model by growing human PAH-afflicted cells in a miniaturized fluidic device, called PAH-on-a-chip. However, our prototype model cannot yet be mass-produced and made available to other researchers working on PAH who would benefit from this advanced tool. Here, we propose a way to scale up the chip fabrication process for mass production and then validate the mass-produced chips so researchers anywhere can use our device as an advantageous alternative to animal models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative p53 tumor suppressor is the most frequently mutated protein in cancer, and p53 mutation inactivates its tumor suppressor functions and/or endows oncogenic functions. Our project is relevant to public health, because it seeks to elucidate a cellular mechanism that restores the tumor suppressor functions of p53 mutants in cancer cells, which may break new ground for cancer treatment. The proposed research is relevant to the part of NCI’s mission that pertains to accelerating scientific discovery to reduce the burden of cancer and suffering of cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Recent reports suggest that exposure to alcohol-related content on popular social media (SM) platforms, such as Instagram and Snapchat, can undermine commonly used college drinking norms intervention strategies not originally intended to address the onslaught of peer generated alcohol content available on these platforms. The proposed intervention strategy innovatively utilizes ads on these SM sites to introduce a microtargeted gamified normative re-education campaign that not only has the potential to mitigate risks associated with SM-related alcohol exposure, but also reduce the cost and increase the reach of this type of normative re-education program. Over the next three years, we will develop and program an innovative, engaging, interactive, and culturally relevant gamified social norms marketing campaign (2 College Truths & 1 Lie) for first-year students during the transition into college (Phase 1) and conduct a pilot trial to evaluate the feasibility and efficacy of the program (Phase 2).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE More than half of low-income older adults (LOA) have maladaptive fall risk appraisal (a discrepancy between perceived fall risk versus physiological fall risk), which is a known contributor to decreased physical activity and no published study has evaluated interventions to help shift LOA with maladaptive fall risk appraisal to its healthy counterpart—adaptive (realistic) fall risk appraisal. We developed a technology-based, individualized, in-home Physio-fEedback Exercise pRogram (PEER), which includes a) physio-feedback using a real-time portable innovative technology—the BTrackS Balance System; b) cognitive reframing based on a novel fall risk appraisal matrix; and c) peer-led exercise by focusing on balance and strength training. The purposes of this clustered randomized controlled trial study are thus to: 1) examine the effects of the technology-based PEER intervention on fall risk reduction, dynamic balance and accelerometer-based physical activity; 2) examine the effects of the PEER intervention on fall risk appraisal shifting and negative self-perceptions of aging; and 3) explore participants’ experiences with the PEER intervention and potential barriers to access and adoption of the technology-based PEER intervention to inform future research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The Program Project application consists of three projects, each directed by an independent and productive investigator and with a longstanding track record of collaborations to study an important class of cell surface receptors, the integrins. The function of integrins in blood and vascular cells and the regulation of their activities and the signaling will be investigated. The information derived from these proposed studies will provide insights into the complex and biologically important responses regulated by integrins and are relevant to thrombosis, atherosclerosis and other vascular pathologies.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE Over 100,000 women in the United States undergo mastectomy procedures each year due to breast cancer, resulting in total loss of breast tissue. One of the key traits of a patient's breast tissue that is often neglected in reconstruction is the nipple areolar complex, and currently there is no clinically viable solution for its reconstruction or regeneration. The long-term goal of this work is to develop a personalized, bioresorbable nipple areolar complex that will provide patients with the shape of a native nipple projection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative  Real-time quaking induced conversion (RT-QuIC) assays for alpha-synuclein and tau seeds can improve diagnostic accuracy for Lewy body diseases (LBD: Parkinson’s disease, dementia with Lewy bodies) and Alzheimer’s disease (AD), but its full utility has not been elucidated. Identifying the ability of RT-QuIC to detect the presence of clinically meaningful co-pathologies and the correlation of RT-QuIC metrics with histopathologic burden and cognitive performance will allow for the comprehensive molecular characterization of LBD and AD patients during life and potentially provide a biomarker of disease activity allowing for improved clinical trial design. Here I propose to utilize existing cohorts of autopsy confirmed LBD and AD cases with antemortem CSF and/or cognitive testing to investigate the association between alpha-synuclein and tau RT-QuIC with histopathological burden and cognitive dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Pseudomonas aeruginosa (Pa) causes an array of infections that lead to high health care costs and mortality rates. In infections, Pa is frequently in microoxic environments, but how it survives and thrives in microoxia has not been well described. We propose to leverage thousands of Pa transcriptome datasets that are available in public repositories to discover novel Pa microoxic fitness factors, which may be promising therapeutic targets, and to find conditions in which these factors can be most easily studied.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer's disease and related dementias (ADRD) are a major public health problem, and our current diagnostic approach for biomarker confirmation of the disease does not meet the clinical need due to challenges with cost, invasiveness, and availability. This project will investigate the utility of several new blood tests for Alzheimer's disease as diagnostic screening tools in a population that represents the full spectrum of neurodegenerative diseases seen in the clinic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The rise in the aging population and the global epidemic of obesity and diabetes will dramatically increase the prevelence of diabetic kidney disease, the most common cause of kidney failure in the United States. Novel interventions that reduce cellular senescence abundance and sterile inflammation, such as senolytics and extracellular vesicles, may alter the trajectory of this resistant disease and improve healthy lifespan. The proposed studies will 1) examine mechanisms by which extracellular vesicles affect injurious senescence and inflammation pathways, 2) test the kidney repair effects of extracellular vesicles in aging and diabetic kidney disease, and 3) assess performance of extracellular vesicles as a drug delivery system for senolytics; therein contributing to the advancement of future treatments for diabetic and age-related kidney dysfunction.
