IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Alida Biosciences is a start-up company focused on reading the epitranscriptomic code, a regulatory layer of biological information controlling how the genetic code is used in cells in health and in disease progression. By creating and commercializing the first platform for reading multiple elements of this epitranscriptomic code simultaneously, we will enable new science to understand the progression of diseases such as cancer and accelerate drug development targeting epitranscriptomic pathways.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Overall Narrative/Summary Our research focuses on understanding the mechanisms that lead individuals to develop Alzheimer’s disease (AD). There is agreement among researchers that astrogliosis, a form of inflammation) plays a critical role in the mechanism of AD but measurement in the living brain has been challenging. The present PPG proposes to explore the relationship of astrogliosis to AD pathology and AD risk factors using a combination of state-of-the- art neuroimaging, clinical, blood biomarker (and neuropathological tools.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The National Social Life, Health, and Aging Project (NSHAP) is a longitudinal study linking social, cognitive, physical, and mental health trajectories among older adults (born 1920-1965) and their coresident spouses and romantic partners. As a follow up to NS HAP Round 4 (conducted 2021-22 with all Cohort 1 and Cohort 2 respondents), NSHAP Rounds 4.2 and 4.4 will produce two critical datasets, fielded two years apart, with the subset of 1,500 NSHAP respondents identified as having higher risk of mortality or who are demographically matched but have lower mortality risk, for comparison. Including all Black and Hispanic respondents from past rounds of NSHAP and adding new measures that are culturally attuned to the experiences of Black and Hispanic older adults will provide the scientific community, clinicians, policymakers, and the public valuable data on health problems impacting older adults, including cognitive decline and Alzheimer's Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD) among others.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Abnormal and potentially life-threatening blood clotting is seen in other severe infections, such as SARS- CoV-2, MERS, and H1N1 influenza, but the regulation of platelet-producing megakaryocytes is poorly understood. Our recent study suggests a novel role for gut bacteria-derived metabolites in limiting the coagulation response by dampening megakaryopoiesis and platelet turnover. This proposal will define the role of the gut microbiome in the regulation of megakaryocyte maturation and function at steady state and in viral infection, and potentially identify gut microbiome-based therapies (probiotics and diet) to optimize megakaryocyte function and coagulation in infection and other disease settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proper level of excitability of bladder sensory afferents is essential for sensing bladder filling and urine chemical composition. Bladder afferent hypersensitivity induced by injury, inflammation, or during neurodegeneration causes urinary urgency, frequency, and pelvic pain which impact millions of Americans. The current proposal aims to examine the analgesic role of peripheral sensory glial cells in decreasing primary afferent sensitivity and reversing inflammation-induced visceral pain and bladder overactivity in mice, which will markedly expand our knowledge on the roles of peripheral glial cells in regulating bladder function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  When a person is found to have a mass that is localized to their kidney (LRM), they face many choices on what to do about it, but their doctors can offer little advice since there is little guidance from prior studies. To address this, we will first create a database between three different academic hospital systems that gathers all known information about the health of the patient and the LRM. This information can then be used to create specific treatment pathways that can help the doctor and patient decide what is best for the patient, particularly in terms of treating the cancer while trying to save the function of their kidney and minimize side effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: HPV associated cancers are significant causes of morbidity and mortality and are not decreasing with the use of antiretroviral therapy, as has been seen with other HIV-associated malignancies. As WHO strives to eliminate cervical cancer globally, and African nations reach out to MSM populations to engage them in care, developing a regional hub for translational research in HPV/HIV associated cancers in Rwanda and DRC, will be a key resource in understanding how to mitigate the impact of HIV and HPV on the health of Africans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our long-term goal is to identify mechanisms for initiation of food allergy by exposures of skin with barrier mutations and to identify factors for detection of risk for skin sensitization. As a step towards our long-term goal, our central HYPOTHESIS is that, early in life, initiation of food allergy by skin exposure to allergen is mediated by signals from keratinocytes with skin barrier mutations that induce a network of cell signals in the skin for activation of the immune system to generate allergen-specific IgE. These mechanistic studies will have a sustained impact in providing a basis towards designing interventions and clinical studies to modify food allergy initiation early in life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Effective administration and leadership form the cornerstone of effective and productive organizations. The Center research and capacity building success requires an effective Administrative Core, so that the high-value research in HPV malignancies can be conducted and shared, and laboratory infrastructure can be effectively developed and optimally utilized. Developing local capacity to lead the Center is critical to research independence in Africa, and to the success of our Research projects and Cores.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sub-Saharan Africa carries a disproportionate burden of HIV and a high burden of virally induced malignancies. Investigations of HPV-related malignancies are heavily dependent on laboratory testing and histopathology, which can be implemented in resource limited settings. The Rwanda/DRC/Einstein HIV- Associated HPV-Malignancies Research Center (HAMRC) proposed in this application will extend both the geographic and the scientific scope of our research and capacity-building activities, in part by developing a Shared Resources Core to support high risk HPV typing and next generation sequencing-based microbiome analysis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative There is a growing consensus that men and women differ in their response to kidney injury, and their susceptibility and progression to chronic kidney disease. We will combine powerful single cell technologies with genetic studies to determine how distinct male and female cell types are generated in the mouse kidney and how these are modified during reproduction. Comparative analysis on human kidney datasets will identify shared, and species-specific, sex programs in the male and female kidney.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Title: Developmental Core of the Rwanda/DRC/Einstein HPV/HIV-Associated Malignancies Research Center (HHAMRC) The Developmental Core of the HHAMRC aims to develop a cadre of junior and mid-level researchers who will utilize the resources developed by the Center to catalyze research in HPV/HIV-associated malignancies in Rwanda and the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). The specific aims of the Developmental core are consistent with the goals of the center, and will have a significant impact on public health by building capacity of local researchers and mentoring them to become independent investigators and subsequently serve a leaders of the Center in the future. The Developmental Core will be led by African investigators who are all independently funded researchers, thus, providing the ESIs with role models who have navigated challenges similar to their own and strong examples to follow/learn from.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project is to conduct a prospective study of Rwandan women living with HIV (WLWH) who were and were not immunized against human papillomavirus (HPV) types 6, 11, 16, and 18. The primary goal is to measure the long-term, population effectiveness and protective immunity of HPV vaccination in Rwandan WLWH. The propose study will provide important evidence on benefits of HPV vaccination in WLWH in the context of the World Health Organization’s call to eliminate cervical cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project is to conduct a prospective study in the Democratic Republic, and continue one in Rwanda, of anal and penile high-risk HPV in men who have sex with men (MSM) with and without human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection. The primary goal of the study is to compare and contrast the natural history of anal and penile HPV and related abnormalities, as well as the associated risk factors, in MSM from the two countries. The propose project will provide important knowledge on exposure to HPV and cancer risks in these populations and inform policy on if and what age to vaccinate these high-risk populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Narative Enchondromas are common benign tumors in bone that can cause pain, deformity, be responsible for pathologic fractures, and undergo malignant degeneration to chondrosarcoma. This project will generate data to answer fundamental questions about the role of metabolism in maintaining the viability of cells in cartilaginous neoplasia. It will lay the foundation for the use of novel targeted agents to improve the clinical outcome for patients with enchondromas and chondrosarcomas, conditions for which no effective pharmacologic therapy is currently available.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Americans with African ancestry sustain higher risks of progressive kidney disease after kidney donation. In this proposal we will use unique mouse models to study whether and how well-recognized mutations in the APOL1-gene, contribute to the progressive kidney disease following removal of one kidney. We will specifically focus on studying two risk factors observed in human studies - high blood pressure and activation of immune cells in our mice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Narrative FSHD muscular dystrophy is one of the common muscular dystrophies with no effective treatment and its pathological mechanism remains enigmatic. The project focuses on effective disease modeling in human skeletal myocytes and dissecting the disease mechanism and disease severity/sensitivity determinants. The successful outcome of this project would not only further our understanding of FSHD biology but also lead to the potential development of novel diagnostic/therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Hematopoietic Stem Cells (HSCs) are the functional units of therapeutic bone marrow transplantation. A major goal of hematology research is in vitro expansion of HSCs from umbilical cord blood and other sources to boost stem cell numbers for transplantation, gene transfer and gene editing. Strategies for HSC expansion typically entail co-culture with supportive cell types to recapitulate the hematopoietic microenvironment, or niche, which regulates HSC maintenance, self-renewal, and differentiation. We propose to generate a most comprehensive single cell atlas of the ecosystem of embryonic hematopoiesis. Elucidating the molecular identity of niche cells, specifying their derivation both in vitro and in vivo through the recreation of synthetic niches, and understanding the cell-cell communication that underlies niche interactions with HSPCs is an important goal that has enormous promise to impact ex vivo culture, expansion, and genetic manipulation of HSCs for experimental and therapeutic applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Socio-affective dysfunction underlies myriad neuropsychiatric diseases; prior efforts to develop neuromodulation paradigms for treatment-resistant cases of neuropsychiatric diseases characterized by socio- affective dysfunction have fallen short, in part due to an absence of defined neural dysfunctional-state signals. The overall goal of this R01 proposal is to map the spatiotemporal dynamics of social affective processing and to examine selective modulation of these dynamics in humans undergoing invasive intracranial monitoring for treatment-resistant epilepsy and depression. We leverage first-in-human intracranial neural recording opportunities created by a novel therapeutic platform termed “stereotactic electroencephalography-informed deep brain stimulation” (stereo-EEG-informed DBS; Parent Study UH3-NS103549), as well as the powerful platform of intracranial stereotactic recording and stimulation in patients undergoing epilepsy surgical evaluation to establish the precise structural, functional, and causal properties of the affective salience network as a circuit substrate underlying social processing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Tuberculosis (TB) remains a worldwide problem despite the availability of a vaccine and pharmacopeia, due to the ability of Mycobacterium tuberculosis, the causative agent of TB, to resist sterilization in mammals also known as persistence. The goal of this proposal is to uncover genes implicated in this phenomenon whose deletion would result in elimination of the persister population and sterilization of M. tuberculosis. Furthermore, unmasking M. tuberculosis in vitro and in vivo persistence mechanisms could lead to novel chemotherapies, vaccine development and immunotherapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: RESEARCH INST OF FOX CHASE CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Brain metastasis remains a major cause of morbidity and mortality in patients with cancer, which urgently needs effective therapeutic strategies. Our preliminary studies revealed that fibroblasts support the growth of brain metastasis, by protecting cancer cells from chemotherapeutic treatment and inducing immunosuppression in the brain. Here we propose to investigate the mechanisms underlying the supportive role of fibroblasts in brain metastasis, and test the therapeutic potentials of targeting fibroblasts in the treatment of brain metastasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Recent advances in natural language processing and machine learning offer a unique opportunity to explore highly complex changes in connected speech in the preclinical and prodromal stages of Alzheimer's disease (AD). This study investigates the accuracy and diagnostic performance of non-invasive digital biomarkers in detecting and predicting AD biomarker status in individuals with normal cognition or mild cognitive impairment. It is anticipated that the findings of this project will improve the ability to detect and track longitudinal changes in the cognitive and functional status in AD.

PHR: This re-competition application describes the previous experience of our multidisciplinary group in conducting  early Phase clinical trials of experimental cancer therapeutics and related correlative translational science  studies through the National Cancer Institute Experimental Therapeutics-Clinical Trials Network (ETCTN). It  details the continued plans of our consortium to perform comprehensive conduct of early clinical trials, more  selective and sophisticated clinical and translational investigational strategies, and seamless advancement of  experimental agents through early stages of development. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: HEALTH RELEVANCE  The groove of Ranvier (GOR) is a histologically defined structure adjacent to the growth plate that is thought to harbor skeletal stem cells and signaling cells. The GOR is of interest to clinicians as it is located at the site of distal femoral physeal fractures (Salter-Harris type II) that occur in children and that can severely impair bone growth. Our proposed studies will provide new genetic tools to study the GOR and potential therapeutic insight that could be used to prevent growth arrest associated with physeal fractures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ovarian cancer is a deadly disease, but survival varies widely by race/ethnicity. We propose to examine whether differences in neighborhood characteristics, patient and clinical factors including receipt of recommended treatments, or molecular features of the tumors can account for these disparities, at least in part. Ovarian cancer is understudied in diverse populations, and the proposed work is one of the largest to search for potentially modifiable factors that can reduce disparities in survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is the most common chronic liver disease in the United States and it increases the risk of cirrhosis, hepatocellular carcinoma, and cardiometabolic diseases. The proposed research will define how liver ketogenesis actively supports fat breakdown in the tricarboxylic acid cycle and show that loss of this beneficial coupling contributes to the pathological progression of NAFLD. This improved understanding of how mitochondrial pathways coordinate fat disposal will inform new interventions to prevent and treat NAFLD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Targeting CD44 signaling in regulating glioblastoma stemness and immune response Project Narrative: Glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) is usually resistant to standard-of-care treatments including chemotherapy and radiotherapy. In the proposed study, we aim to mechanistically investigate how the oncolytic virus oHSV-CD44 modulates the CD44 signaling in GBM microenvironment. We will test the hypothesis that oHSV-CD44 can modulate tumor CD44 signaling to inhibit the stemness of glioblastoma stem cells, enhance the anti-tumor immune response, and sensitize tumor cells to AKT inhibitors or radiotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Given the impressive mortality rate of pediatric patients with cardiac outflow tract (OFT) defects, there remains a critical need to improve medical and surgical strategies through precise delineation of the cellular, molecular, and biomechanical mechanisms responsible for OFT formation. Our studies illuminate Fibulin proteins, previously unappreciated ECM factors involved in OFT development, as critical regulators of TGF-β signaling and elastogenesis in the bulbous arteriosus. We anticipate that our innovative model characterizing the importance of ECM microenvironment in the evolution of OFT defects will fuel further identification of novel genes associated with congenital heart disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: The medicinal use of cannabis has been legalized widely without much evaluation of patient-level outcomes to determine the health effects, positive or negative, of this policy change. This project will include the establishment of a national patient research registry, a cannabis product surveillance and testing program, a program of evaluating patient electronic medical records and a data repository to integrate data from other sources with those collected as part of these initiatives. The data collected and made available to researchers and the public will help inform clinical decision-making about the medicinal use of cannabis as well as help steer policy and regulatory decisions in the interest of public and patient health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Homeostatic mechanisms are vital for the stability and normal function of neural circuits, but our understanding of the underlying molecular mechanisms, especially how they are triggered and recruited by physiologically relevant sensory stimulations, remains incomplete. In this proposal, we will implement innovative in vivo labeling and live imaging techniques to investigate the functional role of a recently-discovered neuronal membrane- associated proteasome (NMP) in visually driven plasticity paradigms. Understanding how NMP functions in the brain will shed light on a novel proteostasis-based fast homeostatic mechanism and may reveal new avenues for our understanding of the etiology of many neurodevleopmental and neurodegenerative disorders, where dysfunction of proteostasis has been implicated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Children with wheezing and allergic inflammation have dysregulated responses to respiratory viral infection and develop difficulties in breathing. Here we will employ cutting-edge molecular profiling technologies and computational systems biology analyses to unlock the molecular pathways that determine dysregulated antiviral immunity leading to abnormal lung function. If successful, these studies will lead to the identification of novel pathways that represent logical targets for the treatment or prevention of asthma and related traits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Pemphigus is an autoimmune blistering skin disease that occurs sporadically across the globe but is triggered by environmental antigens that could be derived from an insect saliva protein or a virus in the endemic areas. Although the etiology of this unique disease remains unknown, it has been demonstrated that the variation in natural killer (NK) cell receptors and their ligands is strongly associated with the risk of developing pemphigus. Here we propose a comprehensive mapping of functional sequence and structural variation in the genomic regions encoding NK cell receptors, followed by a robust functional validation, to further our understanding of the control of NK cell cytotoxicity and function and its implications in disease.

PHR: Our research will produce critical resources for researchers and decision makers, including databases useful for characterizing the environmental and economic conditions associated with past filovirus (e.g., Ebola, Marburg) outbreaks and disease emergence risk maps. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative - Overview Substance misuse remains the second most common mode of exposure to HIV among AIDS cases nationwide, representing 31% of total diagnoses. In addition, substance use is associated with a more severe course of HIV disease, as shown by the poor immune reconstitution and an increased rate of co-morbidities. The Case Western Reserve University (CWRU) Center for Excellence creates a collaborative environment that strongly supports Substance Use in HIV research at CWRU and for our colleagues in other NIDA-sponsored Centers nationwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A better understanding of how metabolite sensing informs epigenetic responses has promise to uncover novel therapeutic targets for a broad spectrum of human malignancies because cancers depend on metabolic processes to fuel cell division and support malignant gene expression programs. This research proposal seeks to understand contributions of acetyl-co-A and short-chain fatty acids to breast cancer biology and characterize chemical inhibitors and activators of these pathways. In particular, focus on the histone acetyltransferase 1 enzyme complex will serve as a platform to better understand how cancer cells import acyl groups for nuclear epigenetic reactions that drive malignant processes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: This is a competitive renewal that builds on a previous stakeholder-engaged cluster-randomized controlled trial across 28 college campuses and that focuses on undergraduate college students at elevated risk for sexual violence and hazardous drinking (i.e., students with prior history of sexual violence, students who are sexual or gender minority, and students with disabilities). “Reducing Alcohol Involved Sexual violence in higher Education (RAISE)” is a longitudinal study that will test research-informed strategies to improve implementation of a prevention intervention in college health and counseling centers, integrate a safety decision aid (via computer or mobile device) to more directly target harm reduction among students particularly vulnerable to hazardous drinking and SV, and evaluate campus policies that increase accessibility and uptake of confidential services for students. This is the first study to situate a sexual violence prevention intervention in college health and counseling centers to address two significant public health concerns -- alcohol-involved sexual violence and hazardous drinking on college campuses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative – Primary Cell and iPSC-derived Cellular Models Core B Understanding the latent state of HIV and how it is impacted by substance use, specifically cocaine, methamphetamine, and opioids, is a central goal of the CWRU Center for Excellence on the Impact of Substance Use on HIV. Core B will provide primary cell ex vivo models and highly sensitive nucleic acid-based techniques to detect inducible viral RNA in cells recovered from patients. These assays will yield essential information about the control of latency in the brain, gut, and immune system. The Core will provide tools to manipulate and analyze primary cells that would not otherwise be available to Substance Use researchers at our institutions or nationwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: In this exploratory project we seek to extend our investigations of the role of neuroinflammation in human chronic pain to painful trigeminal neuropathy. All participants will receive brain imaging with integrated PET/MRI, before steroid treatment. We will test whether 1) patients demonstrate abnormally elevated PET and MRS markers of neuroinflammation, and whether 2) these brain signals can predict response to steroids.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our lab recently identified genetic material from phage (a virus that infects bacteria) that promoted bacterial skin infection during an outbreak of community-acquired methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (CA-MRSA). To understand why the phage promotes CA-MRSA disease, we will delete candidate gene(s) on the phage for testing in a mouse skin infection model to identify which gene(s) are responsible, and we will determine the effect of the phage on bacterial gene expression during infection. In addition to broadening scientific knowledge about the role of phages in bacterial infection, insights gained from the proposed study will provide novel targets for outbreak surveillance and antibiotic development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: HENRY M. JACKSON FDN FOR THE ADV MIL/MED
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bacterial division and differentiation are carried out by intricate, molecular machines that are spatially and temporally regulated. Most of our knowledge regarding these processes is restricted to ‘model organisms’ whose genomes tend to encode highly complex structural and regulatory systems that are often absent in more genetically-reduced organisms. The work proposed here outlines a series of studies to address how more minimalist microbes carry out these basic, cellular processes, and assess the capabilities inherent to the molecular complexes conserved between ‘model’ and ‘non-model’ microbes.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We will determine whether single-dose azithromycin is effective in preventing cholera in children who are at extremely high risk of infection. We will also determine the effect of this intervention on the development of antibiotic resistant bacteria. The results will inform future strategies to prevent cholera in children, and improve our understanding of the impact of azithromycin on antibiotic resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative - Computational Biology in Substance Use Core C Substances of abuse have a major impact on immunological, virological, gastrointestinal, and neurological outcomes associated with HIV disease progression, viral latency, and successful treatment. The complexity and multiplicity of the mechanisms associated with these effects requires the implementation of a comprehensive strategy to identify the mechanisms that lead to these defects. This core will develop and implement a holistic and unbiased analytical strategy that allows investigators in the CWRU Center of Excellence to identify mechanisms triggered by drug use that underlie these defects, thereby leading to the development of novel therapeutic approaches tailored to persons with substance use disorder and HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As the first comprehensive assessment of drug-induced pancreatic injury using modern epidemiologic and biostatistical techniques, the proposed research is relevant to public health because it is expected to identify which medications cause drug-induced pancreatic injury. This will directly impact post-pancreatitis medication management by reducing clinical uncertainty about which medications to stop to prevent recurrent pancreatitis and which essential medications to continue to treat patients’ other conditions. Furthermore, the proposed research is relevant to Scientific Goal 1 and Research Opportunity 2.4 of the 2021 NIDDK Strategic Plan because it will generate hypotheses about biologic and pharmacodynamic mechanisms of drug-induced pancreatic injury through novel data science techniques.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This prospective, two-parallel-arm, randomized controlled trial tests whether time-restricted eating (TRE; 8-hour eating/16-hour fasting) improves treatment-related toxicity, patient-reported adverse events and quality of life, and tumor regression (Aim 1) among rectal cancer patients compared to control (>12-hour eating). Aim 2 explores the underlying molecular mechanisms and tests whether these improvements are mediated through the IGF-1 pathway. Aim 3 examines whether mood, psychosocial functioning, daily activity, sleep and dietary intake moderate the relationships between intervention arms and clinical outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The protein, eIF4E, is important to normal cells and when dysregulated can drive the development of a broad array of cancers. eIF4E does this by co-opting the signal from the DNA (known as RNA) allowing it to generate more of the proteins that can drive cancer. In this proposal, we identified a new mechanism by which eIF4E not only increases the protein-coding capacity of an RNA, but changes its structure, by subverting a process known as splicing. We can exploit this new knowledge to ultimately develop new therapeutic strategies for high-eIF4E cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Excessive consumption of fructose or alcohol causes fatty liver and occasionally liver cancer, but whether these two dietary risk factors synergistically induce liver cancer is unknown. In this proposal, we will determine how fructose intake alters liver handling of alcohol to increase liver cancer risk. To achieve this goal, we will employ state-of-the-art mass spectrometry and our newly generated genetically modified mice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative - Clinical and Behavioral Services Core D Our understanding of the impact of substance use on HIV and those at-risk for HIV is limited by access to patients in this extremely vulnerable and marginalized population. The Clinical and Behavioral Services Research Support Core D’s activities will create, maintain, and expand a Clinical Database and Specimen Repository of this population to enable researchers the opportunity to complete translational investigations on difficult to reach and retain populations. The Clinical database, as well as their biological samples, will initially include HIV substance using individuals and then expand to include at-risk HIV negative substance using individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to the public health because craniofacial malformations, including cleft palate and congenital skull deformity, are among the most common birth defects. Our proposed study aims to improve the understanding how these craniofacial malformations occur and how the occurrence can be affected by environmental pollutants. Discovery from the study will help provide new strategies to prevent or decrease the risk of birth defects and inspire the development of novel therapeutic options.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRIATIVE The cycle of violence is an under addressed public heath treat that disproportionately affects Black children and young adults in the United States (US) through the impact of structural and systemic racism. Life Outside Violence (LOV), the St. Louis region-wide hospital-based violence intervention program, is an individualized program that provides counseling and social- and case-based services to promote healing and prevent re- injury and death in patients who have presented to a LOV partner hospital with a violent injury. This project is a multi-center, mixed-methods study of barriers and facilitators of LOV enrollment informed by the social- ecologic model that uses community-based participatory research methods with an intervention mapping operational structure to design and assess an improved pathway to engage violently injured patients in the program.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative – Pilot Research Project Core E Substance use remains the second most common mode of exposure to HIV among infected individuals nationwide, representing 31% of total diagnoses. In addition, substance use is associated with a more severe course of HIV disease as shown by poor immune reconstitution and increased rate of co-morbidities. This core provides financial support, mentoring, and training for junior and under-represented minority faculty working in this arena.

PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed work focuses on understanding basic cellular and molecular mechanisms that underlie the production and function of blood cells; specifically in regulating the production and terminal development of blood cells (hematopoiesis), regulating the expression of genes relevant to normal blood-cell maturation and function, and defining regulatory molecules that influence blood cell production from hematopoietic stem cells and progenitors. Broad community access to these deliverables will to accelerate scientific progress in understanding, treatment and prevention of diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE My proposed studies will elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which activation and repression dually ensure precise cardiac regeneration enhancer activity in uninjured and regenerating hearts. My studies also seek to identify novel cardiac regeneration enhancers in the genomes of zebrafish, mice, and humans, which will reveal how cardiac regeneration enhancer activity and regulation have evolved across regenerative and non- regenerative species. These studies will utilize genetic tools and the endogenous regenerative ability of the zebrafish heart to elucidate transcriptional mechanisms underlying heart regeneration and identify potential targets for improving heart repair in mammals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Some genetic diseases result not because cells make a defective protein component, but rather because they don’t make enough of the component. We have identified a widely applicable, targeted approach to induce cells to increase the protein output from a single ‘good’ copy of a gene. We aim to define all such clinically relevant targets, and to apply our existing knowledge to a mouse model of specific, incurable, fatal disease called pulmonary arterial hypertension.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The phototransduction pathway in retinal rods is a highly amplified GPCR (rhodopsin)-coupled signaling pathway responsible for vision in dim light. The loss of the proper regulation for the coupling of rhodopsin to its G-protein partner transducin, or in the subsequent stimulation of the cyclic GMP phosphodiesterase by activated transducin-a, has been linked to retinal degeneration and various eye diseases. We propose to learn more about the proper functioning of these critically important signaling steps with the ultimate goal of identifying new therapeutic strategies against these vision disorders, as well as gain fundamental insights into other GPCR-dependent sensory response pathways that have clinical relevance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: Aging and age-related metabolic dysfunction poses unprecedented challenge to public health, and development of innovative and targetable interventions is highly warranted. Our project will examine the interplay of the microbiome and cellular senescence underlying diet-induced metabolic dysfunction in mice with older age. It will offer an integrative understanding of pathophysiology of age-related diseases, and lay a solid foundation to develop robust interventions targeting senescence, microbiome or both to improve health and increase longevity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposed effort will develop, enable access to, and substantially improve information on viruses from the perspective of their evolutionary relationships and taxonomy. It will provide the infrastructure needed to deliver that information, advancing the capacity of bench scientists, computer scientists, educators, trade regulators, pharmaceutical firms, government agencies, policy makers, and the general public to conduct leading edge research, mitigate the threat posed by virus disease, and better understand the risks posed by viruses to human, animal, and agricultural health. This work will also contribute to national and international security by helping governments to respond to unforeseen outbreaks of virus diseases such as COVID-19.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Bladder cancer is the sixth most common cancer in the United States, but current screening tests have low sensitivity, high cost, or require invasive procedures. My proposal will generate a non-invasive, low-cost diagnostic workflow to detect bladder cancer, consisting of a novel method to enrich the cells that give rise to bladder cancer from voided urine and a flow-cytometry assay to detect tumor-specific DNA changes in those cells with high performance characteristics. The goal of this work is to improve outcomes of patients with bladder cancer through the early detection of their disease, when it can be cured without removal of the bladder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Individuals with Lewy body dementia (LBD), one of the Alzheimer’s disease-related dementias, frequently have difficulty accessing specialty care due to limited access to medical specialists, rural residence, travel distances, and physical, cognitive, and behavioral impairments making travel to appointments more challenging. I propose to develop and test a stakeholder-designed telemedicine model of LBD interdisciplinary care. I will also assess the use of a Samsung Galaxy watch to measure a potentially modifiable risk factor of mortality called life-space mobility (the spatial area and frequency through which an individual moves through).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Forensic populations have a rate of traumatic brain injury seven times higher than the general population. Traumatic brain injury is a risk factor for risk-taking behavior, substance use and future offending. There is almost no neuroimaging literature on brain injury in forensic populations. Here we leverage an existing sample and follow-up with a large subsample (n=300) of male and female offenders with varying history and severity of brain injury. This will create a longitudinal time-point to assess change-over-time in neuroimaging measures and relate these to brain injury and other risk factors. Algorithms developed in our laboratory will be tested to assess their generalizability to measuring brain injury and cognitive decline from multimodal neuroimaging data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The antileukemic drug asparaginase is a central component of curative therapy for several acute leukemias, but the development of resistance is a major clinical problem with a poor prognosis. We found that inhibition of the kinase GSK3α induces asparaginase sensitization in several drug-resistant subtypes of acute leukemia. We propose to investigate the biology underlying this potent therapeutic interaction, which is expected to provide fundamental insights into the amino acid starvation response, and allow its rational therapeutic exploitation for maximal clinical benefit.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it develops new methods to investigate the neural circuits governing naturalistic social behaviors in animal models, and such behaviors are often disrupted in human psychiatric disorders such as autism, schizophrenia, and depression. Our objective is to use computer vision and machine learning algorithms (AI) to produce detailed and reproducible measurements capturing the richness of social behaviors, and to correlate those behaviors with simultaneously recorded neural activity in freely interacting animals. We apply these techniques in established and novel social behavior assays to test hypotheses about the neural mechanisms underlying social behavioral decision-making.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Sickle cell disease (SCD) is a devastating genetic blood disorder that disproportionately affects individuals living in low- and middle-income countries and is associated with significant morbidity and mortality, especially in children under age 5. Early diagnosis and treatment could save an estimated 9 million lives by 2050, but currently available tests are either too costly and complex, or ineffective at diagnosing SCD in children who have received emergency blood transfusions to treat acute, severe anemia resulting from SCD. A novel DNA-based nucleic acid amplification test for SCD diagnosis at the point of care could enable immediate and appropriate treatment, thus decreasing the number of deaths of young children due to SCD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heavy episodic drinking and sexual assault (SA) are problematic on college campuses and risk differs based on gender identity and sexual orientation. Alcohol and Sexual Assault Prevention (ASAP) is a web-based personalized feedback intervention for alcohol use and SA tailored based on risk group (cisgender heterosexual men, cisgender heterosexual women, and sexual/gender minorities). The current study will assess the short- and long-term efficacy of ASAP on heavy episodic drinking and SA among college students.

PHR: Narrative A genomics diverse community of data scientists are needed to fully use the growing genetics and data to support biomedical research and translation into the clinic. Here, we present the Pathways in Genomic Data Science (PATH-GDS) research experience program where we will recruit, train, and build a community of genomic data scientists from groups traditionally underrepresented in biomedical research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE – PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Mitochondria are essential organelles in all eukaryotic cells, and their dysfunction has severe consequences in development and diseases. Mitochondria are highly dynamic through biogenesis, trafficking, changing morphology and targeted removal. Our research seeks fundamental understanding of the regulatory biology of mitochondria under normal physiology focusing on the crosstalk among mitochondrial dynamics, mitochondrial functions, cellular metabolism and signaling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Metastatic disease accounts for >90% of cancer-related deaths worldwide, yet this phase of tumor progression is the least biologically understood. To address this challenge, we will integrate newly developed protein phenotyping technology, sophisticated computational biologic analyses, and an understudied neoplastic hybrid cell that represents the largest tumor population in peripheral blood. Our proposed study will explore the biology underlying the lifecycle of a disseminated neoplastic hybrid cells providing new insights into metastatic disease effectors, identification of pre-metastatic tumor states, and evaluation of a stage II colorectal cancer patient cohort in need of new approaches for treatment stratification to impact their survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The objective of the major study proposed in this K01 application is to first, develop and validate a random forest machine learning algorithm (MLA) to predict risk of uncontrolled blood pressure among adults with hypertension. Second, identify barriers and facilitators to implementing an MLA-clinical decision support (CDS) tool that predicts uncontrolled blood pressure into clinical settings by conducting key-informant interviews and focus groups with primary care clinicians and patients. Third, compare clinical management of hypertension with and without information from the MLA on whether a patient will have uncontrolled blood pressure through a case-vignette study.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Intimate partner violence (IPV) is considered a public health problem in the United States, with many scholars identifying it as a public health crisis. American Indian (AI) and Black women in the United States are disproportionately affected by IPV with the communities in which they live also currently disproportionately affected by the COVID-19 pandemic. It is an urgent matter of public health that we systematically identify, in an effort to minimize, the barriers to help- seeking for IPV that AI and Black women are experiencing during the pandemic, in order to inform policy and improve health outcomes for AI and Black populations of women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: This application will evaluate our hypothesis that circulating extracellular vesicles (EVs) in T1D, through distinct molecular characteristics, are cytotoxic to beta cell health, thus contributing to the pathogenesis of T1D; with the potential to serve as biomarkers for early disease diagnosis. Our goal is to decode the molecular messages that circulating EVs carry and decipher their functional characteristics. These studies have the potential to provide novel insights into disease pathology as well as to identify new biomarkers and therapeutics for T1D.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project narrative Adolescents and young adults living with HIV need tailored interventions that address their unique social, interpersonal, and developmental needs. Leveraging data from a parent cluster randomized controlled trial that will be testing a Stepped Care intervention to improve retention in care among adolescents and young adults living with HIV, this F31 project aims to evaluate implementation outcomes of the intervention as it is delivered across 10 Kenyan healthcare facilities. This project will provide the F31 candidate with the opportunity to acquire new methods and content-area expertise and develop necessary skills to become an independent researcher.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Children are not small adults; yet clinicians treating pediatric patients rely heavily on information collected in randomized and non-randomized studies of adult populations. To address this evidence gap – which puts pediatric patients at increased risk – we propose to develop and test the performance of tree-based scan statistic (TreeScan) approaches for the systematic and simultaneous evaluation of multiple potential adverse outcomes in pediatric populations, and to implement these methods for prospective sequential surveillance of new pediatric medications. This project will provide a critically needed tool that could lead to early detection of unsuspected adverse effects of drugs in pediatric populations if they exist and provide reassurance if no such safety concerns are detected.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The increasingly crucial role played by informal cancer caregivers (ICs) is often complicated by persistent anxiety and depression, but to date, current psychosocial interventions fail to adequately address IC anxiety and depression. This project is relevant to NIH’s mission as it represents a step in the development of an intervention – Emotion Regulation Therapy for Cancer Caregivers (ERT-C) – that has shown encouraging results in ameliorating IC anxiety and depression. If successful, ERT-C holds significant promise to not only improve the quality of life for ICs across the caregiving trajectory, but also yield downstream benefits to the patients for whom they provide care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Recent studies have shown that the trillions of microbes living on and within us profoundly influence multiple aspects of human physiology. Malaria remains a significant infectious disease causing the death of over 400,000 people annually. Completing these translational studies will lead to an improved understanding of the role of gut microbiota in differential severity of malaria in humans, which could lead to new strategies to prevent malaria-associated mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Losses in key functional abilities with age prevent many Americans from working in jobs of their choosing and hence healthy aging. The goal of this project is to adapt international methods for measuring functional ability to work to the U.S. context and use this information to identify targets for interventions that would restore or prevent loss of specific functional abilities among Americans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO MED SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative This project will test if the alteration of HCN channel function to progressive cocaine exposure is a critical element of drug action on the VTA resulting from epigenetic regulation acquired during the learning process using contingent and non-contingent animal models. One possible outcome of these studies is to identify risk factors for substance abuse disorders related to epigenetic regulation of an ionic channel that regulates neuronal biophysical properties. Knowledge of the epigenetic control of cocaine-induced biophysical neuronal changes ultimately will lead to the identification of new targets in the development of treatments for substance abuse disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sex differences in the incidence, age of onset, progression, and response to treatment in cancer are well documented. This project aims to understand how genetics contributes to observed cancer differences between men and women across a wide spectrum of cancers, with the goal of generating knowledge that can have a clinical impact. The project will: 1) Characterize sex differences at the molecular level in tumors derived from male and female patients, 2) Characterize sex differences in the contribution of inherited genetics to cancer risk, and 3) Discover mechanisms contributing to sex differences in response to cancer therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE Microglia are long-lived central nervous system immune cells that have critical roles in brain immunity and neuron integrity. HIV-1 infection of microglia and the resulting activation of these cells is hypothesized to drive inflammation in the brain and AIDS-associated neurocognitive diseases. We are proposing to use a novel cell model to explore how HIV RNA expression in microglia mediates this inflammatory response. These studies are relevant for understanding how HIV perpetuates disease even in the presence of antiretroviral treatments and could provide new targets and strategies for treatments to improve the lives of people living with HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Humans with IgE sensitization to the mammalian oligosaccharide allergen galactose-a-1,3- galactose (a-gal) have larger coronary artery plaques and unstable plaque features signifying increased coronary artery disease (CAD) compared to those without IgE to a-gal. However, the causal role of IgE to a-gal in CAD is unknown. The proposed research seeks to understand whether IgE to a-gal directly promotes atherosclerotic plaque development and define immune mechanisms mediating IgE sensitization to a-gal linked to atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease in mice and humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Lipids play an important role as signaling molecules to increase insulin secretion. However, the unregulated accumulation of lipids damages beta cells resulting in type 2 diabetes. By examining how intracellular trafficking of lipids are regulated at an intracellular organelle called lipid droplets, we aim to identify a way to achieve effective usage of lipids in beta cells, while preventing accumulation of toxic lipids that lead to type 2 diabetes.

PHR: Project Narrative The primary objective of this proposal is to assess the anti-cancer efficacy of the selective glucosylceramide synthase inhibitor, eliglustat, alone and in combination with anti-PD-L1 in preclinical mouse models of triple- negative breast cancer, and to define the mechanism(s) by which eliglustat induces anti-cancer immune response. Success of this proposal will establish utility for eliglustat and other inhibitors of glucosylceramide synthase as novel ‘immunometabolic adjuvants’ for the treatment of TNBC, thus creating a new paradigm for cancer immunotherapy. Given that eliglustat is already FDA-approved for Gaucher disease with established toxicity profiles, it has high potential to readily be directly translated into clinical use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative/Public Health Relevance With greater access to effective treatment, adults with HIV around the world are living to older ages. However, we have little knowledge about aging-related conditions, such as frailty and disability, or their causes in older adults with HIV in low- and middle-income countries where the HIV epidemic is greatest. Understanding how local socioeconomic factors, chronic coinfections, and comorbidities contribute to aging-related diseases and outcomes in older adults with HIV is critically important as life expectancies improve worldwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Although obesity has previously been established as a significant risk factor in the development of several cancer types (including breast cancer) and resistance to immunotherapy, there is a lack of genetic evidence for directly attributing obesity to the initiation or progression of its associated breast cancer. Noncoding RNAs have recently emerged as key players in a multitude of cellular signaling processes, and preliminary data has suggested that the upregulation of the small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA) SNORD46 is correlated with both increases in body mass index (BMI) and diminished infiltration of cytotoxic leukocytes. Therefore, this proposal will dissect the molecular mechanisms of adipocyte-expressed SNORD46 under obese conditions, implicate SNORD46-leukocyte interactions in driving obesity-associated immune resistance, and assess the efficacy of a SNORD46 LNAs targeted therapy in improving CD8+ T-cell infiltration and sensitizing obesity-associated breast tumors to immunotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed project aims to develop innovative digital media messages (e.g., photos, videos, pictures with text, text-only content) targeting alcohol-involved bystander intervention, or how alcohol use functions to inhibit bystander intervention for sexual violence. A pilot study will be conducted to assess the feasibility, acceptability, and preliminary efficacy of digital media messages in a social media intervention among high- risk college students who engage in heavy episodic drinking. This R21 has great potential to inform a scalable social media intervention targeting alcohol-involved bystander intervention, particularly among college students who engage in high-risk drinking.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: HCC is a highly aggressive cancer whose incidence is on the rise, made of cells resembling hepatocytes, resulting from chronic Hepatitis B/C Virus infection, non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), and Alcoholic Liver Disease (ALD). Based on our preliminary data in experimental models, metabolic injury accelerates progression of HCC by upregulation of interleukin 17A (IL-17A). Current study will investigate the role of IL-17 signaling in the pathogenesis of ALD-and NASH-induced HCC using mouse models and patient material, and will provide new insights into therapeutic targeting of IL-17 signaling for treatment of HCC patients with ALD and NASH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Restoration of adaptive immunity after radiation damage requires a functional thymus, the fundamental site of T cell generation. Although extremely sensitive to insult, the thymus contains a remarkable capacity for repair; however, thymic regenerative capacity diminishes as a consequence of age and after severe injury such as that caused by radiation injury, leading to a prolonged period of T cell depletion that can impact considerably on outcomes. In this proposal we seek to exploit the mechanisms that govern this regenerative response into rational strategies to boost immune function after radiation damage, even in recipients whose thymus has been impacted by age.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: Project Narrative The precise regulation of cartilage cells is critical for the normal development, morphology and elongation of the long bones. This new project will apply cutting-edge technologies to determine how changes in the expression, and enzymatic activity of an epigenetic factor called Dot1L can influence the growth of the long bones during development. Fundamental knowledge gleamed from our studies will provide new mechanistic insights into how skeletal growth defects arise, and may inform the development of Dot1L-targeted therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Opioid overdose fatalities in women are outpacing that of men, and women with opioid use disorder have unique clinical presentations, barriers to treatment engagement, and treatment needs. Recently the US Department of Health and Human Services’ Office on Women’s Health outlined the importance of providing care to women with opioid use disorder that is gender-specific and emphasized that women-focused services are needed to increase the use of effective medication treatments. This proposal aims to develop and examine the feasibility of a gender-specific digital intervention for women with opioid use disorder in order to increase their initiation and engagement with evidence-based medication treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Endocytosis is a core process used by all eukaryote’s cells to take in nutrients and regulate communication at their surface. Defects in endocytosis are involved in a wide variety of diseases such as cancer, neuropathies and metabolic syndromes, and viruses can infect cells through CME. Understanding how the mechanical properties of the cell’s membrane and the protein machinery at the site of endocytosis will be key to develop new therapies for a broad range of diseases, for example by modulating endocytosis with drugs that control membrane tension rather than target specific proteins.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Prebiotics is a potential treatment for dysbiosis in human gut microbiota, which plays a role in many diseases, including diabetes and obesity. The proposed research is relevant to public health because we will develop and demonstrate the proteomic stable isotope probing approach for characterization of the metabolism of prebiotics by gut microorganisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Pre-cancerous metaplasia develops from reprogramming of protein-secreting chief cells into protective mucous-secreting cells. We will study how innate lymphoid cells (ILC2s) and specific populations of fibroblasts (telocytes) promote both the development of metaplasia as well as progression of metaplasia towards dysplasia. These studies will elucidate elements of the pre-cancerous milieu that may be targets for development of strategies for gastric cancer prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Effective strategies are needed that can secure and direct financial resources to support the adoption of evidence-based practices in adolescent substance use treatment services. The proposed research aims to compare two grant-making strategies used by the U.S. Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration on the widespread adoption and sustained use of one such evidence-based practice, the Adolescent Community Reinforcement Approach, over the past 13+ years. Results will provide critically needed information about the effects of different grant-making strategies in supporting widespread and long- term availability of evidence-based practices, which is necessary to achieving large-scale reductions in adolescent substance use disorders and their major associated public health and societal impacts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE: The Breast Cancer Family Registry (BCFR) Cohort is an international cohort in the U.S., Canada and Australia comprised of multi-generational families (33,037 women and 6,992 men from 15,056 families) that started in 1995. We will strengthen and continue to provide to the research community an important and unique long-term family cohort with extensive epidemiologic and molecular data to address cutting-edge and clinically important research questions on breast cancer susceptibility, outcomes, survival and survivorship with the overall goal of advancing knowledge of the biology of breast cancer development and progression so as to reduce the cancer burden and cancer disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  The proposed studies seek an integrated, systems level understanding of how multiple molecular mechanisms collaborate to control the critical biological switch from proliferation to differentiation, a key regulatory point in the adult stem cell lineages that underlie tissue maintenance and repair. Failure to cleanly execute this switch may contribute to genesis of cancer. Our results will reveal how cell type and stage specific alternative mRNA processing, translational control, changes in chromatin architecture, cell type specific transcriptional regulators, and cell-cell communication act together to ensure that proliferation of precursor cells ceases and the correct gene expression program for differentiation of the right specialized cell type is turned on.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: NORTH CAROLINA AGRI & TECH ST UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. Meprin metalloproteases have been implicated in the pathophysiology of chronic kidney injury induced by diabetes and neurodegenerative disease (e.g. Alzheimer’s disease). The proposed research program will determine; (1) how single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in the meprin genes impact interaction between the meprin enzymes and their substrates, (2) how cleavage of meprin substrates influence signaling pathways involved in disease progression, and (3) the potential use of meprins and meprin cleavage products in early diagnosis of tissue injury. This knowledge is important in developing therapeutic targets and diagnostic tools for diseases such as chronic kidney injury and Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Due to the development of highly effective treatments for HIV and the resulting increased longevity among people with HIV, this population now loses more life years to smoking than to HIV infection itself. Novel and effective models to deliver wider reaching smoking cessation interventions to individuals with HIV are highly needed and indicated as a priority for NIH. This study will generate new clinical evidence for a novel intervention for this population as well as guidance about how to implement it in real-world settings.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal seeks support for the purchase of a JEOL 500 MHz NMR spectrometer that was installed accord- ing to an evaluation agreement without any down payment. This spectrometer is serving as an essential core resource to support diverse biomedical research programs at the Johns Hopkins Medical School campus. The instrument will provide essential structural characterizations of small molecule drug candidates, new clinical im- aging agents, and small molecule metabolites isolated from cells and tissues. The programs supported involve cancer, neuroscience, metabolomics, and general drug discovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Right ventricular (RV) failure is widely recognized to worsen patient outcomes in the setting of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF)-related pulmonary hypertension (PH), yet we fall short in trying to identify and treat it. The current proposal will (1) determine the best clinical indicators of intrinsic RV cardiomyocyte contractile failure in humans with HFrEF-PH, (2) clarify underlying mechanisms, and (3) test novel treatments on RV cardiomyocytes. The long-term goal of this proposal will be to better identify and treat RV failure in humans suffering from HFrEF-PH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Pathogens often exist as diverse populations, where each strain or isolate may differ in the sequence of its genome. Determining how these genetic differences affect the behavior, transmission, drug resistance, and overall risk profile of viral, bacterial, fungal, and parasitic pathogens is important to human health. The proposed research will lead to a greater understanding of what makes a pathogen successful in nature, and ultimately to improved countermeasures against infectious diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: NARRATIVE Microvascular insufficiency underlies many common, chronic diseases, including diabetic retinopathy and neuropathy, chronic venous insufficiency and leg ulcers, cerebral infarction, and coronary microvascular disease. Creating microvessel networks that structurally and functionally mimic the native microvasculature is critical for a wide range of tissue engineering and regenerative medicine applications. The overall goal of this project is to advance a novel ultrasound technology to fabricate complex, functional microvessel networks directly in vivo.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Thymic epithelial cells (TECs) are critical for the development of T cell-mediated immunity, and age-associated declines in their function cause thymus atrophy and diminish T cell responses to infection and vaccination in the elderly. This project aims to identify the underlying mechanisms that cause age-associated TEC dysfunction to identify therapeutic strategies for thymus regeneration, and to test those strategies for their capacity to improve cell responses to viral challenge in aged animals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Project Narrative This research project builds on our current community partner relationships and uses a Community-Based Participatory Research (CBPR) framework to culturally adapt and test the feasibility of a Behavioral Activation and Therapeutic Exposure for Grief (BATE-G) intervention among American Indian and Alaska Native (AI/AN) people who are experiencing impairing grief-related symptoms diagnosed as Persistent Complex Bereavement Disorder (PCBD). BATE-G employs trained AI/AN community paraprofessionals to deliver intervention content via telehealth, increasing access to culturally responsive evidence-based treatments for this often-underserved population. This project will also contribute to the research and training development of an early career investigator whose career goals center around understanding and addressing health inequalities in underserved communities with a focus on trauma and grief.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Our proposed research aims to revolutionize proton therapy by developing a compact fixed beamline system that enables ultra-fast dose delivery. By reducing single-field delivery time to a few seconds and total treatment time by up to 50% compared to current systems, this technology will enhance patient care, improve treatment quality and increase patient throughput, which, combined with a small facility footprint, will ultimately make proton therapy more accessible and cost-effective. This innovative solution has the potential to significantly advance the field of cancer treatment and improve public health outcomes by optimizing the delivery of proton therapy to a wide range of patients.

PHR: Project Narrative: Transmission electron microscopes are the most powerful microscopes, producing high resolution images at a resolution a thousand times higher than a light microscope, allowing study of intricate details within a cell. Changes in these sub-cellular features provide important clues to mechanisms of disease, dysfunction in aging, cancer, and genetic disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE The purpose of our proposed study is to refine induced pluripotent stem cell (iPSC)-neuronal model systems by providing developmentally appropriate extracellular matrix (ECM) cues. We will first define the composition and nature of remodeling of the mammalian CNS matrisome in vivo, and then leverage our combined expertise in iPSC technologies and biomaterials to establish ECM mimetic matrices that can recapitulate the architecture and modulatory activity of the physiological matrisome and facilitate the maturation and aging of stem cell derived neuronal models in vitro.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed 3 Tesla, whole-body, wide-bore magnetic resonance imaging system (3T GE SIGNA Premier XT) would fulfill unmet research needs at the University of Colorado Anschutz Medical Campus while providing greater scientific and funding opportunities for investigators across a wide range of departments and institutions. Specifically, the new system would provide much needed additional scanning capacity and offer higher signal-to-noise ratios, less distortion, shorter exam times, facilitate substantially quieter scanning, and allow access to newer imaging techniques not available on our current platform. These benefits will be particularly important for research involving behavioral health, obesity/metabolic disorders, and neurodevelopment.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative Teenagers and young adult women whose menstrual periods cease due to restrictive eating disorders, such as anorexia nervosa, and/or from excessive exercise, have low bone density and increased fracture risk. This double-blind, placebo-controlled study will examine whether administration of a medication (romosozumab) for 6 months that increases bone formation and reduces bone breakdown, followed by a single dose of an additional medication (zoledronate) to extend the effects of romosozumab will provide a necessary boost to allow bone health to normalize in teenagers and young adult women with these disorders who are also receiving estrogen replacement.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
ORG_NAME: SANFORD BURNHAM PREBYS MEDICAL DISCOVERY INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The SBP Functional Genomics Shared Resource conducts various high-throughput chemical and genetic screens using the Hamilton STAR and Agilent Bravo equipment, which have reached their hardware capacity and limits and are therefore obsolete. Users at the shared resource are unable to operate these semi-automated platforms to execute high-valued arrayed library screening and resolve critical questions raised in current NIH- funded research. Fortunately, the proposed high-throughput automation model, Beckman Coulter Biomek i7, will be able to streamline the entire screening process, including assay development, arrayed library preparation and screening, and target validation in cellular disease models. The acquisition of the Beckman Coulter Biomek i7 will help propel the discovery of novel targets and their underlying mechanisms, advancing our understanding of a wide spectrum of human diseases. The disease indications being studied at SBP that will benefit from this automation include COVID-19, childhood diseases, including leukemia, brain cancer, and Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy, as well as adult diseases such as breast cancer, aging-specific chronic inflammation, Alzheimer’s disease, and its related dementia. Deployment of the Biomek i7 automation will help accelerate the development of innovative therapeutics, which is the primary objective of these NIH-funded projects.

PROJECT_TITLE: Beckman Coulter Biomek i7 Hybrid automated workstation

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Microprocessor-controlled knees (MPKs) do not typically utilize motors to power joint rotation, but they automatically adjust resistance or damping in the joint to improve swing- and/or stance-phase control as appropriate for the prosthesis user during gait. The Ossur Power Knee is the only commercially-available MPK that uses a motor to provide active power generation during walking and other activities. The purpose of this proposed investigation is to perform and compare biomechanical evaluations of the Power Knee and Ossur Rheo XC, a passive MPK, during walking and other activities by prosthesis users. Furthermore, we will compare mobility between male and female subjects to determine if there are differences in prosthetic knee usage on the basis of sex. The Veterans Health Administration (VHA) reported that between 1989-1998, 29% of amputations were performed at the transfemoral level. This emphasizes the strong relevance and potentially high impact of this research study on current Veterans, which is directly applicable to the VHA’s Patient Care Mission.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Project Narrative  Currently, a great majority of research projects that study mechanisms of diseases are dependent on microscopy techniques that allow them to look at the organization, localization and dynamic behavior of proteins inside cells, tissues and entire organisms to better understand how they affect and control human body health and disease. The microscopes utilized in research are extremely valuable and often get surpassed by technological improvements that can easily change the quality and speed of the research produced. The current request is to acquire a microscope called Nikon SoRa W1-spinning disk confocal with photo-stimulation and photo-ablation that will replace our obsolete 13 years old system with improved technology capable of producing higher quality and super-resolution (at 120 nm scale) live images that are essential for the comprehension of how cancer cells function and develop.
